questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. She has no history of serious illness. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 96/52 mm Hg. Examination shows a 2/6 continuous, low-pitched murmur over the left upper sternal border that radiates towards the neck. The murmur disappears when she flexes her neck. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis can also be asymptomatic. However, the condition typically manifests with a systolic murmur that has a point of maximal intensity over the second left intercostal space at the sternal border.

B) INCORRECT:

A patent ductus arteriosus commonly manifests in asymptomatic patients with a loud continuous murmur (machinery murmur) that is best heard at the left infraclavicular region but does not typically disappear on flexion of the head.
Image Description:

Continuous systolic and diastolic heart murmur (machinery murmur)

C) CORRECT:

A venous hum is a common benign finding on auscultation in childhood. The murmur is most likely caused by turbulence in the internal jugular vein (e.g., when blood enters the thoracic inlet). Although typically a continuous murmur that can occur on either side of the neck, it tends to be louder during diastole and is more common on the right. The murmur disappears or becomes softer on compression of the internal jugular vein, lying in the supine position, or flexion of the head, as seen here. This feature helps differentiate it from the murmur in a patent ductus arteriosus.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can also be asymptomatic. However, the typical murmur associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a systolic ejection murmur at the left lower sternal border that increases in loudness with performance of the Valsalva maneuver and decreases with hand grip, squatting, or lying down.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

E) INCORRECT:

Coronary artery fistulas are often asymptomatic and therefore an incidental finding on physical examination. While they also manifest with a continuous murmur, the point of maximal intensity is most commonly located at the left lower sternal border and the murmur would not disappear with flexion of the head.

F) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis may remain asymptomatic for years. However, cardiac examination typically reveals a harsh crescendo-decrescendo (diamond-shaped), late systolic ejection murmur that radiates to the carotids bilaterally and that is heard best in the second intercostal space on the right. The murmur is typically decreased by hand grip rather than by flexing the head.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

G) INCORRECT:

Small atrial septal defects can also be asymptomatic. However, the typical murmur in ASD is a systolic ejection murmur over the left second intercostal space at the sternal border, often accompanied by a soft middiastolic murmur over the lower left sternal border, and a widely split second heart sound that does not change with respiration.
Image Description:

A fixed split does not change with respiration and tends to be wide (i.e., the split is also audible during expiration). It may occur in atrial septal defect or severe right ventricular failure.

A2: closure of aortic valve; P2: closure of pulmonary valve

H) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal defects, especially if they are small, can also be asymptomatic and create a loud murmur. However, the typical murmurs are a harsh holosystolic murmur over the left sternal border and sometimes a middiastolic murmur over the cardiac apex.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

I) INCORRECT:

Coarctation of the aorta can also manifest with a continuous murmur. However, it is typically not only heard below the left clavicula but also in between the shoulder blades. Additional findings are also common, such as a systolic ejection murmur over the left paravertebral region, increased blood pressure in the upper extremities, cold feet, or claudication of the lower extremity, none of which are present in this patient.

J) INCORRECT:

Patients with mitral valve prolapse are also typically asymptomatic. However, cardiac examination usually shows a high-frequency, midsystolic click that is best heard at the fifth left intercostal space in the midclavicular line or a high-frequency, mid-to-late systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur that may radiate to the axilla in the same region.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.
questions.hint: This condition is caused by the high-velocity flow of blood through blood vessels.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician for generalized fatigue and mild shortness of breath on exertion for 3 months. He has a history of recurrent patellar dislocations. He is at the 99th percentile for height and at the 30th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 140/50 mm Hg. Examination shows scoliosis, a protruding breast bone, thin extremities, and flat feet. Ocular examination shows bilateral upward displacement of the lenses. A grade 3/6 early diastolic murmur is heard along the left sternal border. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical splitting of S2 is the pathological closure of the pulmonic valve before the aortic valve. Instead of the physiologic splitting of S2 with inspiration, S2 will instead split with expiration. Conditions that delay left ventricular outflow, such as aortic stenosis or left bundle branch block, may cause paradoxical splitting of S2. However, AR is unlikely to be the sole cause of a paradoxical splitting of S2.
Image Description:

P2 precedes A2 (audible during expiration but not inspiration).

Certain conditions (e.g., aortic stenosis, left bundle branch block) delay the closure of the aortic valve, resulting in P2 preceding A2. In inspiration, P2 is also delayed (physiological), causing a paradoxical decrease in the split.

A2: closure of aortic valve; P2: closure of pulmonary valve

B) INCORRECT:

Pulsus paradoxus is not associated with AR. Instead, it is classically seen in patients with cardiac tamponade, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, or tension pneumothorax, and is sometimes observed in asthma and pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulsus parvus et tardus is a delayed pulse with a low amplitude that is not associated with AR. Instead, it is seen in patients with aortic stenosis, who typically present with a harsh crescendo-decrescendo late systolic ejection murmur and, in more severe aortic stenosis, with angina, syncope, or heart failure.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

D) INCORRECT:

Fixed splitting of S2 is not associated with AR; it is most commonly a result of an atrial septal defect. The second heart sound arises from the sequential closing of the aortic valve and the pulmonic valve. Inspiration increases right ventricular preload, resulting in a delay in pulmonary valve closure, which produces a physiological splitting of S2. Atrial septal defects produce a left-to-right shunt, increasing right atrial and right ventricular volume and forcing the pulmonic valve to close later regardless of breath.
Image Description:

A fixed split does not change with respiration and tends to be wide (i.e., the split is also audible during expiration). It may occur in atrial septal defect or severe right ventricular failure.

A2: closure of aortic valve; P2: closure of pulmonary valve

E) CORRECT:

A water hammer pulse is a classic finding on cardiovascular examination in patients with AR. On palpation of a peripheral artery, such as the radial artery, the clinician will feel rapid engorgement of the artery followed by a significant, prompt collapse of the vessel. This is due to the incompetent aortic valve failing to maintain adequate diastolic pressure in the arterial system, which also causes a widened pulse pressure. Other findings of AR include pulse synchronous head nodding (de Musset's sign) and, occasionally, a rumbling, low-pitched mid-diastolic murmur (Austin Flint murmur) that is caused by the regurgitant blood striking the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve, leading to premature closure of the mitral leaflets.

Patients with Marfan syndrome often have aortic disease (e.g., aortic regurgitation) as a consequence of cystic medial degeneration.

F) INCORRECT:

Radio-femoral pulse delay is caused by aortic coarctation. Physiologically, pulses rise simultaneously in the radial and femoral arteries. However, due to the restricted blood flow through the narrowed aorta, the femoral pulse will rise later than the radial pulse. AR does not cause radio-femoral pulse delay.
questions.hint: This teenager with tall stature, scoliosis, pectus deformity, thin extremities, and upward displacement of the lenses likely has Marfan syndrome. The presence of an early diastolic murmur and widened pulse pressure indicate aortic regurgitation (AR).

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. He has no history of serious illness. He is at the 60th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 3/6 systolic ejection crescendo-decrescendo murmur is heard along the lower left sternal border. The murmur decreases in intensity on rapid squatting and increases in intensity when he performs the Valsalva maneuver. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Angiodysplasia can be associated with aortic stenosis. While aortic stenosis may also manifest with a systolic murmur, the murmur would decrease with the Valsalva maneuver (decreased preload) and increase with rapid squatting (increased preload). Moreover, aortic stenosis usually presents later in life.

B) INCORRECT:

Predamaged heart valves (e.g., aortic stenosis, mitral valve regurgitation) or congenital heart defects (e.g., ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis) can predispose to infective endocarditis. However, systolic murmurs caused by valvular disease or congenital heart disease generally demonstrate increased intensity with rapid squatting (increased preload) and decreased intensity with the Valsalva maneuver (decreased preload).

C) CORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) can manifest with a systolic ejection murmur caused by subvalvular dynamic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO). Rapid squatting increases left ventricular preload, decreasing the dynamic LVOTO and softening the intensity of the murmur, whereas the Valsalva maneuver decreases preload, which exacerbates dynamic obstruction and makes the murmur louder. Unlike a murmur due to valvular or supravalvular aortic stenosis, which is best heard at the right upper sternal border, the systolic ejection murmur due to HCM is best heard at the left lower sternal border and/or Erb's point (cardiology). Hypertrophic myocardium, fibrosis, and disarrangement of cardiac myocytes predispose to potentially lethal ventricular arrhythmias, which can lead to sudden cardiac death, usually during or after physical activity. Since HCM is the most common cause of sudden cardiac death in young athletes, patients with HCM should be advised to avoid strenuous sports. Those at particularly high risk (e.g., survived a previous arrhythmia) should undergo placement of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator.

D) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical embolism can be associated with atrial septal defects (ASD) or ventricular septal defects (VSD). An ASD can present with a systolic murmur, but it would likely also show fixed splitting of the S2. A VSD can present with a holosystolic (not systolic ejection) murmur. The intensity of both defects would decrease rather than increase with the Valsalva maneuver (decreased preload) and increase with rapid squatting (increased preload).

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary apoplexy can occur in mitral stenosis, which presents with a diastolic murmur heard in the third left intercostal space but not a systolic murmur.

F) INCORRECT:

Cerebral aneurysms may be associated with coarctation of the aorta. Coarctation may present with a systolic ejection murmur over the left paravertebral area due to blood flowing through the aortic narrowing and/or a continuous murmur from collateral vessels heard between the shoulder blades. If the intensity changes at all, it would decrease with the Valsalva maneuver and/or increase with rapid squatting. Coarctation of the aorta may also be accompanied by other symptoms, such as hypertension, lower extremity cyanosis, lower extremity claudication, cold feet, dyspnea on exertion, or chest pain.
questions.hint: Echocardiography would most likely show asymmetric interventricular septal hypertrophy and/or systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve, which are consistent with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. She has been healthy apart from an episode of bronchiolitis as an infant. Her 6-year-old sister recently underwent surgery for ventricular septal defect closure. The patient is at the 60th percentile for height and weight. Her mother is concerned about the possibility of the patient having a cardiovascular anomaly. Which of the following is most likely to indicate a benign heart murmur in this child?

choices.text: A grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur heard along the left lower sternal border that increases on valsalva
A grade 4/6 midsystolic murmur at the right upper sternal border that increases on rapid squatting
A grade 2/6 machine-like murmur heard at the upper left sternal border
A grade 2/6 continuous murmur heard at the right supraclavicular region
A grade 3/6 early diastolic murmur heard at the right sternal border that increases with rapid squatting
A grade 4/6 holosystolic murmur heard along the left lower sternal border that increases on hand grip
A grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur at the apex that increases on hand grip

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur heard along the left lower sternal border that increases with the Valsalva maneuver indicates hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. This is a pathological murmur and must be investigated promptly because it carries a significant risk of sudden death. The Valsalva maneuver increases the intensity of this murmur by decreasing preload. As a result, the pathological systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve (which is the underlying cause of the outflow obstruction in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy) intensifies, enhancing the murmur.

B) INCORRECT:

A grade 4/6 midsystolic ejection murmur at the right upper sternal border that increases on rapid squatting indicates aortic stenosis. Aortic stenosis does not represent a benign heart murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

A grade 2/6 machine-like murmur heard at the upper left sternal border should raise suspicion of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). This is not considered a benign murmur, as patients with PDA are at increased risk of heart failure in infancy and pulmonary hypertension in adolescence and adulthood.

D) CORRECT:

A grade 2/6 continuous murmur heard at the right supraclavicular region is called a central venous hum. It is a benign finding that is common in children and results from turbulent flow in the internal jugular veins. The murmur disappears or gets softer when pressure is applied to the ipsilateral jugular vein, when the head is flexed, or in the supine position.

E) INCORRECT:

A grade 3/6 early diastolic murmur heard at the right sternal border that increases with rapid squatting is indicative of aortic regurgitation. Diastolic murmurs in children are very likely to be pathological and require referral to a specialist. Aortic regurgitation in children is very commonly due to a congenital bicuspid aortic valve.

F) INCORRECT:

A grade 4/6 holosystolic murmur heard along the left lower sternal border that increases on handgrip indicates a ventricular septal defect (VSD). Holosystolic murmurs are nearly always pathological. The handgrip exercise serves to increase afterload in the systemic circulation. As a result, blood flow through the aortic valve is reduced, leading to increased blood flow through the VSD that is detectable as a more intense murmur.

G) INCORRECT:

A grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur at the apex that increases on handgrip indicates mitral regurgitation. Holosystolic murmurs are nearly always pathological. The handgrip exercise serves to increase afterload in the systemic circulation. As a result, blood flow through the aortic valve is reduced, leading to increased retrograde blood flow through the incompetent mitral valve that is detectable as a more intense murmur.
questions.hint: A central venous hum is considered a benign finding in children.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for decreased exercise tolerance. Over the past four months, he has noticed progressively worsening shortness of breath while walking his dog. He also becomes short of breath when lying in bed at night. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 155/53 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a high-pitched, decrescendo murmur that occurs immediately after S2 and is heard best along the left sternal border. There is an S3 gallop. Carotid pulses are strong. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis (MS) can cause dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea. Although MS produces a decrescendo diastolic murmur, it is usually slightly delayed after S2 and would be heard best along the left midclavicular line (at third left intercostal space), not the left sternal border. A prominent S1 and/or an opening snap of the mitral valve after S2 may also be present. Furthermore, since MS restricts left ventricular blood flow, left ventricular preload is decreased, such that carotid pulses would be diminished and an S3 would not be present.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation can cause dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea. However, mitral regurgitation produces a holosystolic murmur that is heard best at the apex (5th intercostal space at the left midclavicular line), not a diastolic murmur that is heard best at the left sternal border.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

C) INCORRECT:

While very rare, tricuspid regurgitation (TR) can cause signs of right-sided heart failure (lower extremity edema, hepatomegaly), but not signs of left-sided heart failure (dyspnea, orthopnea). Furthermore, TR produces a holosystolic murmur heard best at the 4th intercostal space of the left sternal border, not a diastolic murmur.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

D) CORRECT:

An early diastolic decrescendo murmur that is heard best at the left sternal border suggests aortic regurgitation (AR). Regurgitation of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle (LV) causes widened pulse pressure with a decreased diastolic blood pressure. To maintain an adequate cardiac output despite regurgitation, initially, there is a compensatory increase in stroke volume. Over time, the increased LV end-diastolic volume leads to LV enlargement and eccentric myocardial hypertrophy. Patients may be asymptomatic for decades despite progressive LV dilation. In chronic AR, this compensatory response results in left ventricular dysfunction, and patients develop signs and symptoms of left heart failure (exertional and nocturnal dyspnea, S3 gallop). The diagnosis of AR should be confirmed with transthoracic echocardiography.

Maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., handgrip) increase the intensity of the associated murmur as a result of the enlargement of regurgitation volume across the valve.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

E) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse can cause fatigue and dyspnea on exertion but is asymptomatic in most patients. Furthermore, it causes a high-frequency midsystolic click that is heard best in the mitral region. This patient has a diastolic murmur, which is not consistent with mitral valve prolapse.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

F) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis (AS) can cause dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea. However, it commonly causes a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur, not a decrescendo diastolic murmur. Furthermore, AS will more likely cause an S4 from a stiff myocardium due to left ventricular hypertrophy, rather than an S3. Carotid pulses tend to be diminished and delayed, not prominent.
Image Description:

Crescendo-decrescendo ejection murmur with an ejection click

In aortic stenosis, there is usually radiation into the carotids.
questions.hint: This patient's murmur would become louder with handgrip.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of shortness of breath while lying on her back over the past month. During this period, she has also had several episodes of bloody coughing. The patient reports that she had a heart problem when she was a child that was treated with antibiotics. She emigrated to the US from Russia 5 years ago. There is no family history of serious illness. Pulmonary examination shows crackles at both lung bases. Cardiac examination is shown. An ECG shows tachycardia and no P waves. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary regurgitation may be caused by pulmonary hypertension as a result of volume overload in patients with left-sided heart failure. Such patients would present with signs of cardiogenic pulmonary edema, which would explain this patient's orthopnea, hemoptysis, and crackles. However, pulmonary regurgitation causes a diastolic murmur heard best at the second left intercostal space parasternally (sometimes referred to as Graham Steel murmur), which would be more pronounced during inspiration.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Although severe aortic valve stenosis may eventually cause signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles), patients would most likely first present with syncope or angina. Furthermore, aortic stenosis causes a harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the second right intercostal space, which can radiate to the carotids.
Image Description:

Aortic stenosis is a valvular heart disease characterized by the inability of the aortic valve to completely open during systole, impeding blood from flowing from the left ventricle to the aorta during systole. This generates in a harsh mid-systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur that is best heard with the diaphragm of the stethoscope in the right 2nd intercostal space (i.e., the aortic area). The murmur characteristically radiates to the carotid arteries. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle.

C) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse is the most common valvular abnormality in developed countries and is often caused by rheumatic fever. However, it is usually asymptomatic and is best heard at the fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line as a high-frequency mid-to-late systolic murmur with a mid-systolic click.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary valve stenosis is usually congenital and causes a systolic murmur best heard at the second left intercostal space parasternally. It can radiate to the back and also be present as a widely split second heart sound, which is not consistent with this patient's findings.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

E) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation may cause signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles). However, it manifests as a holosystolic murmur (i.e., audible between S1 and S2) best heard at the apex of the fifth left intercostal space, in contrast to this patient's diastolic murmur (audible after S2).
Image Description:

Mitral regurgitation is a valvular heart disease characterized by the failure of the mitral valve to completely close at the end of diastole, causing a retrograde flow of blood from the left ventricle to the left atrium during systole. This results in a pansystolic murmur that is best heard with the diaphragm of the stethoscope at the cardiac apex. The murmur does not radiate to the carotid arteries but may radiate to the axilla. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle.

F) CORRECT:

This patient's diastolic murmur (audible after S2) at the fifth left intercostal space and opening snap indicate mitral valve stenosis, which causes an increase in left atrial pressure (and increased pulmonary wedge pressure) and a backup of blood into the lungs. Volume overload eventually causes symptoms of cardiogenic pulmonary edema, which explains this patient's orthopnea, hemoptysis, and crackles. The absence of P waves confirms atrial fibrillation, a common complication of mitral stenosis. This patient most likely suffered from rheumatic fever, the most common cause of mitral stenosis.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

G) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid valve stenosis is extremely rare and can be caused by rheumatic fever. However, it causes a diastolic murmur best heard at the left fourth intercostal space parasternally and is usually associated with signs of right heart failure (e.g., peripheral edema, jugular venous distention).
Image Description:

Delayed diastolic murmur with a decrescendo, possible presystolic crescendo

H) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation can be caused by rheumatic fever. However, it is best heard as a systolic murmur at the fourth intercostal space parallel to the sternum and is usually associated with signs of right heart failure (e.g., peripheral edema, jugular venous distention).
Image Description:

Tricuspid regurgitation is a valvular heart disease characterized by the failure of the tricuspid valve to completely close at the end of diastole, thus causing a retrograde flow of blood from the right ventricle to the right atrium during systole. This generates a pansystolic murmur that is best heard with the diaphragm of the stethoscope at the left lower sternal border. The murmur does not radiate to the carotid arteries. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle. The heart sounds and murmurs have been amplified for demonstration purposes.

I) INCORRECT:

Although aortic regurgitation may lead to signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles), it causes a diastolic decrescendo murmur heard best parasternally at the second intercostal space, and may sometimes be accompanied by an Austin Flint murmur.
Image Description:

Aortic regurgitation is a valvular heart disease characterized by the failure of the aortic valve to completely close at the end of systole, allowing a retrograde flow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle during diastole. This generates an early diastolic decrescendo murmur that is best heard at the left 2nd intercostal space (i.e., the aortic area) and/or at the right 3rd intercostal space (i.e., Erb point). The murmur does not radiate to the carotid arteries. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle. The heart sounds and murmurs have been amplified for demonstration purposes.
questions.hint: This patient's heart problem is consistent with a history of rheumatic fever. An x-ray of the chest in this patient would likely show left atrial enlargement as a result of this patient's condition.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of progressive shortness of breath and fatigue over the past month. He reports that he cannot climb more than one flight of stairs without experiencing shortness of breath and dizziness. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His medications include enalapril, atorvastatin, and low-dose aspirin. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. He does not drink alcohol. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows weak peripheral pulses. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Severe aortic regurgitation (AR) can manifest with dizziness and exertional dyspnea, as seen here. However, patients with AR typically present with high pulse pressure, a water hammer pulse, and a high-pitched early diastolic murmur heard best at the left 3rd ICS that does not radiate to the carotid arteries.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid stenosis (TS) is extremely rare and typically manifests with abdominal discomfort (due to hepatomegaly) and other features of right-sided heart failure, which are not present here. In addition, the typical murmur of TS is a soft middiastolic murmur heard best in the parasternal region of the left 4th ICS.
Image Description:

Delayed diastolic murmur with a decrescendo, possible presystolic crescendo

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary regurgitation (PR) is usually asymptomatic but can also manifest with exertional dyspnea. However, features of right-sided heart failure would be present, and auscultation in PR would show an early diastolic decrescendo murmur that is best heard parasternally at the left 2nd ICS.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is typically asymptomatic but can also manifest with exertional dyspnea. However, auscultation of an MVP shows a high-frequency, midsystolic click with a late systolic murmur that is heard best at the left midclavicular line of the 5th ICS.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

E) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) is extremely rare and in severe cases manifests with abdominal discomfort (due to hepatomegaly) and other features of right-sided heart failure, which are not present here. In addition, the murmur of TR is holosystolic and heard best in the parasternal region of the left 4th ICS.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

F) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis (MS) leads to pulmonary venous congestion, which, in turn, causes dyspnea, as seen here. However, auscultation in MS shows a middiastolic murmur heard best at the midclavicular left 5th ICS (the apex) and is often preceded by an opening snap.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

G) CORRECT:

This patient's auscultation findings are consistent with aortic stenosis, which causes left ventricular outflow obstruction. The result is dizziness and exacerbation of dyspnea upon exertion, and weak peripheral pulses (pulsus parvus et tardus). Incomplete left ventricular emptying may also cause pulmonary venous congestion, which further exacerbates dyspnea.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

H) INCORRECT:

Chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) leads to pulmonary venous congestion, which, in turn, causes dyspnea, as seen in this patient. However, patients with MR typically present with normal peripheral pulses and a holosystolic high-pitched murmur heard best at the left midclavicular line of the 5th ICS that radiates to the left axilla.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

I) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis is mostly a congenital valve defect that can also manifest with exertional dyspnea. However, cardiac auscultation typically shows an ejection systolic murmur best heard at the left 2nd ICS.
Image Description:

Crescendo-decrescendo murmur with ejection click and widely split second heart sound
questions.hint: Auscultation shows a harsh crescendo-decrescendo, systolic ejection murmur best heard at the 2nd right intercostal space (ICS) that radiates to the carotids. These features are suggestive of the most common valvular heart disease in industrialized countries.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue and shortness of breath for 2 months. The dyspnea occurs on moderate exertion and during the night; he sometimes wakes up coughing and “gasping for air.” He has also had several episodes of heart pounding. Two weeks ago, he had a runny nose and a productive cough. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and peripheral arterial disease. He has never smoked. He drinks one to two beers occasionally. He has a history of intravenous illicit drug use but has not used in over 25 years. Current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, and metformin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows bilateral basilar rales. Cardiac auscultation is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's auscultatory findings indicate chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) as the cause of his LHF. MR typically manifests with a high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur that radiates into the axilla and is heard best at the apex. Mitral murmurs are heard best during expiration and while the patient lies on the left side. Causes of primary MR include degenerative mitral valve disease (mitral valve prolapse, mitral annular calcification, ruptured chordae tendineae), infective endocarditis, and rheumatic fever.
Image Description:

Mitral regurgitation is a valvular heart disease characterized by the failure of the mitral valve to completely close at the end of diastole, causing a retrograde flow of blood from the left ventricle to the left atrium during systole. This results in a pansystolic murmur that is best heard with the diaphragm of the stethoscope at the cardiac apex. The murmur does not radiate to the carotid arteries but may radiate to the axilla. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with some features of pericarditis including fatigue, palpitations, and exertional dyspnea, which are often preceded by flu-like symptoms. But he lacks other typical findings, such as fever, and sharp, pleuritic chest pain, and does not have a high-pitched scratching sound (pericardial friction rub) on auscultation.

C) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid valve regurgitation (TR) manifests with a holosystolic murmur and can occur as a result of infective endocarditis in patients with a history of intravenous drug use. However, the murmur of TR is heard best at the lower parasternal region, does not radiate to the axilla, and does not have a blowing quality. Like all right-sided heart murmurs, the murmur of TR is intensified during deep inspiration. In contrast, this patient's murmur is intensified on expiration. Moreover, TR is extremely rare and would typically manifest with symptoms of right-sided heart failure, such as peripheral pitting edema and jugular venous distention.
Image Description:

Tricuspid regurgitation is a valvular heart disease characterized by the failure of the tricuspid valve to completely close at the end of diastole, thus causing a retrograde flow of blood from the right ventricle to the right atrium during systole. This generates a pansystolic murmur that is best heard with the diaphragm of the stethoscope at the left lower sternal border. The murmur does not radiate to the carotid arteries. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle. The heart sounds and murmurs have been amplified for demonstration purposes.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary valve stenosis (PS) primarily manifests during early childhood with a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard best at the 2nd left ICS. In adults, common causes include carcinoid syndrome and chronic rheumatic fever. Like all right-sided heart murmurs, the murmur of PS is intensified during deep inspiration rather than during expiration as in this patient. Moreover, PS is rare and would typically present with symptoms of right-sided heart failure, such as peripheral pitting edema and jugular venous distention.
Image Description:

Crescendo-decrescendo murmur with ejection click and widely split second heart sound

E) INCORRECT:

Although LHF in this patient could be explained by aortic valve regurgitation, this condition would manifest with a high-frequency, blowing decrescendo murmur during early diastole that is heard best in the left 3rd and 4th ICSs and along the left sternal border.
Image Description:

Aortic regurgitation is a valvular heart disease characterized by the failure of the aortic valve to completely close at the end of systole, allowing a retrograde flow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle during diastole. This generates an early diastolic decrescendo murmur that is best heard at the left 2nd intercostal space (i.e., the aortic area) and/or at the right 3rd intercostal space (i.e., Erb point). The murmur does not radiate to the carotid arteries. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle. The heart sounds and murmurs have been amplified for demonstration purposes.

F) INCORRECT:

Although LHF in this patient could be explained by mitral valve stenosis (MS) and mitral murmurs are heard best at the apex, MS would manifest with a low-frequency, mid-diastolic (not systolic) rumble, and loud S1.
Image Description:

Mitral stenosis is a valvular heart disease characterized by the inability of the mitral valve to completely open during diastole, impeding blood from flowing from the left atrium to the left ventricle during diastole. This generates a low-frequency mid-diastolic murmur that is best heard with the bell of the stethoscope at the cardiac apex and is often accompanied by a loud S1. The murmur does not radiate to the carotid arteries. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle.

G) INCORRECT:

Although LHF in this patient could be explained by aortic stenosis, this condition would manifest with a harsh mid-systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur that may radiate bilaterally to the carotids and is heard best in the 2nd ICS at the right upper sternal border.
Image Description:

Aortic stenosis is a valvular heart disease characterized by the inability of the aortic valve to completely open during systole, impeding blood from flowing from the left ventricle to the aorta during systole. This generates in a harsh mid-systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur that is best heard with the diaphragm of the stethoscope in the right 2nd intercostal space (i.e., the aortic area). The murmur characteristically radiates to the carotid arteries. Palpate the carotid pulse while auscultating the heart to relate the auscultatory findings to the cardiac cycle.
questions.hint: This patient presents with progressive fatigue, palpitations, and features of pulmonary congestion (exertional and nocturnal dyspnea, dry cough, bibasilar rales on auscultation). In combination with a heart murmur, these findings are highly suggestive of left-sided heart failure (LHF) caused by valvular heart disease. The auscultation findings reveal a systolic murmur heard best at the midclavicular 5th left intercostal space (ICS), the area of the cardiac apex.

questions.text:
An otherwise healthy 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of palpitations. He says that he can feel his heartbeat in his chest all the time. For the past 3 weeks, he has had shortness of breath on exertion. He has not had chest pain, orthopnea, or nocturnal dyspnea. He emigrated from Nepal at the age of 25 years. He does not take any medications. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 145/56 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation (MR) can manifest with dyspnea (due to pulmonary venous congestion) and palpitations in the setting of atrial fibrillation. Although this patient presents with both dyspnea and palpitations, he lacks the characteristic holosystolic murmur of MR (best heard at the cardiac apex; left 5th intercostal space). In contrast, this patient has a diastolic murmur. Furthermore, his lungs are clear to auscultation, which makes pulmonary venous congestion unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis (PS) is usually a congenital heart defect. Acquired PS is rare but can occur in patients with carcinoid syndrome or rheumatic heart disease. It typically manifests with features of right-sided heart failure rather than the dyspnea and palpitations seen in this patient. The typical murmur of PS is an ejection systolic murmur, which is heard best parasternally at the left 2nd intercostal space, often with a widely split S2. This patient's diastolic murmur rules out PS as a possible diagnosis.
Image Description:

Crescendo-decrescendo murmur with ejection click and widely split second heart sound

C) CORRECT:

The patient has a diastolic murmur, which shortens the list of differentials here to mitral stenosis (MS), aortic regurgitation (AR), tricuspid stenosis (TS), and pulmonary regurgitation (PR). Let's have a look at the location of the murmur: it is best heard at the left sternal border near Erb point (cardiology). This location makes MS unlikely (usually best heard at the apex) but is consistent with a murmur caused by AR due to valvular disease. Now, here comes the tricky part. In this patient, TS and PR cannot be excluded by cardiac auscultation because the left sternal border is also the location at which murmurs due to TS and PR are best heard. However, subtle details make AR more likely. PR can occur in patients with pulmonary hypertension due to lung disease (cor pulmonale) or chronic congestive heart failure, but this patient has no clinical features to suggest either of these etiologies. Isolated TS or PR are extremely rare (usually caused by endocarditis in intravenous drug users, or by congenital heart defects), and manifest with features of right heart failure, which are not seen here. This patient's history of emigration from Nepal increases the likelihood that the underlying etiology of valvular heart disease is rheumatic heart disease, which most commonly affects the mitral and aortic valves. In patients with AR, a widened pulse pressure (due to increased end-diastolic volume and a subsequent increase in stroke volume) is a common finding.

Other common causes of AR include a congenital bicuspid aortic valve (most common cause of AR in high-income countries) and aortic root dilation due to connective tissue disorders (e.g., Marfan syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome). In contrast to AR due to valvular disease, the murmur of AR secondary to aortic root diseases is heard best over the right upper sternal border.

Timing the murmur against the carotid pulse is an important skill to master; if you are finding it difficult to time the murmur, try listening to the murmur again between 10 and 20 seconds using a slow playback speed and gradually increase the playback speed until you are proficient in timing the murmur.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

D) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) is a rare valvular abnormality that is usually asymptomatic. Right-sided valvular heart diseases are more common in individuals with a history of IV drug use, which this patient does not have. Chronic and/or severe TR manifests with features of right-sided heart failure but usually not with dyspnea or palpitations. Furthermore, TR causes a holosystolic murmur heard best at the 4th intercostal space of the left sternal border rather than a diastolic murmur.

E) INCORRECT:

The characteristic triad of symptomatic aortic stenosis (AS) is exertional dyspnea, stable angina, and exertional dizziness/syncope caused by left ventricular outflow obstruction. AS causes weak peripheral pulses (pulsus parvus et tardus) and low/narrow pulse pressure, in contrast to this patient's findings. Moreover, the characteristic murmur of AS is a harsh crescendo-decrescendo late systolic ejection murmur heard best over the right 2nd intercostal space that radiates to the carotids.

F) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis (MS) can manifest with dyspnea (due to pulmonary venous congestion) and palpitations if atrial fibrillation develops. Although the murmur that is characteristic of MS also occurs during diastole, it is most often a mid-diastolic decrescendo murmur preceded by an opening snap and is heard best at the cardiac apex. This patient has an early diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border that is associated with a widened pulse pressure, and his lungs are clear to auscultation, making another diagnosis more likely.

G) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is typically asymptomatic but can present with palpitations and exertional dyspnea. Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is one of the most common valvular abnormalities in the US, especially in young women. However, a widened pulse pressure is not common in MVP. Typical cardiac auscultatory findings of MVP would include a high-frequency, midsystolic click with a late systolic murmur that is heard best at the cardiac apex (left midclavicular line of the 5th intercostal space).
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.
questions.hint: The peak of the carotid pulse upstroke occurs immediately after S1. In this patient, there is a blowing, decrescendo murmur that is heard shortly after the carotid pulse upstroke, which is consistent with a diastolic timing. With early diastolic murmurs, the S2 cannot be distinguished from the murmur on auscultation, as is the case here.

questions.text: A 25-year old man comes to the physician because of fatigue over the past 6 months. He has been to the emergency room several times over the past 3 years for recurrent shoulder and patella dislocations. Physical examination shows abnormal joint hypermobility and skin hyperextensibility. A high-frequency mid-systolic click is heard on auscultation. Which of the following is most likely to result in an earlier onset of this patient’s auscultation finding?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The characteristic click heard on auscultation in patients with mitral valve prolapse (MVP) results from the bulging of the valve leaflets into the atrium, which begins when the contracting left ventricle reaches a critical volume during systole. An increased left ventricular end-diastolic volume, e.g., due to increased afterload and subsequent increased left ventricular end-systolic volume during hand grip (hand clenching) delays the point when that volume is reached and results in a later onset of the auscultatory findings.

B) CORRECT:

The characteristic auscultatory finding of MVP is a high-frequency mid-systolic click, which is caused by sudden tensing of the chordae tendineae as the valve leaflets prolapse. The click may be followed by a mid-to-late systolic murmur indicating mitral regurgitation. Since the prolapse occurs when the contracting ventricle reaches a critical volume, the timing of the click varies according to the left ventricular end-diastolic volume (EDV). Decreased EDV, e.g., due to decreased venous return to the heart during abrupt standing (i.e., decreased preload) causes the leaflets to prolapse sooner, resulting in an earlier onset (i.e., closer to S1) and increased intensity of auscultatory findings. Conversely, maneuvers that increase the volume (e.g., squatting) result in a later onset and decreased intensity.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

The characteristic click heard on auscultation in patients with mitral valve prolapse (MVP) results from the bulging of the valve leaflets into the atrium, which begins when the contracting left ventricle reaches a critical volume during systole. An increased left ventricular end-diastolic volume, e.g., due to increased venous return to the heart during rapid squatting (i.e., increased preload) delays the point when that volume is reached and results in a later onset of the auscultatory findings.

D) INCORRECT:

The characteristic click heard on auscultation in patients with mitral valve prolapse (MVP) results from the bulging of the valve leaflets into the atrium, which begins when the contracting left ventricle reaches a critical volume during systole. An increased left ventricular end-diastolic volume, e.g., due to increased venous return to the heart during the release phase of the Valsalva maneuver (i.e., increased preload) delays the point when that volume is reached and results in a later onset of the auscultatory findings.

E) INCORRECT:

Leaning forward brings the heart closer to the chest, but it has no significant impact on preload or afterload, so it does not affect the timing of the murmur of mitral valve prolapse. However, a pericardial friction rub and the murmur of aortic regurgitation are best heard with the patient leaning forward.
questions.hint: This patient most likely has Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which can manifest with joint hypermobility (predisposing to joint dislocations) and hyperextensible skin. Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is associated with mitral valve prolapse (MVP), a structural defect of the mitral valves due to myxomatous degeneration that leads to the bulging of the leaflets into the left atrium during systole.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of shortness of breath with exertion. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include aspirin, losartan, simvastatin, and insulin. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 74/min, and blood pressure is 150/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Cardiac examination is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
Video

choices.text: Earlier onset of abnormal cardiac sound with standing
Elevated serum brain natriuretic peptide levels
Left-to-right shunt through the atrial septum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Earlier onset of abnormal cardiac sound with standing is an auscultatory finding in patients with mitral valve prolapse (MVP). It is caused by a decrease in preload, which is due to pooling of blood in the venous system. This, in turn, decreases both right and left ventricular volume, resulting in decreased tension and prolapse of the valve. MVP manifests with a high-frequency, midsystolic click that is best heard at the mitral region, which is not consistent with this patient's auscultation findings.

B) INCORRECT:

Calcification of the aortic valve is the most common cause of aortic stenosis (AS). The resulting left ventricular outflow tract obstruction causes left ventricular hypertrophy, which manifests with an S4 gallop, not an S3 gallop. Moreover, the murmur that is characteristic of aortic stenosis is a systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard loudest at the upper right sternal border, which this patient does not have.

C) CORRECT:

Elevated levels of brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) and the presence of an S3 gallop both indicate increased ventricular filling pressures, which is seen in heart failure (HF). BNP, which is released in response to stretching of the cardiac ventricle, is a sensitive parameter to evaluate patients with symptoms of HF. High levels of BNP (> 400 pg/mL) in patients with classic symptoms of HF have a high positive predictive value and are associated with a worse prognosis, while low values (< 100 pg/mL) in patients with dyspnea have a high negative predictive value for HF.

D) INCORRECT:

Digital clubbing is primarily seen in patients with pulmonary diseases that result in chronic hypoxemia, such as cystic fibrosis, bronchiectasis, interstitial lung disease, and non-small cell lung cancer. It may also be seen in cyanotic heart disease and infectious endocarditis, which are unlikely diagnoses in a 66-year-old afebrile patient. As clubbing is a nonspecific physical finding, it is unlikely to help pinpoint the diagnosis. While shortness of breath can be of pulmonary origin, this patient's S3 gallop on examination is more concerning for a cardiac cause.

E) INCORRECT:

A left-to-right shunt through the atrial septum is the pathophysiologic mechanism of an atrial septal defect (ASD). Auscultatory findings in ASD include a systolic ejection murmur over the left upper sternal border (due to increased blood flow across the pulmonary valve), a diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border (due to increased blood flow across the tricuspid valve), and a fixed, widely split S2, none of which are seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Bounding pulses of peripheral arteries (water hammer pulse) occur in patients with aortic regurgitation (AR) and are caused by the hemodynamic changes caused by the regurgitant aortic valve. While an S3 gallop can occur in AR, this patient lacks the characteristic decrescendo, early diastolic murmur of AR, which is best heard in the left third and fourth intercostal spaces along the left sternal border.

G) INCORRECT:

Rupture of a papillary muscle would result in acute mitral regurgitation (MR), a complication associated with myocardial infarction (MI). While this patient has several risk factors for MI, including hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus, he has no symptoms of chest pain or signs to suggest ongoing acute coronary syndrome. Additionally, this patient lacks the characteristic holosystolic, blowing murmur of MR, which is best heard in the apex.
questions.hint: This patient's cardiac examination reveals a third heart sound (S3 gallop).

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician for a preemployment examination. She feels well. She has a history of polycystic ovarian syndrome. She exercises daily and plays soccer recreationally on the weekends. Family history is remarkable for hypertension in her mother. Her current medications include an oral contraceptive pill and a daily multivitamin. She does not smoke and drinks 2 glasses of wine on the weekends. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiac examination shows a grade 1/6 decrescendo diastolic murmur heard best at the apex. Her lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Peripheral pulses are normal and there is no lower extremity edema. An electrocardiogram shows sinus rhythm with a normal axis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the chest with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An exercise stress test is used to assess patients with suspected coronary artery disease as well as those with valvular heart disease and evidence of cardiac ischemia. In an asymptomatic patient with no history of exertional chest pain or dyspnea, a stress test would not be helpful.

B) INCORRECT:

Certain asymptomatic systolic murmurs can be safely monitored, with no further testing required. However, diastolic murmurs are considered abnormal and should be evaluated further.

C) CORRECT:

A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) is the most appropriate next step in managing an asymptomatic patient with a diastolic murmur. Unlike systolic murmurs, which are often physiologic, all diastolic murmurs are considered abnormal. The best initial test to assess the presence, location, and severity of valvular defects is a TTE. TTE is also indicated in certain systolic murmurs (holosystolic and late systolic murmurs, murmurs with added sounds such as clicks, radiating murmurs), continuous murmurs, and any murmur that is symptomatic.

D) INCORRECT:

Chest x-rays are of limited use in assessing valvular heart disease, as they cannot visualize the heart valves in any anatomical or functional detail.

E) INCORRECT:

Contrast-enhanced CT scans of the chest may be used to evaluate patients with suspected aortic valve disease, especially in the preoperative setting, as it can help to identify the extent of aortic calcification and the anatomy of the aortic root. However, chest CT scans are static rather than dynamic studies and are limited in their ability to assess the anatomy and severity of valvular defects. In addition, a CT scan involves radiation exposure and should be avoided when possible, especially in women of child-bearing age.

F) INCORRECT:

Indications for transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) include diagnosis of suspected valvular vegetations (e.g., due to bacterial endocarditis), cardiac tumors, and intramural thrombi. TEE is an invasive study that would not be indicated in an otherwise asymptomatic patient with a diastolic murmur.
questions.hint: This asymptomatic patient has a diastolic murmur.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 3-month history of episodic chest pain and shortness of breath on exertion. He is at the 99th percentile for height and 40th percentile for weight. Examination shows a high-arched palate, long and slender upper extremities, and elbows and knees that can be hyperextended. Cardiac examination shows a grade 2/6 late systolic, crescendo murmur with a midsystolic click. The murmur is most likely to be heard best over which of the following labeled areas?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Area A corresponds to the carotid area. Aortic stenosis causes a midsystolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur that can radiate to this area. Severe carotid artery stenosis can also cause a carotid bruit heard over this area. The murmur most commonly associated with Marfan syndrome is best heard over a different area.

B) INCORRECT:

Area B corresponds to the aortic area, which is located in the right 2nd intercostal space in the parasternal line. Aortic stenosis causes a midsystolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard over this area. Marfan syndrome, which this patient has, commonly causes aortic root dilation and, consequently, aortic regurgitation. In aortic regurgitation due to aortic root disease, an early diastolic murmur is heard over the aortic area during diastole. The systolic murmur in this patient, however, is best heard over a different area.

C) INCORRECT:

Area C corresponds to the pulmonic area, located in the left 2nd parasternal intercostal space. Pulmonary stenosis causes a systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard over this area. Pulmonary stenosis is not associated with Marfan syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Area D corresponds to the left sternal border. Aortic regurgitation (AR) due to valvular disease can cause a murmur that is best heard over this area. AR in Marfan disease, although a common manifestation, is due to aortic root dilation, which causes a murmur best heard at the right rather than the left sternal border. Moreover, the murmur in AR is early diastolic. The systolic murmur in this patient is best heard over a different area.

E) INCORRECT:

Area E corresponds to the tricuspid area located in the left 4th parasternal intercostal space. Ventricular septal defects (the most common congenital cardiac defect) can cause a holosystolic, harsh-sounding murmur best heard over this area. Tricuspid stenosis causes a diastolic, low-pitched, decrescendo murmur and tricuspid regurgitation causes a holosystolic murmur, both of which can also be heard over this area. The murmur most commonly associated with Marfan syndrome is best heard over a different area.

F) CORRECT:

Patients with Marfan syndrome can have mitral valve prolapse (MVP), which causes a late systolic, crescendo murmur with a midsystolic click. This murmur is best heard at the heart apex (mitral area, located at the left 5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line) when the patient is in the left lateral recumbent position. Other cardiovascular abnormalities associated with Marfan syndrome include aortic disease (e.g., aortic root dilation, aortic regurgitation, aortic aneurysm, aortic dissection) and berry aneurysms.

Marfan syndrome can lead to other musculoskeletal abnormalities, including arachnodactyly and spinal abnormalities (scoliosis and sternal kyphosis). Ocular manifestations can include ectopia lentis (superiorly and temporally), myopia, retinal detachment, and glaucoma.
Image Description:

I–IV: anatomical locations of heart valves

1. Aortic area: 2nd right parasternal intercostal space (ICS)
- Ideal site for auscultation of aortic valve murmurs (1a). The murmur of aortic stenosis also radiates to the carotid arteries (1b).

2. Pulmonary area: 2nd left parasternal ICS
- Ideal site for auscultation of pulmonary valve murmurs

3. Tricuspid area: 4th left parasternal ICS
- Ideal site for auscultation of tricuspid valve murmurs

4. Mitral area: 5th left ICS in the midclavicular line (over the cardiac apex)
- Ideal site for auscultation of mitral valve murmurs (4a). The murmur of mitral regurgitation also radiates to the left axilla (4b).

G) INCORRECT:

Area G corresponds to the left midaxillary line. Mitral regurgitation causes a holosystolic murmur that can radiate to this area, particularly if the patient is in the left lateral recumbent position. The murmur most commonly found in patients with Marfan syndrome is best heard over a different area.
questions.hint: This boy's tall stature, long and slender arms, joint hypermobility (as evidenced by his hyperextensible elbows and knees), and high-arched palate are consistent with Marfan syndrome, an inherited connective tissue disorder associated with ocular, musculoskeletal, and cardiovascular abnormalities.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of shortness of breath. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), and pulse is 105/min. When the blood pressure cuff is inflated to 140 mm Hg, the patient's pulse is audible and regular. However, upon inspiration, the pulse disappears and does not reappear until expiration. The pulse becomes audible throughout the entire respiratory cycle when the blood pressure cuff is deflated to 125 mm Hg. Which of the following underlying conditions is most likely responsible for this patient's physical examination findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) can manifest as dyspnea due to pulmonary venous congestion. Physical examination findings associated with MR include holosystolic high-pitched murmur heard best at the apex and crackles on lung auscultation. Pulsus paradoxus is not associated with mitral regurgitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary fibrosis is characterized by progressive scarring of the lung parenchyma, resulting in reduced lung compliance and a restrictive pulmonary physiology. Patients often present with progressive dyspnea, a dry cough, and fine inspiratory crackles on auscultation. Restrictive lung disease does not cause the marked decrease in intrathoracic pressure that leads to pulsus paradoxus.

C) INCORRECT:

Physical examination findings associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HOCM) include the presence of an S4, harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard at the apex, and a brisk carotid upstroke. Rarely, it is also associated with reverse pulsus paradoxus, which refers to an inspiratory increase rather than a decrease in systolic and diastolic pressures. Pulsus paradoxus, as seen in this patient, is not associated with HOCM.

D) INCORRECT:

Heart failure does not commonly cause pulsus paradoxus but can cause pulsus alternans (alternating strong and weak pulses) on physical examination due to alterations in cardiac output. Additional manifestations of heart failure include dyspnea, peripheral edema, crackles on lung auscultation, a 3rd heart sound, and distended jugular veins.

E) CORRECT:

Pulsus paradoxus is most commonly caused by severe obstructive lung disease (e.g., COPD, asthma) or constrictive cardiac disease (e.g., cardiac tamponade, constrictive pericarditis, tension pneumothorax). Increased airway resistance in obstructive lung disease leads to a significant decrease in intrathoracic pressure during inhalation, which increases venous return to the right atrium and ventricle. The enlarged right ventricle then exerts pressure on the left ventricle, resulting in a decrease in stroke volume and a drop in inspiratory blood pressure.

In constrictive cardiac disease, the pericardial space is unable to compensate for inspiratory venous return, leading to pulsus paradoxus. In a pathologically constricted heart, the increase in right ventricular volume causes bowing of the right ventricle into the left ventricle, resulting in decreased left ventricular filling and cardiac output, and a subsequent drop in systolic blood pressure.
questions.hint: Arterial systolic pressure normally falls during inspiration, although the magnitude of decrease usually does not exceed 10 mm Hg. A pathological decrease in arterial systolic pressure > 10 mm Hg during inspiration (in this case, the difference is 15 mm Hg) is characteristic of pulsus paradoxus.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of intermittent dyspnea and dizziness. She has a history of mitral valve stenosis. Her pulse is 125/min and irregularly irregular, and blood pressure is 102/66 mm Hg. A transthoracic echocardiogram shows doming of the anterior mitral valve leaflet during systole. Which of the following elements is most likely to be absent from this patient's jugular venous pressure waveform?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Area 1 corresponds to the a wave of the JVP waveform and corresponds with atrial contraction. Right atrial contraction leads to increased RA pressure and subsequent retrograde blood flow back to the jugular vein, therefore manifesting with a peak in the JVP tracing. The a wave is absent in atrial fibrillation, the most likely etiology of this patient's abnormal rhythm, due to a lack of unified contraction of the right atrium during fibrillation.

A prominent a wave may be seen in patients with right ventricular hypertrophy or pulmonic stenosis (due to increased pressure gradient across the right side of the heart).

B) INCORRECT:

Area 2 corresponds to the c wave of the JVP waveform. It represents right ventricular contraction against a closed tricuspid valve, which causes the valve to bulge into the right atrium. This creates a second peak in the JVP. Because atrial fibrillation does not affect right ventricular contraction or tricuspid valve function, this patient should have a normal c wave.

C) INCORRECT:

Area 3 corresponds to the x descent of the JVP waveform. It represents atrial relaxation with continued ventricular contraction in which there is inferior displacement of the closed tricuspid valve, resulting in a drop in JVP. The x descent may be absent in tricuspid regurgitation in which retrograde blood flow during ventricular systole prohibits a drop in right atrial pressure. This patient has atrial fibrillation, but no known tricuspid disease. Although atrial fibrillation may reduce the degree of x descent secondary to impaired atrial relaxation, it should not be absent.

D) INCORRECT:

Area 4 corresponds to the v wave of the JVP waveform, which represents the increase in right atrial pressure during passive atrial filling against a closed tricuspid valve. A reduced v wave may be seen in cases of decreased preload (e.g., hypovolemia, venous vasodilation), while a prominent v wave can be seen in tricuspid regurgitation and right heart failure. This patient's v wave should not be significantly changed.

E) INCORRECT:

Area 5 corresponds to the y descent of the JVP waveform. It represents tricuspid valve opening, with rapid blood flow from the right atrium into the right ventricle, with a resulting decrease in right atrial pressure. A reduced y descent can be seen in cases of tricuspid stenosis and cardiac tamponade. This patient's y descent should not be significantly changed.
questions.hint: This patient's intermittent symptoms and tachycardia with an irregularly irregular heartbeat are classic features of symptomatic atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. Mitral stenosis is a risk factor for atrial fibrillation.

questions.text:
An 81-year-old man comes to the physician because of increased exertional dyspnea and dizziness over the past 8 weeks. He has hypertension for which he takes lisinopril. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. Physical examination shows weak peripheral pulses. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis is mostly a congenital valve defect that can also manifest with exertional dyspnea. In adults, common causes include carcinoid syndrome and chronic rheumatic fever. But auscultation yields an ejection systolic murmur best heard in the left 2nd ICS.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) leads to pulmonary venous congestion, which, in turn, causes dyspnea, as seen in this patient. However, patients with MR would have normal peripheral pulses and a holosystolic high-pitched murmur heard best at the left midclavicular line of the 5th ICS that radiates to the left axilla.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

C) CORRECT:

This patient's auscultation findings are consistent with aortic stenosis (AS), which causes left ventricular outflow obstruction. The result is dizziness and exacerbation of dyspnea upon exertion, and weak, delayed peripheral pulses (pulsus parvus et tardus). Incomplete left ventricular emptying may also cause pulmonary venous congestion, which further exacerbates dyspnea.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is typically asymptomatic but can also present with exertional dyspnea. However, auscultation of an MVP shows a high-frequency, midsystolic click with a late systolic murmur that is heard best at the left midclavicular line of the 5th ICS.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

E) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis (MS) leads to pulmonary venous congestion, which, in turn, causes dyspnea, as seen in this patient. However, auscultation in MS yields a mid-diastolic murmur heard best at the midclavicular 5th left ICS (the apex), and is often preceded by an opening snap.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

F) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary regurgitation (PR) is usually asymptomatic but can also manifest as exertional dyspnea. However, features of right-sided heart failure would be present, and auscultation in PR would show an early diastolic decrescendo murmur that is best heard parasternally in the left 2nd ICS.

G) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid stenosis (TS) is extremely rare and typically presents with abdominal discomfort (due to hepatomegaly) and other features of right-sided heart failure, which are not present here. In addition, the typical murmur of TS is a soft mid-diastolic murmur heard best in the parasternal region of the left 4th ICS.

H) INCORRECT:

Patients with severe aortic regurgitation can present with dizziness and exertional dyspnea, like this patient. However, examination in AR would show a high pulse pressure, a water hammer pulse, and a high-pitched early diastolic murmur heard best at the 2nd right ICS that does not radiate to the carotid arteries.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

I) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) is extremely rare and in severe cases presents with abdominal discomfort (due to hepatomegaly) and other features of right-sided heart failure, which are not present here. In addition, the murmur of TR is holosystolic and heard best in the parasternal region of the left 4th ICS.
questions.hint: Auscultation shows a harsh crescendo-decrescendo, systolic ejection murmur best heard at the 2nd right intercostal space (ICS) that radiates to the carotids. These features are suggestive of the most common valvular heart disease in industrialized countries.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man who recently immigrated to the United States from Haiti comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and fatigue. For the past few days, he has also had difficulty lying flat due to trouble breathing. Over the past year, he has had intermittent fever, night sweats, and cough but he has not been seen by a physician for evaluation of these symptoms. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F). An x-ray of the chest is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Elimination of S2 heart sound splitting with inspiration
Head bobbing in synchrony with heart beat
Painless erythematous lesions on palms or soles
Prominent "a" wave on jugular venous pressure tracing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Splitting of the second heart sound (S2) is a physiological finding heard during inspiration. It is caused by the early closure of the aortic valve (A2) in relation to the pulmonary valve (P2) when intrathoracic pressure is decreased. In conditions such as aortic stenosis (AS), ventricular septal defect with Eisenmenger syndrome, and left bundle branch block, elimination of S2 splitting can occur because A2 is delayed and superimposed on P2. Although severe, long-standing aortic stenosis can result in fatigue, dyspnea, orthopnea, and cough (due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema), chronic AS is not associated with fever or night sweats but with symptoms such as syncope, palpitations, and angina. Moreover, an x-ray would not show pericardial calcifications but an enlarged cardiac silhouette.

B) INCORRECT:

Rhythmic nodding or bobbing of the head in synchronicity with the heartbeat is referred to as de Musset sign, a typical feature of chronic aortic regurgitation (AR). AR may present with progressively worsening fatigue, dyspnea, orthopnea, and cough (due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema). However, chronic AR is not associated with fever or night sweats, and an x-ray would not show pericardial calcifications, but rather a prominent aortic root and an enlarged cardiac silhouette.

C) INCORRECT:

Painless erythematous lesions on the palms or soles (Janeway lesions) are highly suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE), which can manifest with dyspnea, fatigue, cough, fever, and night sweats. However, the symptoms of IE have an acute or subacute onset (days to weeks), whereas this patient had fever, night sweats, and a cough for a year before developing dyspnea and fatigue. Moreover, an x-ray would not show pericardial calcifications, and IE is almost always associated with the development of a new heart murmur.

D) INCORRECT:

On a jugular venous pressure tracing, the “a” wave is caused by atrial contraction in late diastole. A prominent “a” wave is a sign of increased atrial contraction pressure due to restricted filling of the right ventricle (e.g., tricuspid valve stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, cardiac tamponade). In constrictive pericarditis, right ventricular filling is only impaired when the elastic limit of the pericardium is reached. As a result, all right ventricular filling rapidly occurs in early diastole, producing a prominent and deep x descent and y descent on venous pressure tracing rather than a prominent “a” wave.
Image Description:

A normal jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform is composed of:
- a wave: atrial contraction
- c wave: tricuspid valve closure
- x descent: atrial relaxation
- v wave: venous refilling of the atria
- y descent: passive filling of right ventricle when the tricuspid valve opens

Common abnormalities of the JVP waveform include:
- Constrictive pericarditis: elevated JVP (due to increased external atrial pressure) with a prominent x (exaggerated atrial relaxation) and y (early rapid ventricular filling) descent
- Cardiac tamponade: elevated JVP (due to increased external atrial pressure), a prominent x descent (exaggerated atrial relaxation), and a blunt or absent y descent (minimal ventricular filling)
- Tricuspid regurgitation: prominent v wave as the blood from the right ventricle regurgitates into the right atrium during ventricular systole (atrial diastole), increasing interatrial pressure and volume
- Tricuspid stenosis: giant a wave due to high right atrial systolic pressure
- Atrial septal defect: v wave ≥ a wave due to the left-to-right shunting of blood
- Third-degree atrioventricular (AV) block: cannon a waves due to the loss of AV synchronization and contraction of the atria against a closed tricuspid valve
- Atrial fibrillation: absent a waves due to ineffective contraction of the atria

E) CORRECT:

Normally, the decrease in intrathoracic pressure during inspiration expands the compliant right ventricle, resulting in a decrease in jugular venous pressure.
