In constrictive pericarditis, compliance of the right ventricle is decreased and the right ventricle fails to expand during inspiration. This, alongside a possible increase in baseline jugular venous pressure in constrictive pericarditis due to restricted right ventricular filling during late diastole, leads to an increase in jugular venous pressure during inspiration, and therefore, jugular venous distention on inspiration. This phenomenon, which is called Kussmaul sign, can also be seen in patients with restrictive cardiomyopathy and right atrial or ventricular tumors. Management options for constrictive pericarditis include NSAIDs, colchicine, glucocorticoids, pericardiectomy, and treatment of the underlying condition (e.g., antitubercular or immunomodulatory therapy).

In cardiac tamponade without underlying pericarditis (e.g., traumatic hemopericardium), the jugular venous pressure is increased as a result of impaired right ventricular filling. However, the right ventricle is still compliant and a decrease in intrathoracic pressure can be transmitted to the right ventricle across the fluid-filled pericardial sac. Kussmaul sign would not be expected in traumatic cardiac tamponade.

F) INCORRECT:

A crescendo-decrescendo (diamond-shaped) systolic ejection murmur best heard in the second right intercostal space is a common finding in aortic stenosis (AS). While severe, long-standing AS can result in chest pain, fatigue, dyspnea, orthopnea, and cough (due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema), fever and night sweats are not commonly seen. Finally, symptoms such as syncope, angina, and palpitations are expected in chronic AS, and x-ray would show an enlarged cardiac silhouette rather than the pericardial calcifications seen here.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.
questions.hint: New-onset dyspnea, orthopnea, and fatigue alongside pericardial thickening and calcifications on x-ray indicate constrictive pericarditis. In this patient with an immigration history from an endemic region and a prolonged history of night sweats, fever, and cough, the most likely etiology of constrictive pericarditis is tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man who recently immigrated to the United States from Indonesia comes to the physician because of worsening shortness of breath and swollen extremities for the past 3 months. He has had a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss and intermittent fevers over the last 6 months. Examination shows pitting pedal edema and abdominal distension. Abdominal pressure over the right upper quadrant produces persistent distention of the jugular veins. An x-ray of the chest shows cavernous infiltrates in the left and right-upper lobes and a calcified cardiac silhouette. Cardiovascular examination is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Absent jugular venous pulse y descent

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The y descent of the jugular venous pulse waveform corresponds to the emptying of the right atrium following the opening of the tricuspid valve. Absent y descent would indicate resistance to all phases of diastolic filling, which is seen in cardiac tamponade. In constrictive pericarditis, the early phase of diastolic filling is unchanged, but the mid-late phase is met with resistance. This, coupled with the high jugular venous distention of chronic venous congestion, produces a prominent y descent that is accentuated in the early phase as filling drops rapidly from a higher peak pressure.
Image Description:

A normal jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform is composed of:
- a wave: atrial contraction
- c wave: tricuspid valve closure
- x descent: atrial relaxation
- v wave: venous refilling of the atria
- y descent: passive filling of right ventricle when the tricuspid valve opens

Common abnormalities of the JVP waveform include:
- Constrictive pericarditis: elevated JVP (due to increased external atrial pressure) with a prominent x (exaggerated atrial relaxation) and y (early rapid ventricular filling) descent
- Cardiac tamponade: elevated JVP (due to increased external atrial pressure), a prominent x descent (exaggerated atrial relaxation), and a blunt or absent y descent (minimal ventricular filling)
- Tricuspid regurgitation: prominent v wave as the blood from the right ventricle regurgitates into the right atrium during ventricular systole (atrial diastole), increasing interatrial pressure and volume
- Tricuspid stenosis: giant a wave due to high right atrial systolic pressure
- Atrial septal defect: v wave ≥ a wave due to the left-to-right shunting of blood
- Third-degree atrioventricular (AV) block: cannon a waves due to the loss of AV synchronization and contraction of the atria against a closed tricuspid valve
- Atrial fibrillation: absent a waves due to ineffective contraction of the atria

B) INCORRECT:

In acute pericarditis, inflammation of the pericardial layers can cause friction as they move during the cardiac cycle, creating an audible friction rub on cardiac auscultation. While a friction rub is characteristic of the acute phase of pericarditis, a different heart sound is pathognomonic for chronic constrictive pericarditis, in which the ventricles are working against a calcified and thickened pericardium.

C) CORRECT:

A pericardial knock is a high-pitched, early-diastolic sound that sounds like a premature S3. A pericardial knock is often heard on auscultation in constrictive pericarditis due to the abrupt halting of diastolic ventricular relaxation and filling by the rigid pericardial sac. In constrictive pericarditis, reduced ventricular filling leads to manifestations of reduced cardiac output (forward failure), such as fatigue and/or dyspnea, as well as those of fluid overload (backward failure), such as jugular venous distention, positive Kussmaul sign, hepatomegaly, and the clinical features seen in this patient.

While tuberculosis is the most likely underlying cause of constrictive pericarditis in this patient, other etiologies include prior cardiac surgery, radiation therapy to the chest, viral infection, and connective tissue diseases.

D) INCORRECT:

A fourth heart sound (S4) is caused by a late diastolic contraction of the atria and is seen in restrictive cardiomyopathy, left ventricular hypertrophy, and ischemic heart disease. Restrictive cardiomyopathy is an important differential diagnosis of constrictive pericarditis because it can manifest similarly. However, it does not cause calcification of the cardiac silhouette. An S4 is not a physical exam finding of constrictive pericarditis, most likely because the rigid pericardial sac impairs atrial contraction.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulsus parvus et tardus is characteristic of the prolonged left ventricular total ejection time seen in aortic stenosis (AS). AS would cause signs and symptoms of left heart failure, but not the symptoms of right heart failure seen in this patient. Furthermore, calcification in AS is limited to the aortic valve and does not involve the entire cardiac silhouette, as seen here.

F) INCORRECT:

Fixed splitting of S2 is pathognomonic for atrial septal defect. Although patients with constrictive pericarditis may occasionally have wide splitting of S2 during inspiration due to a reduction in the left ventricular ejection time, they do not have fixed splitting of S2.
questions.hint: This patient's history of immigration from an endemic region, his clinical presentation of fever and weight loss, as well as the cavernous lesions seen on x-ray indicate tuberculosis. His dyspnea, pitting edema, abdominal distention, and positive hepatojugular reflux in the context of a calcified cardiac silhouette suggest constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of chills and worsening shortness of breath. He has no history of serious illness and does not use illicit drugs. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2. His temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 140/60 mm Hg. There is no jugular venous distention. Examination of the extremities shows several nontender, nonblanching, erythematous macules on the palms and soles and painful nodules on the pads of the fingers and toes. Coarse crackles are heard over both lungs. Cardiac examination is shown. Results of initial blood cultures are pending. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's auscultation findings?
Video
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

IE is typically associated with valvular regurgitation. This patient's murmur is loudest at the left sternal border near Erb point (cardiology). The murmur's characteristics and location make aortic regurgitation (AR) due to valvular disease the most likely diagnosis. Other causes of AR include a congenital bicuspid aortic valve, rheumatic fever, and aortic root dilation due to connective tissue disorders (e.g., Marfan syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome). In contrast to AR due to valvular disease, the murmur of AR secondary to aortic root disease is heard best over the right upper sternal border (aortic area). In patients with AR, a high pulse pressure (due to increased end-diastolic volume and a subsequent increase in stroke volume) is a common finding.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis (AS) can cause left heart failure but would result in low pulse pressure. Moreover, the characteristic murmur of AS is a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard best over the right 2nd intercostal space (aortic area) with radiation to the carotids. Furthermore, IE is typically associated with valvular regurgitation rather than valvular stenosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) can cause left heart failure and is a risk factor for as well as a complication of IE. However, a high pulse pressure is not caused by MVP. Typical cardiac auscultatory findings in MVP would include a midsystolic click with a late systolic murmur that is heard best at the cardiac apex (left 5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line).
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation (MR) is the most common valvular disease associated with IE and can manifest with left heart failure. However, MR manifests with a holosystolic murmur heard best at the cardiac apex (left 5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line) and does not cause a high pulse pressure.

E) INCORRECT:

The murmur of pulmonary stenosis (PS) is heard best parasternally at the left 2nd intercostal space but this condition would manifest with features of right heart failure (e.g., jugular venous distention) and the typical murmur of PS is an ejection systolic murmur, often with a widely split S2. Moreover, PS is usually a congenital heart defect. Acquired PS is rare and occurs in patients with carcinoid syndrome or rheumatic heart disease. IE is typically associated with valvular regurgitation rather than valvular stenosis.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

F) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) can be caused by IE and the murmur of TR is loudest parasternally at the left 4th intercostal space. However, TR due to IE occurs in patients with a history of intravenous drug use and would manifest with features of right heart failure (e.g., jugular venous distention). Janeway lesions, Osler nodes, and pulmonary edema would not be expected with right-sided IE. Moreover, the typical murmur of TR is a holosystolic murmur.
questions.hint: The presence of Janeway lesions, Osler nodes, and features of left heart failure (e.g., pulmonary edema) indicate left-sided infective endocarditis (IE). The sound that coincides with the upstroke of carotid pulsation is S1. There is a murmur that is heard shortly after the carotid pulse, which is consistent with diastolic timing. With a decrescendo early diastolic murmur, S2 cannot be distinguished from the murmur on auscultation.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after collapsing during soccer practice. His father died of sudden cardiac arrest at the age of 36 years. The patient appears well. His pulse is 73/min and blood pressure is 125/78 mm Hg. Cardiac examination is shown. An ECG shows large R waves in the lateral leads and deep S waves in V1 and V2. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
Video

choices.text: Monoclonal light chain deposition in the myocardium

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Monoclonal light chain deposition in the myocardium occurs in cardiac amyloidosis, which is secondary to primary (AL) amyloidosis, and leads to heart failure with preserved ejection fraction. Patients can also present with exertional syncope due to an inability to increase cardiac output, and ECG may show a pseudoinfarct pattern that is similar to the repolarization abnormalities seen here. However, this plasma cell dyscrasia typically affects individuals ≥ 40 years of age, and patients are likely to have symptoms of heart failure as well as other systemic manifestations.

B) INCORRECT:

Dilatation of the aortic root occurs in patients with connective tissue syndromes (e.g., Marfan syndrome), a bicuspid aortic valve, hypertension, atherosclerosis, aortic dissection, and aortic stenosis. Significant dilatation of the aortic annulus can lead to aortic regurgitation, which results in a decrescendo diastolic murmur, in contrast to this patient's systolic ejection murmur. Furthermore, this patient's condition is not associated with aortic root dilation.

C) INCORRECT:

Significant dilatation of the left ventricle is characteristic of dilated cardiomyopathy. While patients with dilated cardiomyopathy may present with exertional dyspnea from heart failure, they are less likely to experience exertional syncope. ECG findings in dilated cardiomyopathy include first-degree AV block, left bundle branch block, left anterior fascicular block, and other intraventricular conduction abnormalities, or evidence of prior infarction as the underlying cause; none of these findings are seen in this case. Examination may reveal a pansystolic murmur of secondary mitral regurgitation heard best at the apex due to LV dilatation, whereas this patient has a prominent systolic ejection murmur.

D) CORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) manifests with an area of increased left ventricular wall thickness that is typically asymmetrical and involves the septum or anterolateral LV wall. Along with mitral valve and papillary muscle abnormalities, septal hypertrophy can lead to left ventricular outflow tract obstruction, resulting in exertional syncope and a systolic ejection murmur. Although the systolic murmur in patients with HCM does not significantly radiate into the carotid arteries, left ventricular outflow tract obstruction in obstructive HCM may mimic an aortic stenosis murmur and may be heard as a subtle ejection murmur on auscultation of the carotids. The ECG shows high voltage QRS complexes, indicating left ventricular hypertrophy. HCM is most commonly a hereditary condition, which explains the history of sudden cardiac death in this patient's father.

The intensity of the murmur associated with HCM decreases with maneuvers that increase venous return (e.g., rapid squatting) because they increase preload, which in turn decreases the pressure gradient across the obstruction. This change in murmur intensity can help differentiate HCM from other causes of systolic murmurs, such as ventricular septal defect and mitral regurgitation.
Image Description:

Hypertrophy of the myocardium results in reduced diastolic compliance and filling of the left ventricle (sometimes also of the right ventricle). Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can occur with or without left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) occurs when hypertrophy of the interventricular septum and systolic anterior movement (SAM) of the mitral valve leaflet results in the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction.

E) INCORRECT:

Fibrinoid necrosis of the mitral valve occurs in acute rheumatic fever (RF), which is typically preceded by a group A streptococcal pharyngitis. Acute RF could lead to significant mitral regurgitation, manifesting as exercise intolerance. However, mitral regurgitation would cause a pansystolic murmur rather than a systolic ejection murmur, and ECG findings in acute rheumatic fever include different degrees of atrioventricular block rather than the changes seen in this patient. Furthermore, this patient has not had a recent GAS infection and has had no other features of rheumatic fever.

F) INCORRECT:

Calcification of the aortic valve occurs secondary to aortic valve stenosis (AS). Patients can present with exertional syncope due to an inability to increase cardiac output, while examination may reveal a harsh systolic ejection murmur and ECG may show evidence of compensatory left ventricular hypertrophy. However, calcific AS is a disease seen in advanced age. Even though individuals with an anatomically abnormal (unicuspid or bicuspid) valve can develop calcific AS one or two decades earlier than those with a normal (tricuspid) valve, this 25-year-old patient is too young to have developed calcific AS. Furthermore, there is no hereditary component to this disease.
questions.hint: This young man has a family history of sudden cardiac death and has just experienced exertional syncope. He has a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard best at the apex and left lower sternal border as well as an S4.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. Current medications include atenolol, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. His pulse is 86/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 145/95 mm Hg. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this physical examination finding?
Video

choices.text: Decreased compliance of the left ventricle
Myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve
Thickening of the mitral valve leaflets

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Decreased compliance of the left ventricle is most likely due to left ventricular hypertrophy caused by long-standing hypertension and often manifests with an S4 gallop. Increased blood pressure activates angiotensin II either by local mechanical stretching of myocardiocytes or as a result of the activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. Angiotensin II promotes concentric remodeling of the heart, increasing stiffness of the organ, thus, decreasing compliance.
Image Description:

Systole
1: Mitral valve closes (1st heart sound)
1–2: Isovolumetric contraction
2: Aortic valve opens
2–3: Ventricular ejection

Diastole
3: Aortic valve closes (2nd heart sound)
3–4: Isovolumetric relaxation
4: Mitral valve opens
4–1: Ventricular filling (3rd and 4th heart sounds)

B) INCORRECT:

Myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve occurs in some connective tissue diseases (e.g., Marfan syndrome, Ehler-Danlos syndrome) leading to eventual mitral valve prolapse (MVP). MVP is associated with late-systolic crescendo murmurs as blood backflows from the left ventricle to the left atrium, preceded by a midsystolic click due to tensing of the chordae tendinae. The mitral regurgitation and volume overload associated with MVP can also result in an S3, which is an early diastolic sound, but MVP is not typically associated with an S4, as seen here.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

Pericardial inflammation (pericarditis), which is typically caused by viral infections, would result in an auscultatory finding (pericardial friction rub) but this sound would be heard in both diastolic and systolic portions of the cardiac cycle and it would be best heard along the left sternal border when the patient sits upright, leans forward, and holds his breath. The sound that is heard here is an S4 gallop, which is an unusual finding in pericarditis. Moreover, patients with pericarditis are rarely asymptomatic; they would usually complain of chest pain and/or breathlessness. It is, therefore, unlikely that this patient has pericarditis.

D) INCORRECT:

Dilation of the aortic root, which is caused by age-related degenerative changes, hypertension, aortitis (e.g., tertiary syphilis), or connective tissue disease (e.g., Marfan syndrome), causes chronic aortic insufficiency (AI). AI can result in a low-pitched, mid or late diastolic sound that is best heard at the cardiac apex due to vibration of the ventricular wall by the regurgitant jet. However, a patient with AI would also have an early diastolic murmur best heard in the right upper sternal border. An isolated low-pitched, late diastolic sound on cardiac examination suggests another cause.
Image Description:

Diastolic murmurs (orange waveform) occur in:

(A) Mitral stenosis (decrescendo murmur with OS)
(B) Tricuspid stenosis (mid-diastolic decrescendo murmur)
(C) Patent ductus arteriosus (continuous crescendo-decrescendo murmur)
(D) Aortic and pulmonary regurgitation (decrescendo murmur)

Note that patent ductus arteriosus produces a continuous murmur heard in both systole and diastole.

OS: opening snap

E) INCORRECT:

Thickening of the mitral leaflet is seen in mitral stenosis and is the cause of the opening snap, which is an early diastolic sound that is best heard at the apex in the left lateral decubitus position. However, the opening snap is a high-pitched sound, unlike the low-pitched sound heard here, and it would be accompanied by the late-diastolic, decrescendo murmur of mitral stenosis.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.
questions.hint: The auscultatory finding in this patient is an S4 gallop, which occurs as the atria pump blood into the ventricles. An S4 gallop is almost always pathological.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She appears well. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiac auscultation shows a mid-systolic click and a grade 3/6, late-systolic, crescendo murmur that is best heard at the cardiac apex in the left lateral recumbent position. After the patient stands up suddenly, the click is heard during early systole and the intensity of the murmur increases. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's examination findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A myosin heavy chain defect is associated with familial hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which is frequently asymptomatic and classically manifests with a heart murmur that can be intensified by standing up. However, HOCM usually presents with a mitral regurgitation systolic murmur and/or a systolic ejection murmur (crescendo-decrescendo), but not with a mid-systolic click and crescendo systolic murmur.

B) INCORRECT:

Aortic root dilation is a characteristic feature of Marfan syndrome and can lead to aortic regurgitation. However, AR would manifest with a diastolic murmur with a decrescendo best heard at the left sternal border, not with a mid-systolic click and crescendo systolic murmur heard in the mitral area. Moreover, the murmur in AR intensifies when the patient leans forward and decreases instead of increases by standing.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

C) CORRECT:

Dermatan sulfate deposition in the mitral valve leaflets, which is characteristic of myxomatous degeneration of the mitral valve, is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's MVP. This condition is most commonly idiopathic but can also be associated with connective tissue disorders (e.g., Marfan syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, fragile X syndrome) or occur as a complication of infective endocarditis, rheumatic heart disease, and myocardial infarction. The mid-systolic click heard on auscultation is caused by sudden tensing of the chordae tendinae, which occurs earlier and more forcefully with decreased left ventricular size.

Maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., handgrip, squatting) are another way to help differentiate MVP from other causes of mitral insufficiency. In MVP, these maneuvers cause the click to move later in systole and become softer due to an increase in left ventricular size.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

D) INCORRECT:

Congenital valvular fusion is the underlying cause of bicuspid aortic valve, which is usually asymptomatic but can predispose to both aortic stenosis (AS) and aortic regurgitation. A calcified bicuspid aortic valve manifests with an aortic systolic ejection click followed by a late systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard over the 2nd right intercostal space, not with a mid-systolic click and crescendo systolic murmur heard best in the mitral area. Furthermore, the murmur in AS decreases instead of increases by sudden standing. Aortic regurgitation, in turn, presents with a murmur during diastole (not systole).

E) INCORRECT:

Congenital interventricular communication causes a ventricular septal defect, which is usually asymptomatic (if the defect is small). However, VSD manifests with a harsh holosystolic murmur over the left lower sternal border and a mid-diastolic murmur over the cardiac apex, not with a mid-systolic click and crescendo systolic murmur heard in the mitral area. In addition, the intensity of the murmur in VSD would be decreased or remain unchanged by standing up instead of increasing.
questions.hint: The presence of a mid-systolic click followed by a crescendo murmur at the mitral area (cardiac apex) is suggestive of mitral valve prolapse (MVP). Maneuvers that decrease the left ventricular size (e.g., sudden standing) increase the intensity of the murmur and cause the click to occur earlier in systole.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He has not seen a physician for 10 years. He works as a telemarketer and does not exercise. Cardiac examination shows a dull, low-pitched sound during late diastole that is best heard at the apex. The sound is loudest in the left lateral decubitus position and during end-expiration. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this finding?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The fourth heart sound is the result of filling a noncompliant ventricle through atrial contraction in late diastole. Positioning the patient in the left-lateral decubitus position increases filling of the left atrium and can thus amplify the heart sound on auscultation. Concentric left ventricular hypertrophy decreases ventricle compliance, which is classically seen in advanced age. In this middle-aged, physically inactive patient, the most likely antecedent cause for left ventricular hypertrophy is hypertensive heart disease secondary to persistently increased afterload.
Image Description:

I–IV: anatomical locations of heart valves

1. Aortic area: 2nd right parasternal intercostal space (ICS)
- Ideal site for auscultation of aortic valve murmurs (1a). The murmur of aortic stenosis also radiates to the carotid arteries (1b).

2. Pulmonary area: 2nd left parasternal ICS
- Ideal site for auscultation of pulmonary valve murmurs

3. Tricuspid area: 4th left parasternal ICS
- Ideal site for auscultation of tricuspid valve murmurs

4. Mitral area: 5th left ICS in the midclavicular line (over the cardiac apex)
- Ideal site for auscultation of mitral valve murmurs (4a). The murmur of mitral regurgitation also radiates to the left axilla (4b).

B) INCORRECT:

Large atrial septal defects can lead to volume overload of the right ventricle (due to left-to-right shunting) and pulmonary hypertension. Pulmonary hypertension can result in right ventricular dysfunction and a right-sided fourth heart sound. However, significant defects would be unlikely to remain asymptomatic until the age of 52. Moreover, this patient does not have the wide, fixed splitting of S2, which is a characteristic finding of atrial septal defects on auscultation.

C) INCORRECT:

Dilation of both ventricles occurs in dilated cardiomyopathy and chronic heart failure. However, this patient has no symptoms of these conditions (e.g., nocturia, fatigue, tachyarrhythmia) and auscultation revealed a fourth heart sound rather than a third heart sound (S3 gallop), which would be expected in ventricular dilation.

D) INCORRECT:

Fusion of the mitral valve leaflets leads to mitral stenosis, which is often asymptomatic. Upon cardiac auscultation, mitral stenosis can produce a low-pitched diastolic rumbling murmur, the duration of which depends on the severity of the stenosis. Other auscultatory findings may include a loud S1 and S2 and an opening snap. However, the fourth heart sound detected in this patient would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Right bundle branch block most commonly occurs as a consequence of right ventricular distension, myocardial infarction, myocarditis, hypertension, or congenital heart disease. It is mostly asymptomatic but may manifest with a wide, fixed-splitting of S2 due to asynchronous ventricular contraction. RBBB does not cause a fourth heart sound.

F) INCORRECT:

Dilatation of the aortic root occurs in patients with connective tissue disorders (e.g., Marfan syndrome), a bicuspid aortic valve, hypertension, atherosclerosis, aortic dissection, or aortic stenosis. Significant dilatation of the aortic annulus can lead to aortic regurgitation, which may be asymptomatic in chronic cases similar to the disorder affecting this patient. However, auscultation would reveal a decrescendo diastolic murmur, unlike the fourth heart sound detected in this patient.
questions.hint: What is described here is a left-sided fourth heart sound (S4).

questions.text:
A 3-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a routine follow-up examination. He was delivered at 32 weeks' gestation to a 35-year-old woman. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this patient's findings?
Video
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) manifests with a continuous machinery murmur best heard in the left infraclavicular area. The machinery murmur is generated as blood continuously shunts from the high-pressure aorta through the ductus arteriosus into the low-pressure pulmonary artery. It may envelop the S2 and is not usually affected by positional changes. Patients with moderate-sized PDAs may present with bounding pulses, widened pulse pressure, and symptoms of heart failure.
Image Description:

Continuous systolic and diastolic heart murmur (machinery murmur)

B) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal defects (VSD) manifest with holosystolic, harsh sounding murmurs, best heard in the left lower sternal border. These murmurs often obliterate the S2 and are associated with a palpable thrill. Neonates present with an asymptomatic heart murmur or, in cases of moderate-to-large sized defects, with signs of heart failure. The examination findings in this patient reveal a continuous machinery murmur in the left upper sternal border, which is not suggestive of a VSD.

C) INCORRECT:

Atrial septal defects (ASD) manifest with pulmonary outflow tract murmurs heard best at the left upper sternal border and are often associated with fixed splitting of S2. ASDs are often low-velocity shunts that produce insufficient flow to be audible. Larger shunts may cause diastolic flow murmurs across the tricuspid valve owing to a large left-to-right shunt. However, the continuous machinery murmur would not be seen in patients with an ASD.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is associated with a late systolic crescendo murmur with a midsystolic click heard best at the apex. The examination findings of a continuous machinery murmur in the left upper sternal border, such as that observed in this patient, would not be seen in patients with MVP.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

E) INCORRECT:

Persistent truncus arteriosus results in a single conduit providing mixed venous and arterial blood to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic circulations. Cardiac exam findings would include a single loud S2, the presence of an ejection click at the cardiac apex or left sternal border, and harsh systolic murmurs at the left sternal border, unlike the continuous machinery murmur heard in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is associated with a harsh crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard along the left mid- to upper-sternal border. The murmur can decrease in intensity as the degree of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction worsens because of increased right-to-left shunting of blood. The examination findings of a continuous machinery murmur in the left upper sternal border, such as that observed in this patient, would not be seen in patients with TOF.
questions.hint: Auscultation shows a continuous murmur. This finding is associated with a condition that affects premature infants or infants with a congenital rubella infection.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a well-child examination. Cardiac auscultation is shown. When she clenches her fist forcefully for a sustained time, the intensity of the murmur increases. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's auscultation findings?
Video

choices.text: Fusion of the right and left coronary leaflets
Asymmetric hypertrophy of the left ventricle
Failure of the ductus arteriosus to close

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse leads to a systolic murmur heard best at the cardiac apex (5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line). This murmur is a late systolic crescendo character, and it is preceded by a click due to tensing of the chordae tendinae. Furthermore, unlike what's seen here, maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., handgrip), decrease rather than increase the intensity of the murmur associated with mitral valve prolapse.

B) INCORRECT:

Fusion of the right and left coronary leaflets of the aortic valve is the pathologic process that underlies a bicuspid aortic valve, which can lead to a systolic murmur caused by aortic stenosis (AS). A murmur caused by AS is heard best at the right upper sternal border. In addition, this murmur has a crescendo-decrescendo character, and it decreases in intensity with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload (e.g., handgrip).

C) INCORRECT:

An atrial septal defect can cause a systolic murmur because of increased flow across the pulmonary valve, but the murmur is heard best at the left upper sternal border. In addition, this murmur has a midsystolic crescendo-decrescendo character, and it is accompanied by a wide, fixed split second heart sound.

D) INCORRECT:

Asymmetric left ventricular hypertrophy is seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which can cause a murmur as a result of mitral regurgitation (MR) or left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. A murmur due to MR is holosystolic, and it increases in intensity with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload (e.g., handgrip), but this murmur is heard best at the cardiac apex (5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line). A murmur due to LVOT obstruction is heard best at the left lower sternal border, but this murmur has a midsystolic, crescendo-decrescendo character, and it decreases in intensity with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload.

E) CORRECT:

A ventricular septal defect (VSD), which causes a left-to-right shunt, leads to a harsh holosystolic murmur because of turbulent blood flow across the defect. The murmur is heard best at the left lower sternal border (tricuspid area) and becomes louder with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload (e.g., handgrip) because of increased left-to-right shunting. The murmur is typically louder with smaller defects as blood rushes through a smaller space. Eventually, a VSD can lead to pulmonary hypertension and a reversal in blood flow (Eisenmenger syndrome), in which case the murmur may disappear or no longer become louder with increased LV afterload because of a countering right-to-left shunting.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

F) INCORRECT:

The failure of the ductus arteriosus to close (patent ductus arteriosus) leads to a murmur heard best at the left infraclavicular region. This murmur occurs during both diastole and systole (i.e., a continuous murmur), unlike the harsh holosystolic murmur seen here.
questions.hint: The handgrip maneuver increases afterload by increasing total peripheral resistance.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of worsening shortness of breath. Initially, his breathlessness developed after climbing one flight of stairs but now appears when he walks from one room to the next. He drinks six glasses of whisky daily and has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years. His blood pressure is 115/90 mm Hg. Cardiac examination is shown. The abnormal finding on cardiac auscultation is loudest when auscultation is performed with the bell of the stethoscope. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's auscultation findings?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Constrictive pericarditis can manifest with chronic, progressively worsening dyspnea but this condition is associated with a pericardial knock, rather than an S3 heart sound. Although a pericardial knock occurs during diastole, it is a high-frequency sound and is best heard at the left sternal border rather than the cardiac apex.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) may manifest with chronic, progressively worsening dyspnea and abnormal cardiac auscultation findings that are loudest at the cardiac apex. However, MVP is associated with a high-frequency midsystolic click and a late systolic crescendo murmur. This patient has no murmur and has a low-frequency diastolic heart sound.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

C) CORRECT:

The S3 heart sound results from a sudden deceleration of blood flow from the atrium into the ventricle during the rapid ventricular filling phase. An S3 originating from the left ventricle is best heard at the cardiac apex and in the left lateral position. An S3 gallop can be a normal variant in young, healthy individuals and during pregnancy but its presence in older patients usually indicates an underlying abnormality such as hyperdynamic circulation, ventricular volume overload (e.g., due to valvular regurgitation), or systolic dysfunction (e.g., due to dilated cardiomyopathy). Given this patient's heavy alcohol use, left ventricular failure due to alcohol-induced cardiomyopathy is a likely cause of the S3 heart sound.
Image Description:

I–IV: anatomical locations of heart valves

1. Aortic area: 2nd right parasternal intercostal space (ICS)
- Ideal site for auscultation of aortic valve murmurs (1a). The murmur of aortic stenosis also radiates to the carotid arteries (1b).

2. Pulmonary area: 2nd left parasternal ICS
- Ideal site for auscultation of pulmonary valve murmurs

3. Tricuspid area: 4th left parasternal ICS
- Ideal site for auscultation of tricuspid valve murmurs

4. Mitral area: 5th left ICS in the midclavicular line (over the cardiac apex)
- Ideal site for auscultation of mitral valve murmurs (4a). The murmur of mitral regurgitation also radiates to the left axilla (4b).

D) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis due to severe aortic valve sclerosis can manifest with chronic, progressively worsening dyspnea but auscultation would likely disclose a mid-systolic ejection murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border. Moreover, left ventricular hypertrophy due to aortic stenosis is typically associated with an S4 heart sound. An S4 is a low-frequency sound and would be best heard at the cardiac apex if it originates from the left ventricle but it is heard immediately before S1 (i.e., during late diastole).
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

E) INCORRECT:

While ventricular septal rupture may cause dyspnea, it typically occurs following myocardial infarction and manifests with acute-onset symptoms and features of hemodynamic instability. Furthermore, a patient with a ventricular septal defect would have a harsh, holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. This patient has no murmur.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

F) INCORRECT:

Depending on the underlying etiology (e.g., cor pulmonale), right ventricular hypertrophy may be associated with chronic, progressively worsening dyspnea. However, ventricular hypertrophy is typically associated with an S4 gallop, which is a low-frequency sound but is heard immediately before S1 (i.e., during late diastole). Moreover, abnormal heart sounds that originate from the right ventricle are best heard at the left lower sternal border.

G) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve stenosis can present with chronic, progressively worsening dyspnea and diastolic sounds that are loudest at the cardiac apex. However, auscultation would reveal a high-frequency diastolic opening snap followed by a mid- to late-diastolic murmur. This patient has no murmur and an S3 heart sound does not typically occur with valvular stenosis.
questions.hint: The sound that coincides with the upstroke of carotid pulsation is S1. The additional heart sound that is heard immediately after S2 (i.e., during early diastole) is the S3 heart sound. S3 gallops follow the cadence of the word Kentucky (Ken: S1, Tuc-ky: S2, S3). A low-frequency sound such as S3 is best heard with the stethoscope bell or the diaphragm in light contact with the skin. This patient's S3 is best heard at the cardiac apex.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after collapsing during soccer practice. The patient appears well. His pulse is 73/min and blood pressure is 125/78 mm Hg. Cardiac examination is shown. Rapid squatting decreases the intensity of the patient's auscultation finding. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
Video

choices.text: Fibrinoid necrosis of the mitral valve
Eccentric dilatation of the left ventricle

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) manifests with an area of increased left ventricular wall thickness that is typically asymmetrical and involves the septum or anterolateral LV wall. Along with mitral valve and papillary muscle abnormalities, septal hypertrophy can lead to dynamic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction, resulting in exertional syncope and systolic ejection murmur, both of which are seen in this patient. The intensity of the murmur associated with HCM decreases with maneuvers that increase venous return (e.g., rapid squatting) because they increase preload, which in turn decreases the pressure gradient across the obstruction. This change in murmur intensity can help differentiate HCM from other causes of systolic murmurs, such as ventricular septal defect and mitral regurgitation.
Image Description:

Hypertrophy of the myocardium results in reduced diastolic compliance and filling of the left ventricle (sometimes also of the right ventricle). Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can occur with or without left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) occurs when hypertrophy of the interventricular septum and systolic anterior movement (SAM) of the mitral valve leaflet results in the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction.

B) INCORRECT:

Fibrinoid necrosis of the mitral valve occurs in acute rheumatic fever (RF), which is typically preceded by a group A streptococcal pharyngitis. Acute RF could lead to significant mitral regurgitation, manifesting as exercise intolerance. However, mitral regurgitation would cause a pansystolic murmur heard best at the apex rather than a systolic ejection murmur. Rapid squatting would result in an increased, not decreased, intensity of the murmur associated with mitral regurgitation. Furthermore, this patient has not had a recent GAS infection and has had no other features of RF.

C) INCORRECT:

Significant dilatation of the left ventricle is characteristic of dilated cardiomyopathy. While patients with dilated cardiomyopathy may present with exertional dyspnea from heart failure, they are less likely to experience exertional syncope. Examination may reveal an S3 and/or a pansystolic murmur of secondary mitral regurgitation heard best at the apex due to LV dilatation. A prominent systolic ejection murmur, as seen in this patient, would not be expected. Furthermore, rapid squatting would result in an increased, not decreased, intensity of the murmur associated with mitral regurgitation.

D) INCORRECT:

Calcification of the aortic valve occurs secondary to aortic valve stenosis (AS). Patients can present with exertional syncope due to an inability to increase cardiac output, and examination may reveal a harsh systolic ejection murmur, as seen here. However, an AS murmur is heard best at the right upper sternal border, not the left sternal border. In addition, calcific AS is a disease usually seen in advanced age. Even though individuals with an anatomically abnormal (unicuspid or bicuspid) valve can develop calcific AS one or two decades earlier than those with a normal (tricuspid) valve, this 26-year-old patient is most likely too young to have developed calcific AS.

E) INCORRECT:

Dilation of the aortic root occurs in individuals with connective tissue syndromes (e.g., Marfan syndrome), a bicuspid aortic valve, and aortic dissection. Significant dilatation of the aortic annulus can lead to aortic regurgitation, which results in a decrescendo diastolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border, in contrast to the systolic ejection murmur seen here. Furthermore, this patient's condition is not associated with aortic root dilation.
questions.hint: This young man has just experienced exertional syncope. He has a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border as well as a fourth heart sound (S4).

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening shortness of breath and nocturnal cough for the past 2 weeks. On two occasions, his cough was bloody. He had a heart condition as a child that was treated with antibiotics. He emigrated to the US from Kazakhstan 15 years ago. Pulmonary examination shows crackles at both lung bases. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although aortic regurgitation may cause signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles), it causes a diastolic decrescendo murmur heard best parasternally at the second intercostal space, and may sometimes be accompanied by an Austin Flint murmur.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse is the most common valvular abnormality in developed countries and is often caused by rheumatic fever. However, it is usually asymptomatic and is best heard at the fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line as a mid-systolic high-frequency click.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary valve stenosis is usually congenital and causes a systolic murmur best heard at the second left intercostal space parasternally. It can radiate to the back and also be present as a widely split second heart sound, but this is not consistent with this patient's findings.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's diastolic murmur at the fifth intercostal space and opening snap indicate mitral stenosis, which causes an increase in left atrial pressure (and ↑ PCWP) and a backup of blood into the lungs. The volume overload eventually causes symptoms of cardiogenic pulmonary edema, which explain this patient's orthopnea, hemoptysis, and crackles. This patient most likely had rheumatic fever as a child, the most common cause of mitral stenosis.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

E) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation may cause signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles). However, it presents as a holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex of the fifth left intercostal space, in contrast to this patient's diastolic murmur.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

F) INCORRECT:

Although severe aortic valve stenosis may eventually cause signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles), patients would most likely first present with syncope or angina. Furthermore, aortic stenosis causes a harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the second right intercostal space, which can radiate to the carotids.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

G) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid valve stenosis is extremely rare and can be caused by rheumatic fever. However, it causes a diastolic murmur best heard at the left fourth intercostal space parasternally and is usually associated with signs of right heart failure (e.g., peripheral edema, jugular venous distention).
Image Description:

Delayed diastolic murmur with a decrescendo, possible presystolic crescendo
questions.hint: This patient's heart problem is consistent with a history of rheumatic fever. An x-ray of the chest in this patient could show left atrial enlargement as a result of this patient's condition.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a well-child examination. He feels well. He was born at 40 weeks' gestation and weighed 3100 g (6 lb 13 oz). There is no personal or family history of serious illness. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at 70th percentile for height and 55th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiac auscultation is shown. When he clenches his fist forcefully for a sustained time, the intensity of the murmur increases. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis (AS) can lead to a systolic murmur, as seen in this patient. However, a murmur caused by AS is heard best at the right upper sternal border. In addition, this murmur has a crescendo-decrescendo character, and it decreases in intensity with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload (e.g., handgrip).

B) INCORRECT:

Patent ductus arteriosus leads to a murmur heard best at the left infraclavicular region. This murmur occurs during both diastole and systole (i.e., a continuous murmur), unlike the harsh holosystolic murmur seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can cause a murmur as a result of mitral regurgitation (MR) or left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. A murmur due to MR is holosystolic and increases in intensity with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload (e.g., handgrip) but is heard best at the cardiac apex (5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line). A murmur due to LVOT obstruction is heard best at the left lower sternal border but has a midsystolic, crescendo-decrescendo character and decreases in intensity with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload.

D) CORRECT:

A ventricular septal defect (VSD), which causes a left-to-right shunt, leads to a harsh holosystolic murmur because of turbulent blood flow across the defect. The murmur is heard best at the left lower sternal border (tricuspid area) and becomes louder with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload (e.g., handgrip) because of increased left-to-right shunting. The murmur is typically louder with smaller defects as blood rushes through a smaller space. Eventually, a VSD can lead to pulmonary hypertension and a reversal in blood flow (Eisenmenger syndrome), in which case the murmur may disappear or no longer become louder with increased LV afterload because of a countering right-to-left shunting.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

E) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse leads to a systolic murmur that increases in intensity with maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., handgrip), which is seen here. However, this murmur is heard best at the cardiac apex (5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line). In addition, this murmur has a late systolic crescendo character, and it is preceded by a click due to tensing of the chordae tendinae.

F) INCORRECT:

An atrial septal defect can cause a systolic murmur because of increased flow across the pulmonary valve, but the murmur is heard best at the left upper sternal border. In addition, this murmur has a midsystolic crescendo-decrescendo character, and it is accompanied by a wide, fixed split second heart sound.
questions.hint: The handgrip maneuver increases afterload by increasing total peripheral resistance.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. He has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia controlled with atenolol, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 90 kg (198 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 145/95 mm Hg. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's auscultation finding?
Video

choices.text: Thickening of the mitral valve leaflets
Decreased compliance of the left ventricle
Impaired closure of the mitral valve

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

With increased left ventricular filling pressures, the left ventricle fills more rapidly in diastole, producing an S3 gallop rather than an S4 gallop, which is seen in this patient. An S3 gallop is caused by rapid left ventricular filling and sudden deceleration of blood when the ventricle reaches its elastic limit. This sound can be a normal variant in young, healthy individuals. In adults, it is typically a sign of ventricular dysfunction due to heart failure, dilated cardiomyopathy, and/or volume overload.

B) INCORRECT:

Dilation of the aortic root, which is caused by age-related degenerative changes, hypertension, aortitis (e.g., tertiary syphilis), or connective tissue disease (e.g., Marfan syndrome), causes chronic aortic insufficiency (AI). AI can result in a low-pitched, mid or late diastolic sound that is best heard at the cardiac apex due to vibration of the ventricular wall by the regurgitant jet. However, a patient with AI would also have an early diastolic murmur best heard in the right upper sternal border. An isolated low-pitched, late diastolic sound on cardiac examination suggests another cause.
Image Description:

Diastolic murmurs (orange waveform) occur in:

(A) Mitral stenosis (decrescendo murmur with OS)
(B) Tricuspid stenosis (mid-diastolic decrescendo murmur)
(C) Patent ductus arteriosus (continuous crescendo-decrescendo murmur)
(D) Aortic and pulmonary regurgitation (decrescendo murmur)

Note that patent ductus arteriosus produces a continuous murmur heard in both systole and diastole.

OS: opening snap

C) INCORRECT:

Thickening of the mitral leaflet is seen in mitral stenosis and is the cause of the opening snap, which is an early diastolic sound that is best heard at the apex in the left lateral decubitus position. However, the opening snap is a high-pitched sound, unlike the low-pitched sound heard here, and it would be accompanied by the late-diastolic, decrescendo murmur of mitral stenosis.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

D) CORRECT:

Decreased compliance of the left ventricle is most likely due to left ventricular hypertrophy caused by long-standing hypertension and often manifests with an S4 gallop, which is due to late diastolic contraction of the atria (atrial kick) against high ventricular pressures. Increased blood pressure activates angiotensin II either by local mechanical stretching of myocardiocytes or as a result of the activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. Angiotensin II promotes concentric remodeling of the heart, increasing stiffness of the organ, thus, decreasing compliance.
Image Description:

Systole
1: Mitral valve closes (1st heart sound)
1–2: Isovolumetric contraction
2: Aortic valve opens
2–3: Ventricular ejection

Diastole
3: Aortic valve closes (2nd heart sound)
3–4: Isovolumetric relaxation
4: Mitral valve opens
4–1: Ventricular filling (3rd and 4th heart sounds)

E) INCORRECT:

Impaired closure of the mitral valve, which can be due to organic changes in the valve leaflets or chordae tendinae (as seen in degenerative mitral valve diseases, rheumatic fever, or infective endocarditis), causes mitral regurgitation (MR). MR is typically associated with a high-pitched, blowing, holosystolic murmur that is best heard over the apex (the 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line) as blood backflows from the left ventricle to the left atrium. While an early diastolic sound (S3) might be heard in severe cases of MR, S4 gallop is not a typical finding.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)
questions.hint: The auscultatory finding in this patient is an S4 gallop, which occurs as the atria pump blood into the ventricles. An S4 gallop is almost always pathological.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man who is a college baseball player comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. One week ago, he had a sore throat and a nonproductive cough that resolved spontaneously within 2 days. His father was diagnosed with dilated cardiomyopathy at the age of 56 years. He has no other personal or family history of serious illness and takes no medications. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 75 kg (165 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 60/min, and blood pressure is 120/79 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac auscultation is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute pericarditis can occur following a viral upper respiratory tract infection, like the self-limiting infection that this patient had one week ago. However, this patient does not have the characteristic features of pericarditis, including fever and pleuritic chest pain. In addition, cardiac auscultation would reveal a pericardial friction rub (a high-pitched scratching sound that is heard best during expiration with the patient sitting up and leaning forward), not a split S2.

B) INCORRECT:

Myocarditis can develop in young individuals following a viral upper respiratory tract infection, such as the self-limiting infection that this patient had one week ago. However, this patient does not have typical features of myocarditis, such as fever, fatigue, dyspnea, and chest pain. In addition, cardiac auscultation findings in a patient with myocarditis include the third heart sound (S3), fourth heart sound (S4), and systolic murmurs of functional mitral regurgitation or tricuspid regurgitation due to dilated cardiomyopathy. Myocarditis does not cause a split S2.

C) INCORRECT:

An atrial septal defect (ASD) is the most common congenital heart defect in adults and can be asymptomatic in younger individuals. Although an ASD can manifest with a split S2, it typically causes fixed splitting (i.e., the split does not change with respiration). In addition, patients with an ASD often have a systolic ejection murmur over the left upper sternal border, which is not heard in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) is frequently asymptomatic and can be detected during routine screening of young athletes. Although HOCM can manifest with a split S2, a paradoxical splitting is typically seen in which the split is more pronounced during expiration rather than inspiration. This phenomenon is caused by delayed closure of the aortic valve (A2) due to left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. In addition, patients with HOCM usually also have a crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur, which is not heard in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis (AS) is most commonly caused by aortic valve sclerosis but can develop in younger patients with a bicuspid aortic valve due to dystrophic calcification and degeneration. Less commonly, AS can develop secondary to rheumatic fever, which typically develops 1–5 weeks after an untreated infection with group A Streptococcus; this patient's untreated respiratory infection one week ago was self-limiting. Severe AS can cause a split S2, but it is typically heard during expiration, not inspiration. Moreover, the characteristic cardiac auscultation finding of AS is a harsh, crescendo-decrescendo, late systolic ejection murmur that radiates bilaterally to the carotid arteries, which is not heard in this patient.

F) CORRECT:

Splitting of S2 during inspiration is a common physiologic finding that occurs because of a decrease in intrathoracic pressure during inspiration. Decreased intrathoracic pressure leads to increased venous return to the right side of the heart, which results in prolonged right ventricular systole and delayed closure of the pulmonic valve (P2). During inspiration, there is also decreased blood flow to the left side of the heart due to pooling within the pulmonary vasculature, resulting in early closure of the aortic valve (A2). A physiologic split S2 is more common in young individuals and requires no further evaluation.

G) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is the most common heart valve abnormality and can be seen in young individuals, most of whom are asymptomatic. Cardiac auscultation in an individual with MVP would reveal a high-frequency, midsystolic click followed by a high-frequency, mid-to-late systolic murmur that is heard best at the mitral region and may radiate to the axilla. MVP does not cause a split S2.
questions.hint: Cardiac auscultation shows splitting of the second heart sound (S2) during inspiration.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents for management of hypertension. At his previous visit 8 weeks ago, his blood pressure was 180/95 mm Hg. He reports that he has stopped smoking and has restricted his salt intake since that visit. He is asymptomatic, with normal exercise tolerance.
Today, his initial blood pressure is 166/94 mm Hg in both arms, and his heart rate is 65 beats per minute. A second blood pressure reading, obtained after he has been seated for 10 minutes, is similar. An S4 gallop is clearly audible on cardiac auscultation. He has no cardiac murmurs, no abdominal bruits, and no other abnormal findings. His serum electrolyte levels, urinalysis, and creatinine concentration are normal. An electrocardiogram shows no left ventricular hypertrophy.
In addition to initiating an antihypertensive medication, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of serum N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urine catecholamine and renal Doppler studies are tests for secondary causes of hypertension. Given that most individuals with elevated blood pressure have primary hypertension, evaluation for secondary causes of hypertension is not recommended unless there are other reasons to suspect a secondary cause. This patient has none of the features that would suggest a secondary cause of hypertension and therefore does not require an evaluation for a secondary cause of hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

In a young, asymptomatic, hypertensive person with normal exercise tolerance, echocardiography is not indicated. Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction would be very unlikely. Although the echocardiogram might demonstrate left ventricular hypertrophy or heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (diastolic dysfunction), those findings would not change the management of this case.

C) INCORRECT:

A serum N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide concentration, whether normal or abnormal, has limited diagnostic value in an asymptomatic patient and would not alter the management approach.

D) INCORRECT:

Urine catecholamine and renal Doppler studies are tests for secondary causes of hypertension. Given that most individuals with elevated blood pressure have primary hypertension, evaluation for secondary causes of hypertension is not recommended unless there are other reasons to suspect a secondary cause. This patient has none of the features that would suggest a secondary cause of hypertension and therefore does not require an evaluation for a secondary cause of hypertension.

E) CORRECT:

An S4 gallop is a common finding in patients with hypertension, resulting from forceful left atrial contraction and movement of blood into a hypertrophied left ventricle. Unlike an S3 gallop, an S4 gallop does not indicate ventricular systolic failure. An S4 gallop does not warrant further evaluation, but aggressive treatment of hypertension is indicated to prevent progression of end-organ effects.

Given that most individuals with elevated blood pressure have primary hypertension, evaluation for secondary causes of hypertension is not recommended unless there are other reasons to suspect a secondary cause. Indications to initiate evaluation for secondary causes of hypertension include symptoms, historical features, or physical examination findings that suggest a specific secondary cause of hypertension or one of the following criteria:

• Onset of hypertension before age 30
• Drug-resistant hypertension
• Abrupt onset of hypertension
• Exacerbation of previously controlled hypertension
• Disproportionate target-organ damage for the degree of hypertension
• Accelerated or malignant hypertension
• Onset of diastolic hypertension in adults age 65 years or older
• Unprovoked or excessive hypokalemia

This patient has none of these features and therefore does not require an evaluation for a secondary cause of hypertension.

Key learning point: An S4 gallop is the most common physical finding on cardiac auscultation in patients with hypertension and does not warrant further evaluation.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man who has not seen a health care provider in many years presents for follow-up after a required preemployment electrocardiogram (figure). He has no notable medical history, feels well, and does not use tobacco or alcohol. He takes no medications.
His blood pressure is 190/105 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 75 beats per minute. Cardiac examination reveals a sustained apical impulse and no audible murmurs. His kidney function and serum electrolyte levels are normal.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Renal artery stenosis is a rare cause of hypertension and resultant LVH and is often associated with impaired kidney function.

B) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma that is sufficiently severe and chronic to cause LVH typically produces a range of symptoms, including headaches and palpitations.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is associated with LVH but not hypertension. In addition, patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and significant left ventricular outflow-tract obstruction often have a murmur related to this obstruction or a mitral regurgitation murmur related to systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve.

D) INCORRECT:

Although aortic stenosis can cause LVH, it does not cause hypertension and is easily identified by the presence of a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur.

E) CORRECT:

This asymptomatic patient has primary hypertension, with electrocardiographic evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH). A sustained apical impulse indicates that LVH is present. The patient’s echocardiogram would be likely to show thickened LV walls and an elevated LV mass index.

Key learning point: The cardiac examination finding of a sustained apical impulse is most consistent with a diagnosis of left ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old woman presents to the emergency department reporting a 24-hour history of progressive chest discomfort and shortness of breath. She was diagnosed with invasive breast cancer 4 weeks ago and is currently undergoing staging evaluation as an outpatient.
On examination, she has a heart rate of 120 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 84/52 mm Hg. She has an elevated jugular venous pressure, clear lungs, and cool extremities.
She is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. A chest radiograph shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette with clear lungs. An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following physical findings is this patient most likely to have?

choices.text: A friction rub heard over the cardiac apex
A decrease in systolic blood pressure of at least 10 mm Hg on inspiration

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A friction rub heard at the apex is typical of pericarditis but not necessarily pericardial effusion with tamponade.

B) INCORRECT:

In cardiac tamponade, the jugular venous pressure is usually elevated because of restricted filling of the right atrium and ventricle.

C) INCORRECT:

A left ventricular third heart sound (S3) is unlikely in this patient with clear lungs and a presentation more consistent with tamponade than with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.

D) CORRECT:

The combination of a large heart with hypotension, clear lungs on chest radiograph, and electrical alternans on electrocardiogram suggests cardiac tamponade. Acute management for hemodynamically unstable cardiac tamponade includes aggressive intravenous fluids and urgent pericardiocentesis or surgical drainage.

A characteristic clinical finding in a patient with cardiac tamponade is pulsus paradoxus. Pulsus paradoxus is defined by a decrease in systolic blood pressure of at least 10 mm Hg on inspiration, an exaggeration of the normal hemodynamic response. Inspiration is accompanied by a decrease in intrathoracic pressure, which increases venous return. Given that the right ventricular free wall cannot expand (because of the increased pericardial pressure), the increased venous return to the right ventricle shifts the interventricular septum leftward. This septal shift reduces left ventricular filling and, consequently, lowers systemic stroke volume and blood pressure. Note that pulsus paradoxus can also occur in asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Key learning point: Pulsus paradoxus, commonly seen in patients with cardiac tamponade, refers to an exaggeration of a normal hemodynamic response to inspiration, whereby the systolic blood pressure decreases by at least 10 mm Hg.

E) INCORRECT:

A loud second pulmonary sound is most indicative of pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old male college student who is about to join the school basketball team presents for a preparticipation physical examination. He reports no medical problems, and all members of his family are well.
On examination, you note a brief, low-pitched, midsystolic, vibratory murmur that is loudest when the patient is in the supine position and that disappears when he sits up; there is no radiation of the murmur, and the remainder of the cardiac examination is normal.
What testing, if any, is appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Electrocardiogram, echocardiogram, and exercise stress test

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The American Heart Association recommends a complete personal history, family history, and physical examination for any young athlete who is about to participate in competitive sports. The routine use of electrocardiography, echocardiography, or exercise testing is not recommended, unless prompted by findings on the initial comprehensive history and physical examination.

B) CORRECT:

The American Heart Association recommends a complete personal history, family history, and physical examination for any young athlete who is about to participate in competitive sports. The routine use of electrocardiography, echocardiography, or exercise testing is not recommended, unless prompted by findings on the initial comprehensive history and physical examination. The European Society of Cardiology, however, includes electrocardiography in its recommendations for initial screening of athletes.

This patient’s murmur is an innocent Still murmur. The Still murmur is a brief, vibratory, grade 1–3, midsystolic, low-pitched murmur. It is heard at the left lower sternal border and occasionally radiates to the cardiac apex. It is the loudest in the supine position and diminishes in intensity when a patient is made to sit or stand up, as these positions diminish the venous return to the heart.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial screening in a young adult before they participate in competitive sports involves a complete personal history, family history, and physical examination.

C) INCORRECT:

The American Heart Association recommends a complete personal history, family history, and physical examination for any young athlete who is about to participate in competitive sports. The routine use of electrocardiography, echocardiography, or exercise testing is not recommended, unless prompted by findings on the initial comprehensive history and physical examination.

D) INCORRECT:

The American Heart Association recommends a complete personal history, family history, and physical examination for any young athlete who is about to participate in competitive sports. The routine use of electrocardiography, echocardiography, or exercise testing is not recommended, unless prompted by findings on the initial comprehensive history and physical examination.

E) INCORRECT:

The American Heart Association recommends a complete personal history, family history, and physical examination for any young athlete who is about to participate in competitive sports. The routine use of electrocardiography, echocardiography, or exercise testing is not recommended, unless prompted by findings on the initial comprehensive history and physical examination.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presents with fatigue that has been worsening for a year. He recently quit his construction job because of exertional intolerance. He also reports dyspnea on climbing two flights of stairs or walking more than half a mile. He has no ankle swelling, chest pain, or orthopnea. He has not seen a doctor since childhood and has no family history of cardiorespiratory conditions.
On examination, he is of normal weight and has no clubbing, cyanosis, or lower-extremity edema. A left parasternal heave is detected on precordial palpation. Cardiac auscultation reveals wide and fixed splitting of the second heart sound, with a soft systolic murmur at the upper-left sternal border. The lung fields are clear on auscultation.
A resting electrocardiogram shows an incomplete right bundle-branch block.
Which one of the following congenital cardiac abnormalities is this patient most likely to have?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A patent foramen ovale usually causes no cardiac symptoms or signs.

B) INCORRECT:

A ventricular septal defect would cause a holosystolic murmur loudest over the lower-left sternal border.

C) INCORRECT:

A mid-diastolic murmur at the apex, or a loud first heart sound would suggest mitral stenosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Cyanosis or a loud P2 would be characteristic of Eisenmenger syndrome (i.e., pulmonary hypertension due to a long-standing left-to-right intracardiac shunt that results eventually in shunt reversal). Severe pulmonary hypertension is likely to cause hypertrophy of the free wall of the right ventricle and lead to a high or wide R-prime or to a pattern of marked right ventricular hypertrophy on the 12-lead electrocardiogram.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has an atrial septal defect (ASD). Dyspnea and fatigue are common symptoms of an ASD characterized by substantial left-to-right intracardiac shunting. The splitting of the second heart sound is fixed, as phasic changes in venous return are accompanied by reciprocal changes in the interatrial shunt volume, thereby minimizing respiratory influence on pulmonary-valve closure timing. The systolic murmur results from increased forward flow across the pulmonary valve; flow across the ASD is inaudible. Electrocardiographic evidence of an incomplete right bundle-branch block is typical of ASD.

Key learning point: Findings of a widely fixed splitting of the second heart sound, a soft systolic murmur, and electrocardiographic evidence of an incomplete right bundle-branch block are most likely to be caused by an atrial septal defect.

questions.text:
A 79-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents with shortness of breath, chest pressure, and lower-extremity swelling. He is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
His vital signs on admission include a blood pressure of 148/94 mm Hg, a heart rate of 90 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 91% while he is breathing ambient air.
His jugular venous pressure is elevated to 10 cm above the manubriosternal angle. Inspiratory crackles are heard at both lung bases. S1 is normal; S2 is only heard faintly at the right upper sternal border. He has a crescendo-decrescendo midsystolic grade 3/6 murmur that is loudest at the right upper sternal border, with radiation to the neck and also to the apex. The carotid pulse is low-volume and slow-rising.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonic stenosis is usually a congenital abnormality; when it is acquired in adulthood, it is often associated with carcinoid syndrome.
