Pulmonic stenosis, like AS, causes a crescendo-decrescendo midsystolic murmur, but it is best heard at the upper left sternal border. In addition, severe pulmonic stenosis would cause right heart (not left heart) failure.

B) INCORRECT:

Aortic sclerosis is the term used for calcification and thickening of aortic valve leaflets, without a gradient across the valve. Because the valve is not yet stenotic (by definition) in aortic sclerosis, patients are asymptomatic. Patients with aortic sclerosis often have a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur similar to that of aortic stenosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Because the murmur of aortic stenosis often radiates to the apex (as well as to the neck), clinicians may wonder whether an additional murmur of mitral regurgitation is present. However, murmurs of mitral regurgitation in patients with heart failure are usually pansystolic with radiation to the axilla.

D) INCORRECT:

Severe tricuspid regurgitation causes a holosystolic murmur heard best along the mid- to lower sternal borders. Many patients with tricuspid regurgitation have a visible rise and fall of the jugular venous wave with each heartbeat. This so-called “V wave” corresponds to the regurgitant jet of blood during systole and the return of blood to the right heart during diastole.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s physical examination findings suggest left heart failure secondary to severe aortic stenosis (AS). Severe AS is associated with a low-volume, slow-rising carotid pulse (pulsus parvus et tardus), a late-peaking crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur, and a diminished or absent aortic component of the second heart sound correlate with severe AS (valve area <1.0 cm2). The diminished intensity of S2 occurs because the calcified aortic leaflets in AS become relatively immobile.

Key learning point: A low-volume, slow-rising carotid pulse, a diminished aortic component of the second heart sound, and a late-peaking systolic ejection murmur are clinical signs of severe aortic stenosis.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman with a history of scleroderma reports a 6-month history of progressively worsening dyspnea.
On examination, she has an accentuated P2 heart sound, a right ventricular heave, and a diastolic decrescendo murmur at the left upper sternal border that is graded 2 on a scale of 1 to 4. She has jugular venous distention to 10 cm and 1+ lower-extremity edema. Her lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Scleroderma is one of the more common connective tissue diseases to result in pulmonary arterial hypertension, in which there is increased pulmonary vascular resistance, with subsequent hypertrophy of the right ventricle. Cardiac examination findings characteristic of pulmonary arterial hypertension include an accentuated P2 heart sound (related to the forceful closure of the pulmonic valve), a right ventricular heave (related to right ventricular hypertrophy), and elevated right heart filling pressures. The diastolic murmur of pulmonic regurgitation (a so-called Graham Steell murmur) may also be audible, as in this patient.

Key learning point: An accentuated P2 heart sound, a right ventricular heave, and evidence of right heart failure are most consistent with a diagnosis of pulmonary arterial hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

A patent ductus arteriosus would produce a continuous, machinery-like murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

Eisenmenger syndrome (i.e., right-to-left intracardiac shunting, cyanosis, and polycythemia) is caused by pulmonary hypertension related to a congenital defect between the right and left heart circulations. Scleroderma does not cause Eisenmenger syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis is most often a congenital condition that produces a systolic ejection murmur along the left sternal border. The P2 component is usually soft, not accentuated.

E) INCORRECT:

Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by elevated jugular venous pressure, Kussmaul sign, and a pericardial knock. An accentuated P2 heart sound or a right ventricular heave is not characteristic of constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text:
A healthy 4-year-old girl who is growing and developing normally is found to have a heart murmur during her physical examination. She has no family history of valvular heart disease or sudden cardiac death.
Her temperature is 36.7°C, her heart rate is 110 beats per minute, her respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute, and her blood pressure is 92/57 mm Hg. She has a II/VI high-pitched crescendo-decrescendo midsystolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border between the second and third intercostal spaces. The murmur is loudest when she is supine. There are no clicks or gallops.
The patient is warm and well perfused, and her peripheral pulses are symmetric bilaterally. Her lungs are clear to auscultation.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this child?

choices.text: Obtain an electrocardiogram and chest radiograph
Arrange for a follow-up visit in 2 months to evaluate for any progression in the murmur
Obtain a throat swab for rapid streptococcal antigen detection

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Heart murmurs are often detected in healthy infants, children, and adolescents. The vast majority of murmurs referred for specialty evaluation are benign.

This child has an innocent pulmonary flow murmur. Such murmurs have seven key descriptive features, known as the 7 S's: sensitive (changes with the child’s position or with respiration), short duration (not holosystolic), single (no associated clicks or gallops), small (nonradiating murmur limited to a small area), soft (low amplitude), sweet (not harsh-sounding), and systolic (occurs during and limited to systole).

Any of the following features should heighten concern for a pathologic murmur: feeding intolerance or sweating upon feeding; failure to thrive; changes in skin color; and respiratory symptoms, such as persistent cough, audible wheeze, or increased work of breathing. In older children and adolescents, exercise intolerance, shortness of breath, palpitations, syncope, or chest pain with exercise should be elicited. A family history of sudden cardiac death and valvular heart disease are also red flags.

Pathologic murmurs are generally grade III and above. Murmurs that are loudest in the supine position and disappear with standing or Valsalva maneuvers are generally innocent in nature.

Obtaining an electrocardiogram, chest radiograph, or echocardiogram; testing for streptococcal infection; and planning further evaluation in 2 months are each unnecessary for this patient, given that she has no historical or physical examination findings to suggest a pathologic murmur.

Key learning point: In a young child with a pulmonary flow murmur and no related historical features, physical examination findings, or family history of cardiac disease, the most appropriate next step is to reassure the parents and provide them with anticipatory guidance.

B) INCORRECT:

Obtaining an electrocardiogram is unnecessary for this patient, given that she has no historical or physical examination findings to suggest a pathologic murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

Planning further evaluation in 2 months is unnecessary for this patient, given that she has no historical or physical examination findings to suggest a pathologic murmur.

D) INCORRECT:

Obtaining an echocardiogram is unnecessary for this patient, given that she has no historical or physical examination findings to suggest a pathologic murmur.

E) INCORRECT:

Testing for streptococcal infection is unnecessary for this patient, given that she has no historical or physical examination findings to suggest a pathologic murmur.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. He has no history of serious illness. He is at the 60th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 3/6 systolic ejection crescendo-decrescendo murmur is heard along the lower left sternal border. The murmur decreases in intensity on rapid squatting and increases in intensity when he performs the Valsalva maneuver. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Predamaged heart valves (e.g., aortic stenosis, mitral valve regurgitation) or congenital heart defects (e.g., ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis) can predispose to infective endocarditis. However, systolic murmurs caused by valvular disease or congenital heart disease generally demonstrate increased intensity with rapid squatting (increased preload) and decreased intensity with the Valsalva maneuver (decreased preload).

B) CORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) can manifest with a systolic ejection murmur caused by subvalvular dynamic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO). Rapid squatting increases left ventricular preload, decreasing the dynamic LVOTO and softening the intensity of the murmur, whereas the Valsalva maneuver decreases preload, which exacerbates dynamic obstruction and makes the murmur louder. Unlike a murmur due to valvular or supravalvular aortic stenosis, which is best heard at the right upper sternal border, the systolic ejection murmur due to HCM is best heard at the left lower sternal border and/or Erb's point (cardiology).

Hypertrophic myocardium, fibrosis, and disarrangement of cardiac myocytes predispose to potentially lethal ventricular arrhythmias, which can lead to sudden cardiac death, usually during or after physical activity. Since HCM is the most common cause of sudden cardiac death in young athletes, patients with HCM should be advised to avoid strenuous sports. Those at particularly high risk (e.g., survived a previous arrhythmia) should undergo placement of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator.

C) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical embolism can be associated with atrial septal defects (ASD) or ventricular septal defects (VSD). An ASD can present with a systolic murmur, but it would likely also show fixed splitting of the S2. A VSD can present with a holosystolic (not systolic ejection) murmur. The intensity of both defects would decrease rather than increase with the Valsalva maneuver (decreased preload) and increase with rapid squatting (increased preload).

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary apoplexy can occur in mitral stenosis, which presents with a diastolic murmur heard in the third left intercostal space but not a systolic murmur.

E) INCORRECT:

Cerebral aneurysms may be associated with coarctation of the aorta. Coarctation may present with a systolic ejection murmur over the left paravertebral area due to blood flowing through the aortic narrowing and/or a continuous murmur from collateral vessels heard between the shoulder blades. If the intensity changes at all, it would decrease with the Valsalva maneuver and/or increase with rapid squatting. Coarctation of the aorta may also be accompanied by other symptoms, such as hypertension, lower extremity cyanosis, lower extremity claudication, cold feet, dyspnea on exertion, or chest pain.
questions.hint: Echocardiography would most likely show asymmetric interventricular septal hypertrophy and/or systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve, which are consistent with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man comes to the office because of a 6-month history of worsening fatigue and exertional shortness of breath. He sometimes wakes up coughing and gasping for air. Two months ago, he emigrated from Bangladesh. He does not take any medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Auscultation of the lungs shows crackles at both lung bases. Physical examination shows a high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur that radiates into the axilla. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's auscultatory findings indicate mitral regurgitation as the cause of his left-sided heart failure. His history of emigration from Bangladesh makes rheumatic heart disease (RHD) the most likely etiology. RHD is the leading cause of acquired valve defects in developing countries; in ∼ 65% of cases, it is the mitral valve that is affected. While regurgitation murmurs are common in the early course of RHD, murmurs of stenosis or mixed murmurs typically develop as the disease progresses. Other causes of primary mitral regurgitation include degenerative mitral valve diseases (e.g., mitral valve prolapse, mitral annular calcification, ruptured chordae tendineae) and infective endocarditis.

See “Auscultation in valvular defects” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation can cause a holosystolic murmur; however, it is typically heard best at the lower parasternal region, does not radiate to the axilla, and does not have a blowing quality. Like all right-sided heart murmurs, it intensifies during deep inspiration. In contrast, this patient's murmur intensifies on expiration. Moreover, tricuspid valve regurgitation is extremely rare and more commonly manifests with symptoms of right-sided heart failure (e.g., peripheral pitting edema, jugular venous distention).

C) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis can result in manifestations of left-sided heart failure. However, the murmur associated with aortic stenosis is typically a harsh mid-systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur that may radiate bilaterally to the carotids and is heard best in the 2nd intercostal space at the right upper sternal border.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis can result in manifestations of left-sided heart failure. However, the murmur associated with mitral stenosis is typically a low-frequency, mid-diastolic (not systolic) rumble with an associated loud S1. This patient's history of immigration from a developing country should raise suspicion for rheumatic heart disease, the most common cause of mitral stenosis, as the cause of his murmur. However, mitral stenosis typically occurs later in the course of rheumatic heart disease in middle-aged adults.

E) INCORRECT:

Aortic regurgitation can result in manifestations of left-sided heart failure. However, the murmur associated with aortic regurgitation is typically a high-frequency, blowing decrescendo murmur during early diastole that is heard best in the left 3rd and 4th intercostal spaces and along the left sternal border.
questions.hint: This patient presents with fatigue, exertional dyspnea, paroxysmal nocturnal awakening, dry cough, and crackles at both lung bases; these findings suggest a diagnosis of left-sided heart failure. Auscultation shows a high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur that radiates into the axilla and is heard best at the apex.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the office for decreased exercise tolerance. Over the past four months, he has noticed progressively worsening shortness of breath while walking his dog. He also becomes short of breath when lying in bed at night. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 155/53 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a high-pitched, decrescendo murmur that occurs immediately after S2 and is heard best along the left sternal border. There is an S3 gallop. Carotid pulses are strong. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis (MS) can cause dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea. Although MS produces a decrescendo diastolic murmur, it is usually slightly delayed after S2 and would be heard best along the left midclavicular line (at third left intercostal space), not the left sternal border. A prominent S1 and/or an opening snap of the mitral valve after S2 may also be present. Furthermore, since MS restricts left ventricular blood flow, left ventricular preload is decreased, such that carotid pulses would be diminished and an S3 would not be present.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation can cause dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea. However, mitral regurgitation produces a holosystolic murmur that is heard best at the apex (5th intercostal space at the left midclavicular line), not a diastolic murmur that is heard best at the left sternal border.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

C) INCORRECT:

While very rare, tricuspid regurgitation (TR) can cause signs of right-sided heart failure (lower extremity edema, hepatomegaly), but not signs of left-sided heart failure (dyspnea, orthopnea). Furthermore, TR produces a holosystolic murmur heard best at the 4th intercostal space of the left sternal border, not a diastolic murmur.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

D) CORRECT:

An early diastolic decrescendo murmur that is heard best at the left sternal border suggests aortic regurgitation (AR). Regurgitation of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle (LV) causes widened pulse pressure with a decreased diastolic blood pressure. To maintain an adequate cardiac output despite regurgitation, initially, there is a compensatory increase in stroke volume. Over time, the increased LV end-diastolic volume leads to LV enlargement and eccentric myocardial hypertrophy. Patients may be asymptomatic for decades despite progressive LV dilation. In chronic AR, this compensatory response results in left ventricular dysfunction, and patients develop signs and symptoms of left heart failure (exertional and nocturnal dyspnea, S3 gallop). The diagnosis of AR should be confirmed with transthoracic echocardiography.

Maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., handgrip) increase the intensity of the associated murmur as a result of the enlargement of regurgitation volume across the valve.

Key learning point: Aortic regurgitation presents with a high-pitched, early diastolic decrescendo murmur at the left sternal border, widened pulse pressure, and can lead to left-sided heart failure symptoms and an S3 gallop.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

E) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis (AS) can cause dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea. However, it commonly causes a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur, not a decrescendo diastolic murmur. Furthermore, AS will more likely cause an S4 from a stiff myocardium due to left ventricular hypertrophy, rather than an S3. Carotid pulses tend to be diminished and delayed, not prominent.
Image Description:

Crescendo-decrescendo ejection murmur with an ejection click

In aortic stenosis, there is usually radiation into the carotids.
questions.hint: This patient's murmur would become louder with handgrip.

questions.text: A 79-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents with shortness of breath, chest pressure, and lower-extremity swelling. Vital signs on admission include a pulse of 90/min, blood pressure of 148/94 mm Hg, and a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 91% while he is breathing ambient air. His jugular venous pressure is elevated to 10 cm above the manubriosternal angle. Inspiratory crackles are heard at both lung bases. S1 is normal; S2 is only heard faintly at the right upper sternal border. He has a crescendo-decrescendo midsystolic grade 3/6 murmur that is loudest at the right upper sternal border, with radiation to the neck and also to the apex. The carotid pulse is low-volume and slow-rising. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonic stenosis is usually a congenital abnormality; when it is acquired in adulthood, it is often associated with carcinoid syndrome. Pulmonic stenosis, like AS, causes a crescendo-decrescendo midsystolic murmur, but it is best heard at the upper left sternal border. In addition, severe pulmonic stenosis would cause right heart (not left heart) failure.

B) INCORRECT:

Aortic sclerosis is the term used for calcification and thickening of aortic valve leaflets, without a gradient across the valve. Because the valve is not yet stenotic (by definition) in aortic sclerosis, patients are asymptomatic. Patients with aortic sclerosis often have a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur similar to that of aortic stenosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Because the murmur of aortic stenosis often radiates to the apex (as well as to the neck), clinicians may wonder whether an additional murmur of mitral regurgitation is present. However, murmurs of mitral regurgitation in patients with heart failure are usually pansystolic with radiation to the axilla.

D) INCORRECT:

Severe tricuspid regurgitation causes a holosystolic murmur heard best along the mid- to lower sternal borders. Many patients with tricuspid regurgitation have a visible rise and fall of the jugular venous wave with each heartbeat. This so-called “V wave” corresponds to the regurgitant jet of blood during systole and the return of blood to the right heart during diastole.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s physical examination findings suggest left heart failure secondary to severe aortic stenosis (AS). Severe AS is associated with a low-volume, slow-rising carotid pulse (pulsus parvus et tardus), a late-peaking crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur, and a diminished or absent aortic component of the second heart sound correlate with severe AS (valve area <1.0 cm2). The diminished intensity of S2 occurs because the calcified aortic leaflets in AS become relatively immobile.

Key learning point: A low-volume, slow-rising carotid pulse, a diminished aortic component of the second heart sound, and a late-peaking systolic ejection murmur are clinical signs of severe aortic stenosis.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man who recently immigrated to the United States from Haiti comes to the office because of a 3-week history of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and fatigue. For the past few days, he has also had difficulty lying flat due to trouble breathing. Over the past year, he has had intermittent fever, night sweats, and cough but he has not been seen by a physician for evaluation of these symptoms. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F). An x-ray of the chest is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Elimination of S2 heart sound splitting with inspiration
Painless erythematous lesions on palms or soles
Prominent "a" wave on jugular venous pressure tracing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Splitting of the second heart sound (S2) is a physiological finding heard during inspiration. It is caused by the early closure of the aortic valve (A2) in relation to the pulmonary valve (P2) when intrathoracic pressure is decreased. In conditions such as aortic stenosis (AS), ventricular septal defect with Eisenmenger syndrome, and left bundle branch block, elimination of S2 splitting can occur because A2 is delayed and superimposed on P2. Although severe, long-standing aortic stenosis can result in fatigue, dyspnea, orthopnea, and cough (due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema), chronic AS is not associated with fever or night sweats but with symptoms such as syncope, palpitations, and angina. Moreover, an x-ray would not show pericardial calcifications but an enlarged cardiac silhouette.

B) INCORRECT:

Painless erythematous lesions on the palms or soles (Janeway lesions) are highly suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE), which can manifest with dyspnea, fatigue, cough, fever, and night sweats. However, the symptoms of IE have an acute or subacute onset (days to weeks), whereas this patient had fever, night sweats, and a cough for a year before developing dyspnea and fatigue. Moreover, an x-ray would not show pericardial calcifications, and IE is almost always associated with the development of a new heart murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

On a jugular venous pressure tracing, the “a” wave is caused by atrial contraction in late diastole. A prominent “a” wave is a sign of increased atrial contraction pressure due to restricted filling of the right ventricle (e.g., tricuspid valve stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, cardiac tamponade). In constrictive pericarditis, right ventricular filling is only impaired when the elastic limit of the pericardium is reached. As a result, all right ventricular filling rapidly occurs in early diastole, producing a prominent and deep x descent and y descent on venous pressure tracing rather than a prominent “a” wave.
Image Description:

A normal jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform is composed of:
- a wave: atrial contraction
- c wave: tricuspid valve closure
- x descent: atrial relaxation
- v wave: venous refilling of the atria
- y descent: passive filling of right ventricle when the tricuspid valve opens

Common abnormalities of the JVP waveform include:
- Constrictive pericarditis: elevated JVP (due to increased external atrial pressure) with a prominent x (exaggerated atrial relaxation) and y (early rapid ventricular filling) descent
- Cardiac tamponade: elevated JVP (due to increased external atrial pressure), a prominent x descent (exaggerated atrial relaxation), and a blunt or absent y descent (minimal ventricular filling)
- Tricuspid regurgitation: prominent v wave as the blood from the right ventricle regurgitates into the right atrium during ventricular systole (atrial diastole), increasing interatrial pressure and volume
- Tricuspid stenosis: giant a wave due to high right atrial systolic pressure
- Atrial septal defect: v wave ≥ a wave due to the left-to-right shunting of blood
- Third-degree atrioventricular (AV) block: cannon a waves due to the loss of AV synchronization and contraction of the atria against a closed tricuspid valve
- Atrial fibrillation: absent a waves due to ineffective contraction of the atria

D) CORRECT:

Normally, the decrease in intrathoracic pressure during inspiration expands the compliant right ventricle, resulting in a decrease in jugular venous pressure. In constrictive pericarditis, compliance of the right ventricle is decreased and the right ventricle fails to expand during inspiration. This, alongside a possible increase in baseline jugular venous pressure in constrictive pericarditis due to restricted right ventricular filling during late diastole, leads to an increase in jugular venous pressure during inspiration, and therefore, jugular venous distention on inspiration. This phenomenon, which is called Kussmaul sign, can also be seen in patients with restrictive cardiomyopathy and right atrial or ventricular tumors. Management options for constrictive pericarditis include NSAIDs, colchicine, glucocorticoids, pericardiectomy, and treatment of the underlying condition (e.g., antitubercular or immunomodulatory therapy).

In cardiac tamponade without underlying pericarditis (e.g., traumatic hemopericardium), the jugular venous pressure is increased as a result of impaired right ventricular filling. However, the right ventricle is still compliant and a decrease in intrathoracic pressure can be transmitted to the right ventricle across the fluid-filled pericardial sac. Kussmaul sign would not be expected in traumatic cardiac tamponade.

E) INCORRECT:

A crescendo-decrescendo (diamond-shaped) systolic ejection murmur best heard in the second right intercostal space is a common finding in aortic stenosis (AS). While severe, long-standing AS can result in chest pain, fatigue, dyspnea, orthopnea, and cough (due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema), fever and night sweats are not commonly seen. Finally, symptoms such as syncope, angina, and palpitations are expected in chronic AS, and x-ray would show an enlarged cardiac silhouette rather than the pericardial calcifications seen here.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.
questions.hint: New-onset dyspnea, orthopnea, and fatigue alongside pericardial thickening and calcifications on x-ray indicate constrictive pericarditis. In this patient with an immigration history from an endemic region and a prolonged history of night sweats, fever, and cough, the most likely etiology of constrictive pericarditis is tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of scleroderma reports a 6 month history of progressively worsening dyspnea. On examination, she has an accentuated P2 heart sound, a right ventricular heave, and a diastolic decrescendo murmur at the left upper sternal border that is graded 2 on a scale of 1 to 4. She has jugular venous distention to 10 cm and 1+ lower-extremity edema. Her lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Scleroderma is one of the more common connective tissue diseases to result in pulmonary arterial hypertension, in which there is increased pulmonary vascular resistance, with subsequent hypertrophy of the right ventricle. Cardiac examination findings characteristic of pulmonary arterial hypertension include an accentuated P2 heart sound (related to the forceful closure of the pulmonic valve), a right ventricular heave (related to right ventricular hypertrophy), and elevated right heart filling pressures. The diastolic murmur of pulmonic regurgitation (a so-called Graham Steell murmur) may also be audible, as in this patient.

Key learning point: An accentuated P2 heart sound, a right ventricular heave, and evidence of right heart failure are most consistent with a diagnosis of pulmonary arterial hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

A patent ductus arteriosus would produce a continuous, machinery-like murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

Eisenmenger syndrome (i.e., right-to-left intracardiac shunting, cyanosis, and polycythemia) is caused by pulmonary hypertension related to a congenital defect between the right and left heart circulations. Scleroderma does not cause Eisenmenger syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis is most often a congenital condition that produces a systolic ejection murmur along the left sternal border. The P2 component is usually soft, not accentuated.

E) INCORRECT:

Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by elevated jugular venous pressure, Kussmaul sign, and a pericardial knock. An accentuated P2 heart sound or a right ventricular heave is not characteristic of constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man who has not seen a health care provider in many years presents for follow-up after a required preemployment electrocardiogram (figure). He has no notable medical history, feels well, and does not use tobacco or alcohol. He takes no medications. His blood pressure is 190/105 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 75 beats per minute. Cardiac examination reveals a sustained apical impulse and no audible murmurs. His kidney function and serum electrolyte levels are normal. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Renal artery stenosis is a rare cause of hypertension and resultant LVH and is often associated with impaired kidney function.

B) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma that is sufficiently severe and chronic to cause LVH typically produces a range of symptoms, including headaches and palpitations.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is associated with LVH but not hypertension. In addition, patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and significant left ventricular outflow-tract obstruction often have a murmur related to this obstruction or a mitral regurgitation murmur related to systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve.

D) INCORRECT:

Although aortic stenosis can cause LVH, it does not cause hypertension and is easily identified by the presence of a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur.

E) CORRECT:

This asymptomatic patient has primary hypertension, with electrocardiographic evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH). A sustained apical impulse indicates that LVH is present. The patient’s echocardiogram would be likely to show thickened LV walls and an elevated LV mass index.

Key learning point: The cardiac examination finding of a sustained apical impulse is most consistent with a diagnosis of left ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents for management of hypertension. At his previous visit 8 weeks ago, his blood pressure was 180/95 mm Hg. He reports that he has stopped smoking and has restricted his salt intake since that visit. He is asymptomatic, with normal exercise tolerance. Today, his initial blood pressure is 166/94 mm Hg in both arms, and his heart rate is 65 beats per minute. An S4 gallop is clearly audible on cardiac auscultation. He has no cardiac murmurs, no abdominal bruits, and no other abnormal findings. His serum electrolyte levels, urinalysis, and creatinine concentration are normal. An electrocardiogram shows no left ventricular hypertrophy. In addition to initiating an antihypertensive medication, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of serum N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urine catecholamine and renal Doppler studies are tests for secondary causes of hypertension. Given that most individuals with elevated blood pressure have primary hypertension, evaluation for secondary causes of hypertension is not recommended unless there are other reasons to suspect a secondary cause. This patient has none of the features that would suggest a secondary cause of hypertension and therefore does not require an evaluation for a secondary cause of hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

In a young, asymptomatic, hypertensive person with normal exercise tolerance, echocardiography is not indicated. Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction would be very unlikely. Although the echocardiogram might demonstrate left ventricular hypertrophy or heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (diastolic dysfunction), those findings would not change the management of this case.

C) INCORRECT:

A serum N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide concentration, whether normal or abnormal, has limited diagnostic value in an asymptomatic patient and would not alter the management approach.

D) INCORRECT:

Urine catecholamine and renal Doppler studies are tests for secondary causes of hypertension. Given that most individuals with elevated blood pressure have primary hypertension, evaluation for secondary causes of hypertension is not recommended unless there are other reasons to suspect a secondary cause. This patient has none of the features that would suggest a secondary cause of hypertension and therefore does not require an evaluation for a secondary cause of hypertension.

E) CORRECT:

An S4 gallop is a common finding in patients with hypertension, resulting from forceful left atrial contraction and movement of blood into a hypertrophied left ventricle. Unlike an S3 gallop, an S4 gallop does not indicate ventricular systolic failure. An S4 gallop does not warrant further evaluation, but aggressive treatment of hypertension is indicated to prevent progression of end-organ effects.

Given that most individuals with elevated blood pressure have primary hypertension, evaluation for secondary causes of hypertension is not recommended unless there are other reasons to suspect a secondary cause. Indications to initiate evaluation for secondary causes of hypertension include symptoms, historical features, or physical examination findings that suggest a specific secondary cause of hypertension or one of the following criteria:

• Onset of hypertension before age 30
• Drug-resistant hypertension
• Abrupt onset of hypertension
• Exacerbation of previously controlled hypertension
• Disproportionate target-organ damage for the degree of hypertension
• Accelerated or malignant hypertension
• Onset of diastolic hypertension in adults age 65 years or older
• Unprovoked or excessive hypokalemia

This patient has none of these features and therefore does not require an evaluation for a secondary cause of hypertension.

Key learning point: An S4 gallop is the most common physical finding on cardiac auscultation in patients with hypertension and does not warrant further evaluation.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the office for a well-child examination. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He is at 70th percentile for height and 55th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a harsh, holosystolic murmur over the left lower sternal border. When he clenches his fist forcefully for a sustained time, the intensity of the murmur increases. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patent ductus arteriosus leads to a murmur heard best at the left infraclavicular region. This murmur occurs during both diastole and systole (i.e., a continuous murmur), unlike the harsh holosystolic murmur seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can cause a murmur as a result of mitral regurgitation (MR) or left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. A murmur due to MR is holosystolic and increases in intensity with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload (e.g., handgrip) but is heard best at the cardiac apex (5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line). A murmur due to LVOT obstruction is heard best at the left lower sternal border but has a midsystolic, crescendo-decrescendo character and decreases in intensity with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload.

C) CORRECT:

A ventricular septal defect (VSD), which causes a left-to-right shunt, leads to a harsh holosystolic murmur because of turbulent blood flow across the defect. The murmur is heard best at the left lower sternal border (tricuspid area) and becomes louder with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload (e.g., handgrip) because of increased left-to-right shunting. The murmur is typically louder with smaller defects because of the large pressure difference between the left and right ventricles.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse leads to a systolic murmur that increases in intensity with maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., handgrip), which is seen here. However, this murmur is heard best at the cardiac apex (5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line). In addition, this murmur has a late systolic crescendo character, and it is preceded by a click due to tensing of the chordae tendinae.

E) INCORRECT:

An atrial septal defect can cause a systolic murmur because of increased flow across the pulmonary valve, but the murmur is heard best at the left upper sternal border. In addition, this murmur has a midsystolic crescendo-decrescendo character, and it is accompanied by a wide, fixed split second heart sound.
questions.hint: The handgrip maneuver increases afterload by increasing total peripheral resistance.

questions.text: A 3-month-old boy is brought to the office for a routine follow-up examination. He was delivered at 32 weeks' gestation to a 35-year-old woman. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a grade 4/6 continuous murmur heard best in the left infraclavicular region. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) manifests with a continuous machinery murmur best heard in the left infraclavicular area. The machinery murmur is generated as blood continuously shunts from the high-pressure aorta through the ductus arteriosus into the low-pressure pulmonary artery. It may envelop the S2 and is not usually affected by positional changes. Patients with moderate-sized PDAs may present with bounding pulses, widened pulse pressure, and symptoms of heart failure.

Key learning point: A continuous, machinery-like murmur best heard at the left infraclavicular area is characteristic of a patent ductus arteriosus, commonly seen in premature infants.
Image Description:

Continuous systolic and diastolic heart murmur (machinery murmur)

B) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal defects (VSD) manifest with holosystolic, harsh sounding murmurs, best heard in the left lower sternal border. These murmurs often obliterate the S2 and are associated with a palpable thrill. Neonates present with an asymptomatic heart murmur or, in cases of moderate-to-large sized defects, with signs of heart failure. The examination findings in this patient reveal a continuous murmur, which is not suggestive of a VSD.

C) INCORRECT:

Atrial septal defects (ASD) manifest with pulmonary outflow tract murmurs heard best at the left upper sternal border and are often associated with fixed splitting of S2. ASDs are often low-velocity shunts that produce insufficient flow to be audible. Larger shunts may cause diastolic flow murmurs across the tricuspid valve owing to a large left-to-right shunt. However, a continuous murmur would not be seen in patients with an ASD.

D) INCORRECT:

Persistent truncus arteriosus results in a single conduit providing mixed venous and arterial blood to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic circulations. Cardiac examination findings would include a single loud S2, the presence of an ejection click at the cardiac apex or left sternal border, and harsh systolic murmurs at the left sternal border, unlike the continuous murmur heard in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is associated with a harsh crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard along the left mid- to upper-sternal border. The murmur can decrease in intensity as the degree of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction worsens because of increased right-to-left shunting of blood. The examination findings of a continuous murmur would not be seen in patients with TOF.
questions.hint: This patient's condition typically affects premature infants or infants with a congenital rubella infection.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the office because of a 6-month history of worsening shortness of breath. Initially, his breathlessness developed after climbing one flight of stairs but now appears when he walks from one room to the next. He drinks six glasses of whisky daily and has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years. His blood pressure is 115/90 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a dull, low-pitched early diastolic sound at the cardiac apex. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's auscultation findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Constrictive pericarditis can manifest with chronic, progressively worsening dyspnea but this condition is associated with a pericardial knock, rather than an S3 heart sound. Although a pericardial knock occurs during diastole, it is a high-frequency sound and is best heard at the left sternal border rather than the cardiac apex.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) may manifest with chronic, progressively worsening dyspnea and abnormal cardiac auscultation findings that are loudest at the cardiac apex. However, MVP is associated with a high-frequency midsystolic click and a late systolic crescendo murmur. This patient has no murmur and has a low-frequency diastolic heart sound.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

C) CORRECT:

The S3 heart sound results from a sudden deceleration of blood flow from the atrium into the ventricle during the rapid ventricular filling phase. An S3 originating from the left ventricle is best heard at the cardiac apex and in the left lateral position. An S3 gallop can be a normal variant in young, healthy individuals and during pregnancy but its presence in older patients usually indicates an underlying abnormality such as hyperdynamic circulation, ventricular volume overload (e.g., due to valvular regurgitation), or systolic dysfunction (e.g., due to dilated cardiomyopathy). Given this patient's heavy alcohol use, left ventricular failure due to alcohol-induced cardiomyopathy is a likely cause of the S3 heart sound.
Image Description:

I–IV: anatomical locations of heart valves

1. Aortic area: 2nd right parasternal intercostal space (ICS)
- Ideal site for auscultation of aortic valve murmurs (1a). The murmur of aortic stenosis also radiates to the carotid arteries (1b).

2. Pulmonary area: 2nd left parasternal ICS
- Ideal site for auscultation of pulmonary valve murmurs

3. Tricuspid area: 4th left parasternal ICS
- Ideal site for auscultation of tricuspid valve murmurs

4. Mitral area: 5th left ICS in the midclavicular line (over the cardiac apex)
- Ideal site for auscultation of mitral valve murmurs (4a). The murmur of mitral regurgitation also radiates to the left axilla (4b).

D) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis due to severe aortic valve sclerosis can manifest with chronic, progressively worsening dyspnea but auscultation would likely disclose a mid-systolic ejection murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border. Moreover, left ventricular hypertrophy due to aortic stenosis is typically associated with an S4 heart sound. An S4 is a low-frequency sound and would be best heard at the cardiac apex if it originates from the left ventricle but it is heard immediately before S1 (i.e., during late diastole).
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

E) INCORRECT:

Depending on the underlying etiology (e.g., cor pulmonale), right ventricular hypertrophy may be associated with chronic, progressively worsening dyspnea. However, ventricular hypertrophy is typically associated with an S4 gallop, which is a low-frequency sound but is heard immediately before S1 (i.e., during late diastole). Moreover, abnormal heart sounds that originate from the right ventricle are best heard at the left lower sternal border.
questions.hint: The heart sound heard immediately after S2 (i.e., during early diastole) is the S3 heart sound. S3 gallops follow the cadence of the word Kentucky (Ken: S1, Tuc-ky: S2, S3). A low-frequency sound such as S3 is best heard with the stethoscope bell or the diaphragm in light contact with the skin. This patient's S3 is best heard at the cardiac apex.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to the office because of a 3-week history of shortness of breath with exertion. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include aspirin, losartan, and simvastatin. His blood pressure is 150/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Auscultation of the heart shows an S3 gallop. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Elevated serum brain natriuretic peptide levels
Left-to-right shunt through the atrial septum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Calcification of the aortic valve is the most common cause of aortic stenosis (AS). The resulting left ventricular outflow tract obstruction causes left ventricular hypertrophy, which manifests with an S4 gallop, not an S3 gallop. Moreover, the murmur that is characteristic of aortic stenosis is a systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard loudest at the upper right sternal border, which this patient does not have.

B) CORRECT:

Elevated levels of brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) and the presence of an S3 gallop both indicate increased ventricular filling pressures, which is seen in heart failure (HF). BNP, which is released in response to stretching of the cardiac ventricle, is a sensitive parameter to evaluate patients with symptoms of HF. High levels of BNP (> 400 pg/mL) in patients with classic symptoms of HF have a high positive predictive value and are associated with a worse prognosis, while low values (< 100 pg/mL) in patients with dyspnea have a high negative predictive value for HF.

C) INCORRECT:

Digital clubbing is primarily seen in patients with pulmonary diseases that result in chronic hypoxemia, such as cystic fibrosis, bronchiectasis, interstitial lung disease, and non-small cell lung cancer. It may also be seen in cyanotic heart disease and infectious endocarditis, which are unlikely diagnoses in a 66-year-old afebrile patient. As clubbing is a nonspecific physical finding, it is unlikely to help pinpoint the diagnosis. While shortness of breath can be of pulmonary origin, this patient's S3 gallop on examination is more concerning for a cardiac cause.

D) INCORRECT:

A left-to-right shunt through the atrial septum is the pathophysiologic mechanism of an atrial septal defect (ASD). Auscultatory findings in ASD include a systolic ejection murmur over the left upper sternal border (due to increased blood flow across the pulmonary valve), a diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border (due to increased blood flow across the tricuspid valve), and a fixed, widely split S2, none of which are seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Rupture of a papillary muscle would result in acute mitral regurgitation (MR), a complication associated with myocardial infarction (MI). While this patient has several risk factors for MI, including hypertension and hyperlipidemia, he has no symptoms of chest pain or signs to suggest ongoing acute coronary syndrome. Additionally, this patient lacks the characteristic holosystolic, blowing murmur of MR, which is best heard in the apex.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents with progressive shortness of breath on exertion and lower-leg edema for 6 months. He has a remote history of tuberculosis. Examination shows elevated jugular venous pressure that rises during inspiration and distant heart sounds without pulsus paradoxus (see report).
Chest X-ray: Thickening around the cardiac silhouette
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cardiac tamponade involves impaired ventricular filling due to pericardial fluid accumulation, often presenting with pulsus paradoxus. The absence of pulsus paradoxus and the chronic nature of symptoms suggest a chronic pericardial process. Imaging shows pericardial thickening, not the effusion typical of tamponade.

B) CORRECT:

Constrictive pericarditis manifests with pericardial thickening and fibrosis, leading to restricted diastolic filling of the ventricles. This condition results in elevated and nearly equalized diastolic pressures in the heart chambers, causing systemic venous congestion, such as lower extremity edema and elevated jugular venous pressure that rises with inspiration. A history of tuberculosis is significant, as it can cause granulomatous inflammation leading to chronic pericardial scarring. Chest X-ray findings of pericardial thickening support the diagnosis by visualizing structural changes that impair ventricular filling.

Key learning point: Kussmaul's sign (elevated JVP that rises on inspiration) and a history of tuberculosis are indicative of constrictive pericarditis, a condition where the pericardium becomes thickened and calcified, impairing cardiac filling.

C) INCORRECT:

Cor pulmonale results from right ventricular dysfunction due to pulmonary hypertension, often linked to chronic lung disease. While symptoms may overlap, distant heart sounds and pericardial thickening on imaging suggest pericardial disease. Tuberculosis history aligns with pericardial involvement, not cor pulmonale.

D) INCORRECT:

Restrictive cardiomyopathy presents with diastolic dysfunction, similar to constrictive pericarditis. However, the chest X-ray showing pericardial thickening suggests a pericardial rather than myocardial process. Tuberculosis history and distant heart sounds further indicate pericardial involvement, not typical of restrictive cardiomyopathy.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy with normal development is found to have a new heart murmur during a routine checkup. He is active, without respiratory distress or cyanosis. Cardiac examination reveals a low-pitched, vibratory murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border. The murmur becomes louder when he is lying down and softer when standing. Pulses are normal, and the rest of his examination is normal.
Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy presents with a dynamic, crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur that intensifies with standing or the Valsalva maneuver. The described murmur is low-pitched and vibratory, increasing when supine and decreasing when standing, inconsistent with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy. The absence of symptoms like exercise intolerance or syncope further reduces the likelihood of this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal defects typically present with a harsh, holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border, often with palpable thrills or signs of volume overload. The described murmur is low-pitched and vibratory, with positional intensity changes, aligning more with a benign murmur. Additionally, significant ventricular septal defects often cause symptoms like respiratory distress or failure to thrive, which are absent here.

C) INCORRECT:

Atrial septal defects often produce a systolic ejection murmur with fixed splitting of the second heart sound. The described murmur is low-pitched and vibratory, localized to the lower left sternal border, and varies with position, which is atypical for an atrial septal defect. These features suggest a benign murmur rather than an atrial septal defect.

D) CORRECT:

The heart murmur described is characteristic of a Still murmur, a common benign murmur in children. It is low-pitched and vibratory, best heard at the lower left sternal border. The murmur's intensity increases when the child is supine and decreases when standing, reflecting changes in venous return. The absence of symptoms such as cyanosis, respiratory distress, or abnormal pulses supports a non-pathologic origin, distinguishing it from structural heart abnormalities.

Key learning point: A Still murmur is a common innocent murmur in children, characterized by a vibratory or musical quality, heard best at the lower left sternal border, and accentuated in the supine position.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents with progressive fatigue and mild exertional dyspnea for the past month. He has no significant medical history. Auscultation reveals a high-pitched, blowing diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border when sitting up and leaning forward. The remainder of the examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reassurance and routine follow-up in six months

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A high-pitched, blowing diastolic murmur is pathologic and suggests valvular disease, such as aortic regurgitation. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) is the first-line, noninvasive imaging modality for evaluating cardiac structure and function. It provides detailed assessment of valve morphology, regurgitant flow, chamber dimensions, and left ventricular function. TTE uses two-dimensional imaging with Doppler techniques to quantify regurgitant volumes and effective orifice areas, guiding management decisions. In an older patient with exertional symptoms, TTE is crucial for identifying structural or functional cardiac abnormalities.

Key learning point: Diastolic murmurs often indicate significant valvular pathology and warrant further evaluation with transthoracic echocardiography to assess cardiac structure and function.

B) INCORRECT:

Diastolic murmurs are typically pathological and require evaluation. The patient's high-pitched, blowing diastolic murmur and symptoms of fatigue and exertional dyspnea suggest a regurgitant valvular lesion, such as aortic regurgitation. Delaying evaluation risks progression of cardiac compromise, making reassurance and routine follow-up inappropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) offers high-resolution images but is typically reserved for detailed valve assessment or when transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) is inconclusive. The patient's diastolic murmur suggests a valvular issue that TTE can effectively evaluate. TEE is not immediately necessary without specific indications such as suspected endocarditis or suboptimal TTE images.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) assesses heart failure by indicating myocardial stretch and volume overload. However, the patient's diastolic murmur suggests a valvular lesion, not nonspecific heart failure. BNP does not provide anatomical or severity details of regurgitation, making it less useful for evaluating the suspected valvular pathology.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother for a routine check-up. He appears healthy with normal growth parameters. Cardiac examination reveals a continuous, low-pitched murmur in the right supraclavicular area, most prominent when upright and disappearing when lying down. He denies chest pain or dyspnea. Extremity pulses are normal, and there is no clubbing or cyanosis.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Reassure that no further workup is needed

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chest radiographs are useful for evaluating structural heart or vascular abnormalities. However, the positional nature of the murmur, which is prominent when upright and disappears when supine, suggests a benign venous hum rather than a fixed structural anomaly. The absence of symptoms or abnormal findings further reduces the likelihood of a significant cardiac lesion.

B) INCORRECT:

A transthoracic echocardiogram is used to evaluate structural heart anomalies. However, the murmur's characteristics—continuous, low-pitched, positional, and disappearing when supine—are typical of a venous hum, not a pathologic lesion like a patent ductus arteriosus, which would present with additional findings such as bounding pulses.

C) INCORRECT:

The murmur's features—low-pitched, continuous, positional, and in the right supraclavicular area—are consistent with a benign venous hum. The child is asymptomatic with normal growth and no abnormal findings, reducing the suspicion for congenital heart defects. Immediate referral to pediatric cardiology is not warranted.

D) CORRECT:

The continuous, low-pitched murmur in the right supraclavicular area, which is positional and disappears when supine, is characteristic of an innocent venous hum. The absence of symptoms, normal growth, and normal physical examination findings, including normal pulses and no cyanosis or clubbing, support a benign etiology. In pediatric patients, many murmurs are benign, and further workup is reserved for those with concerning features or abnormal findings.

Key learning point: A continuous murmur that disappears when supine in a child is likely a venous hum, which is an innocent murmur and does not require further investigation or intervention.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the Outpatient Clinic for a routine well-child visit. He has normal growth parameters and meets developmental milestones. His parents report no symptoms of chest pain, shortness of breath, or exercise intolerance. On cardiac auscultation, there is a short, high-pitched, crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the mid-sternal border, which decreases in intensity with standing. The remainder of the physical examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Reassure the parents that no additional evaluation is necessary
Refer to a pediatric cardiologist for further evaluation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The murmur is a benign systolic flow murmur, common in children. It is characterized by a short, high-pitched crescendo-decrescendo quality, best heard at the mid-sternal border, and decreases in intensity with standing. These features, along with the child's normal growth, development, and absence of symptoms, indicate a physiologic process. Innocent murmurs are associated with normal cardiac structures and hemodynamic changes during maneuvers like standing, which reduce blood flow velocity and murmur intensity. No further diagnostic testing or referral is needed.

Key learning point: In children, a high-pitched, crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard best at the midsternal border is most likely a systolic ejection murmur, which can be innocent or physiologic.

B) INCORRECT:

The murmur's characteristics and the child's asymptomatic status suggest a benign etiology. Innocent murmurs are short, vibratory, and decrease with maneuvers reducing left ventricular filling. The absence of symptoms or signs of structural heart disease makes echocardiography unnecessary.

C) INCORRECT:

The murmur's features and the child's normal development and lack of symptoms indicate an innocent murmur, such as Still’s murmur. Pathological murmurs are typically accompanied by symptoms or abnormal findings, which are absent here, making cardiology referral unnecessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Innocent murmurs occur in structurally normal hearts and do not increase the risk of infective endocarditis. Antibiotic prophylaxis is reserved for patients with specific high-risk cardiac conditions, which this child does not have.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with persistent nasal congestion, dry cough, and low-grade fever for three days. He has no significant past medical history, and his routine physical examinations have consistently noted a normal cardiovascular exam. On auscultation, a soft, grade 2/6 crescendo-decrescendo murmur is heard along the left upper sternal border when he is seated. Lung fields are clear. No jugular venous distension or peripheral edema is observed.


Heart rate
98/min


Blood pressure
106/68 mmHg


Respiratory rate
16/min


Temperature
38.0°C


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Advise routine follow-up after symptoms resolve and recheck the murmur
Begin intravenous antibiotic therapy for possible endocarditis
Refer to a pediatric cardiologist for urgent evaluation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Benign heart murmurs in children are typically low-grade, soft, and isolated without signs of structural heart disease. The described grade 2/6 crescendo-decrescendo murmur along the left upper sternal border, in the context of recent upper respiratory symptoms and no abnormal cardiovascular findings, suggests an innocent murmur. These murmurs, such as Still’s murmur, are often transient and vary with position or activity. Monitoring with routine follow-up after the acute illness resolves, and reassessing the murmur, is appropriate to confirm its benign nature.

Key learning point: In the context of an acute illness, a newly detected heart murmur in a child with previously normal cardiac exams is likely functional and should be re-evaluated after the illness resolves.

B) INCORRECT:

Endocarditis is associated with high-grade fever, systemic emboli, and vascular phenomena, often in patients with predisposing factors. This child has a benign murmur and symptoms of a viral infection, not endocarditis, making antibiotics inappropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Urgent referral is for pathological murmurs with high intensity, diastolic components, or cardiac dysfunction. The child's soft, grade 2/6 murmur and normal cardiovascular exam suggest an innocent murmur, not requiring urgent cardiology evaluation.

D) INCORRECT:

A transthoracic echocardiogram is reserved for diastolic, high-grade, or concerning murmurs. The soft, grade 2/6 murmur in this child, without signs of structural heart disease or hemodynamic compromise, suggests an innocent murmur, not warranting immediate echocardiography.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to your clinic for a well-child examination. She has no history of serious illness. Her temperature is 37°C, pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 96/52 mm Hg. On examination, you hear a 2/6 continuous, low-pitched murmur over the left upper sternal border that radiates toward the neck. The murmur disappears when she flexes her neck. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Coarctation of the aorta can also manifest with a continuous murmur. However, it is typically not only heard below the left clavicula but also in between the shoulder blades. Additional findings are also common, such as a systolic ejection murmur over the left paravertebral region, increased blood pressure in the upper extremities, cold feet, or claudication of the lower extremity, none of which are present in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis can also be asymptomatic. However, the condition typically manifests with a systolic murmur that has a point of maximal intensity over the second left intercostal space at the sternal border.

C) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis may remain asymptomatic for years. However, cardiac examination typically reveals a harsh crescendo-decrescendo (diamond-shaped), late systolic ejection murmur that radiates to the carotids bilaterally and that is heard best in the second intercostal space on the right. The murmur is typically decreased by hand grip rather than by flexing the head.

D) INCORRECT:

A patent ductus arteriosus commonly manifests in asymptomatic patients with a loud continuous murmur (machinery murmur) that is best heard at the left infraclavicular region but does not typically disappear on flexion of the head.

E) CORRECT:

A venous hum is a common benign finding on auscultation in childhood. The murmur is most likely caused by turbulence in the internal jugular vein (e.g., when blood enters the thoracic inlet). Although typically a continuous murmur that can occur on either side of the neck, it tends to be louder during diastole and is more common on the right. The murmur disappears or becomes softer on compression of the internal jugular vein, lying in the supine position, or flexion of the head, as seen here. This feature helps differentiate it from the murmur in a patent ductus arteriosus.

Key learning point: A venous hum is a benign, continuous murmur in children that disappears with neck flexion or jugular vein compression and is due to turbulent flow in the internal jugular vein.
questions.hint: This condition is caused by the high-velocity flow of blood through blood vessels.

questions.text: You are seeing a 4-year-old girl in your clinic for a well-child examination. She has been healthy except for an episode of bronchiolitis during infancy. Her 6-year-old sister recently had surgery to close a ventricular septal defect. The patient is at the 60th percentile for both height and weight. Her mother is concerned about the possibility of a cardiovascular anomaly. Which one of the following is most likely to indicate a benign heart murmur in this child?

choices.text: A grade 2/6 continuous murmur heard at the right supraclavicular region.
A grade 2/6 machine-like murmur heard at the upper left sternal border.
A grade 4/6 midsystolic murmur at the right upper sternal border that increases on rapid squatting.
A grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur heard along the left lower sternal border that increases on valsalva.
A grade 4/6 holosystolic murmur heard along the left lower sternal border that increases on hand grip.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A grade 2/6 continuous murmur heard at the right supraclavicular region is called a central venous hum. It is a benign finding that is common in children and results from turbulent flow in the internal jugular veins. The murmur disappears or gets softer when pressure is applied to the ipsilateral jugular vein, when the head is flexed, or in the supine position.

Key learning point: A central venous hum is a benign, continuous, low-grade murmur in children, typically heard at the right supraclavicular region and caused by turbulent flow in the internal jugular veins.

B) INCORRECT:

A grade 2/6 machine-like murmur heard at the upper left sternal border should raise suspicion of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). This is not considered a benign murmur, as patients with PDA are at increased risk of heart failure in infancy and pulmonary hypertension in adolescence and adulthood.

C) INCORRECT:

A grade 4/6 midsystolic ejection murmur at the right upper sternal border that increases on rapid squatting indicates aortic stenosis. Aortic stenosis does not represent a benign heart murmur.

D) INCORRECT:

A grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur heard along the left lower sternal border that increases with the Valsalva maneuver indicates hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. This is a pathological murmur and must be investigated promptly because it carries a significant risk of sudden death. The Valsalva maneuver increases the intensity of this murmur by decreasing preload. As a result, the pathological systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve (which is the underlying cause of the outflow obstruction in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy) intensifies, enhancing the murmur.

E) INCORRECT:

A grade 4/6 holosystolic murmur heard along the left lower sternal border that increases on handgrip indicates a ventricular septal defect (VSD). Holosystolic murmurs are nearly always pathological. The handgrip exercise serves to increase afterload in the systemic circulation. As a result, blood flow through the aortic valve is reduced, leading to increased blood flow through the VSD that is detectable as a more intense murmur.
questions.hint: A central venous hum is considered a benign finding in children.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a one-month history of shortness of breath when lying on her back. She has also experienced several episodes of coughing up blood during this time. She reports a history of a heart problem in childhood that was treated with antibiotics. She emigrated from Russia 5 years ago. There is no family history of serious illness. On pulmonary examination, you hear crackles at both lung bases. Cardiac examination is provided. An ECG shows tachycardia and absence of P waves. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation may cause signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles). However, it manifests as a holosystolic murmur (i.e., audible between S1 and S2) best heard at the apex of the fifth left intercostal space, in contrast to this patient's diastolic murmur (audible after S2).

B) INCORRECT:

Although severe aortic valve stenosis may eventually cause signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles), patients would most likely first present with syncope or angina. Furthermore, aortic stenosis causes a harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the second right intercostal space, which can radiate to the carotids.

C) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse is the most common valvular abnormality in developed countries and is often caused by rheumatic fever. However, it is usually asymptomatic and is best heard at the fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line as a high-frequency mid-to-late systolic murmur with a mid-systolic click.

D) INCORRECT:

Although aortic regurgitation may lead to signs of pulmonary edema (orthopnea, hemoptysis, crackles), it causes a diastolic decrescendo murmur heard best parasternally at the second intercostal space, and may sometimes be accompanied by an Austin Flint murmur.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's diastolic murmur (audible after S2) at the fifth left intercostal space and opening snap indicate mitral valve stenosis, which causes an increase in left atrial pressure (and increased pulmonary wedge pressure) and a backup of blood into the lungs. Volume overload eventually causes symptoms of cardiogenic pulmonary edema, which explains this patient's orthopnea, hemoptysis, and crackles. The absence of P waves confirms atrial fibrillation, a common complication of mitral stenosis. This patient most likely suffered from rheumatic fever, the most common cause of mitral stenosis.

Key learning point: Mitral valve stenosis, often due to rheumatic fever, presents with a diastolic murmur, atrial fibrillation, and symptoms of pulmonary congestion such as orthopnea, hemoptysis, and crackles.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.
questions.hint: This patient's heart problem is consistent with a history of rheumatic fever. An x-ray of the chest in this patient would likely show left atrial enlargement as a result of this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to your clinic for evaluation of progressive fatigue over the past month. He reports that he is unable to climb more than one flight of stairs without experiencing shortness of breath and dizziness. His medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Pulse is 70/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/80 mm Hg. On examination, he has weak peripheral pulses. Cardiac examination shows a harsh crescendo-decrescendo, systolic ejection murmur that is best heard at the 2nd right intercostal space and radiates to the carotids. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's auscultation findings are consistent with aortic stenosis, which causes left ventricular outflow obstruction. The result is dizziness and exacerbation of dyspnea upon exertion, and weak peripheral pulses (pulsus parvus et tardus). Incomplete left ventricular emptying may also cause pulmonary venous congestion, which further exacerbates dyspnea.

Key learning point: Aortic stenosis typically presents with exertional dyspnea, dizziness, and weak peripheral pulses due to left ventricular outflow obstruction and is characterized by a systolic murmur radiating to the carotids.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

B) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) is extremely rare and in severe cases manifests with abdominal discomfort (due to hepatomegaly) and other features of right-sided heart failure, which are not present here. In addition, the murmur of TR is holosystolic and heard best in the parasternal region of the left 4th ICS.

C) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis (MS) leads to pulmonary venous congestion, which, in turn, causes dyspnea, as seen here. However, auscultation in MS shows a middiastolic murmur heard best at the midclavicular left 5th ICS (the apex) and is often preceded by an opening snap.

D) INCORRECT:

Severe aortic regurgitation (AR) can manifest with dizziness and exertional dyspnea, as seen here. However, patients with AR typically present with high pulse pressure, a water hammer pulse, and a high-pitched early diastolic murmur heard best at the left 3rd ICS that does not radiate to the carotid arteries.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) leads to pulmonary venous congestion, which, in turn, causes dyspnea, as seen in this patient. However, patients with MR typically present with normal peripheral pulses and a holosystolic high-pitched murmur heard best at the left midclavicular line of the 5th ICS that radiates to the left axilla.
questions.hint: A harsh crescendo-decrescendo, systolic ejection murmur that is best heard at the 2nd right intercostal space (ICS) and radiates to the carotids is suggestive of the most common valvular heart disease in industrialized countries.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of palpitations. He reports feeling his heartbeat constantly in his chest. Over the past 3 weeks, he has developed shortness of breath on exertion. He denies chest pain, orthopnea, or nocturnal dyspnea. He emigrated from Nepal at age 25. He does not take any medications. His temperature is 36.5°C, pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 145/56 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a blowing, decrescendo murmur that is best heard at the left sternal border. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The characteristic triad of symptomatic aortic stenosis (AS) is exertional dyspnea, stable angina, and exertional dizziness/syncope caused by left ventricular outflow obstruction. AS causes weak peripheral pulses (pulsus parvus et tardus) and low/narrow pulse pressure, in contrast to this patient's findings. Moreover, the characteristic murmur of AS is a harsh crescendo-decrescendo late systolic ejection murmur heard best over the right 2nd intercostal space that radiates to the carotids.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis (MS) can manifest with dyspnea (due to pulmonary venous congestion) and palpitations if atrial fibrillation develops. Although the murmur that is characteristic of MS also occurs during diastole, it is most often a mid-diastolic decrescendo murmur preceded by an opening snap and is heard best at the cardiac apex. This patient has an early diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border that is associated with a widened pulse pressure, and his lungs are clear to auscultation, making another diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation (MR) can manifest with dyspnea (due to pulmonary venous congestion) and palpitations in the setting of atrial fibrillation. Although this patient presents with both dyspnea and palpitations, he lacks the characteristic holosystolic murmur of MR (best heard at the cardiac apex; left 5th intercostal space). In contrast, this patient has a diastolic murmur. Furthermore, his lungs are clear to auscultation, which makes pulmonary venous congestion unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) is a rare valvular abnormality that is usually asymptomatic. Right-sided valvular heart diseases are more common in individuals with a history of IV drug use, which this patient does not have. Chronic and/or severe TR manifests with features of right-sided heart failure but usually not with dyspnea or palpitations. Furthermore, TR causes a holosystolic murmur heard best at the 4th intercostal space of the left sternal border rather than a diastolic murmur.

E) CORRECT:

The patient has a diastolic murmur, which shortens the list of differentials here to mitral stenosis (MS), aortic regurgitation (AR), tricuspid stenosis (TS), and pulmonary regurgitation (PR). Let's have a look at the location of the murmur: it is best heard at the left sternal border near Erb point (cardiology). This location makes MS unlikely (usually best heard at the apex) but is consistent with a murmur caused by AR due to valvular disease. Now, here comes the tricky part. In this patient, TS and PR cannot be excluded by cardiac auscultation because the left sternal border is also the location at which murmurs due to TS and PR are best heard. However, subtle details make AR more likely. PR can occur in patients with pulmonary hypertension due to lung disease (cor pulmonale) or chronic congestive heart failure, but this patient has no clinical features to suggest either of these etiologies.
