Isolated TS or PR are extremely rare (usually caused by endocarditis in intravenous drug users, or by congenital heart defects), and manifest with features of right heart failure, which are not seen here. This patient's history of emigration from Nepal increases the likelihood that the underlying etiology of valvular heart disease is rheumatic heart disease, which most commonly affects the mitral and aortic valves. In patients with AR, a widened pulse pressure (due to increased end-diastolic volume and a subsequent increase in stroke volume) is a common finding.

Other common causes of AR include a congenital bicuspid aortic valve (most common cause of AR in high-income countries) and aortic root dilation due to connective tissue disorders (e.g., Marfan syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome). In contrast to AR due to valvular disease, the murmur of AR secondary to aortic root diseases is heard best over the right upper sternal border.

Key learning point: Aortic regurgitation due to valvular disease manifests with a diastolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border (Erb point).
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man who recently immigrated from Indonesia comes to your clinic with worsening shortness of breath and swollen extremities for the past 3 months. He reports a 4-kg weight loss and intermittent fevers over the last 6 months. On examination, he has pitting pedal edema and abdominal distension. Applying pressure over the right upper quadrant of the abdomen results in persistent distention of the jugular veins. A chest x-ray shows cavernous infiltrates in the left and right upper lobes and a calcified cardiac silhouette. Which one of the following is most likely to be found on cardiovascular examination?

choices.text: Absent jugular venous pulse y descent.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In acute pericarditis, inflammation of the pericardial layers can cause friction as they move during the cardiac cycle, creating an audible friction rub on cardiac auscultation. While a friction rub is characteristic of the acute phase of pericarditis, a different heart sound is pathognomonic for chronic constrictive pericarditis, in which the ventricles are working against a calcified and thickened pericardium.

B) INCORRECT:

A fourth heart sound (S4) is caused by a late diastolic contraction of the atria and is seen in restrictive cardiomyopathy, left ventricular hypertrophy, and ischemic heart disease. Restrictive cardiomyopathy is an important differential diagnosis of constrictive pericarditis because it can manifest similarly. However, it does not cause calcification of the cardiac silhouette. An S4 is not a physical exam finding of constrictive pericarditis, most likely because the rigid pericardial sac impairs atrial contraction.

C) INCORRECT:

The y descent of the jugular venous pulse waveform corresponds to the emptying of the right atrium following the opening of the tricuspid valve. Absent y descent would indicate resistance to all phases of diastolic filling, which is seen in cardiac tamponade. In constrictive pericarditis, the early phase of diastolic filling is unchanged, but the mid-late phase is met with resistance. This, coupled with the high jugular venous distention of chronic venous congestion, produces a prominent y descent that is accentuated in the early phase as filling drops rapidly from a higher peak pressure.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulsus parvus et tardus is characteristic of the prolonged left ventricular total ejection time seen in aortic stenosis (AS). AS would cause signs and symptoms of left heart failure, but not the symptoms of right heart failure seen in this patient. Furthermore, calcification in AS is limited to the aortic valve and does not involve the entire cardiac silhouette, as seen here.

E) CORRECT:

A pericardial knock is a high-pitched, early-diastolic sound that sounds like a premature S3. A pericardial knock is often heard on auscultation in constrictive pericarditis due to the abrupt halting of diastolic ventricular relaxation and filling by the rigid pericardial sac. In constrictive pericarditis, reduced ventricular filling leads to manifestations of reduced cardiac output (forward failure), such as fatigue and/or dyspnea, as well as those of fluid overload (backward failure), such as jugular venous distention, positive Kussmaul sign, hepatomegaly, and the clinical features seen in this patient.

While tuberculosis is the most likely underlying cause of constrictive pericarditis in this patient, other etiologies include prior cardiac surgery, radiation therapy to the chest, viral infection, and connective tissue diseases.

Key learning point: A high-pitched early diastolic pericardial knock is a classic auscultatory finding in constrictive pericarditis due to abrupt cessation of ventricular filling by a rigid pericardium.
questions.hint: This patient's history of immigration from an endemic region, his clinical presentation of fever and weight loss, as well as the cavernous lesions seen on x-ray indicate tuberculosis. His dyspnea, pitting edema, abdominal distention, and positive hepatojugular reflux in the context of a calcified cardiac silhouette suggest constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to your clinic for a routine health maintenance examination. He reports feeling well. His medical history includes hypertension and hypercholesterolemia, both managed with atenolol, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. He is 175 cm tall and weighs 90 kg; BMI is 29. His temperature is 37.2°C, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 145/95 mm Hg. Cardiac auscultation with the bell of the stethoscope reveals an isolated late diastolic sound in the mitral area when the patient is lying in a left lateral position. Auscultation with the diaphragm of the stethoscope reveals no abnormal heart sounds. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's auscultation finding?

choices.text: Thickening of the mitral valve leaflets.
Decreased compliance of the left ventricle.
Impaired closure of the mitral valve.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thickening of the mitral leaflet is seen in mitral stenosis and is the cause of the opening snap, which is an early diastolic sound that is best heard at the apex in the left lateral decubitus position. However, the opening snap is a high-pitched sound, unlike the low-pitched sound heard here, and it would be accompanied by the late-diastolic, decrescendo murmur of mitral stenosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Dilation of the aortic root, which is caused by age-related degenerative changes, hypertension, aortitis (e.g., tertiary syphilis), or connective tissue disease (e.g., Marfan syndrome), causes chronic aortic insufficiency (AI). AI can result in a low-pitched, mid or late diastolic sound that is best heard at the cardiac apex due to vibration of the ventricular wall by the regurgitant jet. However, a patient with AI would also have an early diastolic murmur best heard in the right upper sternal border. An isolated low-pitched, late diastolic sound on cardiac examination suggests another cause.

C) CORRECT:

Decreased compliance of the left ventricle is most likely due to left ventricular hypertrophy caused by long-standing hypertension and often manifests with an S4 gallop, which is due to late diastolic contraction of the atria (atrial kick) against high ventricular pressures. Increased blood pressure activates angiotensin II either by local mechanical stretching of myocardiocytes or as a result of the activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. Angiotensin II promotes concentric remodeling of the heart, increasing stiffness of the organ, thus, decreasing compliance.

Key learning point: An S4 heart sound is associated with decreased left ventricular compliance, often due to concentric hypertrophy from long-standing hypertension.
Image Description:

Systole
1: Mitral valve closes (1st heart sound)
1–2: Isovolumetric contraction
2: Aortic valve opens
2–3: Ventricular ejection

Diastole
3: Aortic valve closes (2nd heart sound)
3–4: Isovolumetric relaxation
4: Mitral valve opens
4–1: Ventricular filling (3rd and 4th heart sounds)

D) INCORRECT:

With increased left ventricular filling pressures, the left ventricle fills more rapidly in diastole, producing an S3 gallop rather than an S4 gallop. An S3 gallop is caused by rapid left ventricular filling and sudden deceleration of blood when the ventricle reaches its elastic limit. This sound can be a normal variant in young, healthy individuals. In adults, it is typically a sign of ventricular dysfunction due to heart failure, dilated cardiomyopathy, and/or volume overload.

E) INCORRECT:

Impaired closure of the mitral valve, which can be due to organic changes in the valve leaflets or chordae tendinae (as seen in degenerative mitral valve diseases, rheumatic fever, or infective endocarditis), causes mitral regurgitation (MR). MR is typically associated with a high-pitched, blowing, holosystolic murmur that is best heard over the apex (the 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line) as blood backflows from the left ventricle to the left atrium. While an early diastolic sound (S3) might be heard in severe cases of MR, S4 gallop is not a typical finding.
questions.hint: The bell of the stethoscope detects low-pitched sounds, while the diaphragm is ideal for hearing high-pitched heart sounds (e.g., ejection clicks, high-pitched murmurs). An isolated low-pitched, late diastolic sound is consistent with an S4 gallop, which occurs as the atria pump blood into the ventricles. An S4 gallop is almost always pathological.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to your clinic for a routine health maintenance examination. He reports feeling well and has no history of serious illness. He is at the 60th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are normal. Lung examination is normal. A grade 3/6 systolic ejection crescendo-decrescendo murmur is heard along the lower left sternal border. The murmur decreases in intensity with rapid squatting and increases with the Valsalva maneuver. This patient is at increased risk for which one of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Predamaged heart valves (e.g., aortic stenosis, mitral valve regurgitation) or congenital heart defects (e.g., ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis) can predispose to infective endocarditis. However, systolic murmurs caused by valvular disease or congenital heart disease generally demonstrate increased intensity with rapid squatting (increased preload) and decreased intensity with the Valsalva maneuver (decreased preload).

B) INCORRECT:

Cerebral aneurysms may be associated with coarctation of the aorta. Coarctation may present with a systolic ejection murmur over the left paravertebral area due to blood flowing through the aortic narrowing and/or a continuous murmur from collateral vessels heard between the shoulder blades. If the intensity changes at all, it would decrease with the Valsalva maneuver and/or increase with rapid squatting. Coarctation of the aorta may also be accompanied by other symptoms, such as hypertension, lower extremity cyanosis, lower extremity claudication, cold feet, dyspnea on exertion, or chest pain.

C) CORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) can manifest with a systolic ejection murmur caused by subvalvular dynamic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO). Rapid squatting increases left ventricular preload, decreasing the dynamic LVOTO and softening the intensity of the murmur, whereas the Valsalva maneuver decreases preload, which exacerbates dynamic obstruction and makes the murmur louder. Unlike a murmur due to valvular or supravalvular aortic stenosis, which is best heard at the right upper sternal border, the systolic ejection murmur due to HCM is best heard at the left lower sternal border and/or Erb's point (cardiology).

Hypertrophic myocardium, fibrosis, and disarrangement of cardiac myocytes predispose to potentially lethal ventricular arrhythmias, which can lead to sudden cardiac death, usually during or after physical activity. Since HCM is the most common cause of sudden cardiac death in young athletes, patients with HCM should be advised to avoid strenuous sports. Those at particularly high risk (e.g., survived a previous arrhythmia) should undergo placement of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator.

Key learning point: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy increases the risk of sudden cardiac death in young individuals due to ventricular arrhythmias, especially during or after physical activity.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary apoplexy can occur in mitral stenosis, which presents with a diastolic murmur heard in the third left intercostal space but not a systolic murmur.

E) INCORRECT:

Paradoxical embolism can be associated with atrial septal defects (ASD) or ventricular septal defects (VSD). An ASD can present with a systolic murmur, but it would likely also show fixed splitting of the S2. A VSD can present with a holosystolic (not systolic ejection) murmur. The intensity of both defects would decrease rather than increase with the Valsalva maneuver (decreased preload) and increase with rapid squatting (increased preload).
questions.hint: Echocardiography would most likely show asymmetric interventricular septal hypertrophy and/or systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve, which are consistent with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of worsening fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. He reports occasionally waking up at night coughing and gasping for air. He emigrated from Bangladesh 2 months ago. He does not take any medications. Vital signs are normal. On auscultation, there are crackles at both lung bases. Physical examination reveals a high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur radiating to the axilla. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation can cause a holosystolic murmur; however, it is typically heard best at the lower parasternal region, does not radiate to the axilla, and does not have a blowing quality. Like all right-sided heart murmurs, it intensifies during deep inspiration. In contrast, this patient's murmur intensifies on expiration. Moreover, tricuspid valve regurgitation is extremely rare and more commonly manifests with symptoms of right-sided heart failure (e.g., peripheral pitting edema, jugular venous distention).

B) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis can result in manifestations of left-sided heart failure. However, the murmur associated with aortic stenosis is typically a harsh mid-systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur that may radiate bilaterally to the carotids and is heard best in the 2nd intercostal space at the right upper sternal border.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's auscultatory findings indicate mitral regurgitation as the cause of his left-sided heart failure. His history of emigration from Bangladesh makes rheumatic heart disease (RHD) the most likely etiology. RHD is the leading cause of acquired valve defects in developing countries; in ∼ 65% of cases, it is the mitral valve that is affected. While regurgitation murmurs are common in the early course of RHD, murmurs of stenosis or mixed murmurs typically develop as the disease progresses. Other causes of primary mitral regurgitation include degenerative mitral valve diseases (e.g., mitral valve prolapse, mitral annular calcification, ruptured chordae tendineae) and infective endocarditis.

See “Auscultation in valvular defects” table.

Key learning point: A high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur radiating to the axilla is characteristic of mitral regurgitation, often due to rheumatic heart disease in individuals from developing countries.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis can result in manifestations of left-sided heart failure. However, the murmur associated with mitral stenosis is typically a low-frequency, mid-diastolic (not systolic) rumble with an associated loud S1. This patient's history of immigration from a developing country should raise suspicion for rheumatic heart disease, the most common cause of mitral stenosis, as the cause of his murmur. However, mitral stenosis typically occurs later in the course of rheumatic heart disease in middle-aged adults.

E) INCORRECT:

Aortic regurgitation can result in manifestations of left-sided heart failure. However, the murmur associated with aortic regurgitation is typically a high-frequency, blowing decrescendo murmur during early diastole that is heard best in the left 3rd and 4th intercostal spaces and along the left sternal border.
questions.hint: This patient presents with fatigue, exertional dyspnea, paroxysmal nocturnal awakening, dry cough, and crackles at both lung bases; these findings suggest a diagnosis of left-sided heart failure. Auscultation shows a high-frequency, holosystolic blowing murmur that radiates into the axilla and is heard best at the apex.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to your clinic because of decreased exercise tolerance. Over the past four months, he has experienced progressively worsening shortness of breath while walking his dog and also reports shortness of breath when lying in bed at night. His temperature is 36.4°C, pulse is 82/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 155/53 mm Hg. On cardiac examination, you hear a high-pitched, decrescendo murmur that occurs immediately after S2 and is best heard along the left sternal border. An S3 gallop is present. Carotid pulses are strong. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

An early diastolic decrescendo murmur that is heard best at the left sternal border suggests aortic regurgitation (AR). Regurgitation of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle (LV) causes widened pulse pressure with a decreased diastolic blood pressure. To maintain an adequate cardiac output despite regurgitation, initially, there is a compensatory increase in stroke volume. Over time, the increased LV end-diastolic volume leads to LV enlargement and eccentric myocardial hypertrophy. Patients may be asymptomatic for decades despite progressive LV dilation. In chronic AR, this compensatory response results in left ventricular dysfunction, and patients develop signs and symptoms of left heart failure (exertional and nocturnal dyspnea, S3 gallop). The diagnosis of AR should be confirmed with transthoracic echocardiography.

Maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., handgrip) increase the intensity of the associated murmur as a result of the enlargement of regurgitation volume across the valve.

Key learning point: Aortic regurgitation presents with a high-pitched early diastolic decrescendo murmur at the left sternal border, widened pulse pressure, and symptoms of left-sided heart failure.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral regurgitation can cause dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea. However, mitral regurgitation produces a holosystolic murmur that is heard best at the apex (5th intercostal space at the left midclavicular line), not a diastolic murmur that is heard best at the left sternal border.

C) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis (MS) can cause dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea. Although MS produces a decrescendo diastolic murmur, it is usually slightly delayed after S2 and would be heard best along the left midclavicular line (at third left intercostal space), not the left sternal border. A prominent S1 and/or an opening snap of the mitral valve after S2 may also be present. Furthermore, since MS restricts left ventricular blood flow, left ventricular preload is decreased, such that carotid pulses would be diminished and an S3 would not be present.

D) INCORRECT:

While very rare, tricuspid regurgitation (TR) can cause signs of right-sided heart failure (lower extremity edema, hepatomegaly), but not signs of left-sided heart failure (dyspnea, orthopnea). Furthermore, TR produces a holosystolic murmur heard best at the 4th intercostal space of the left sternal border, not a diastolic murmur.

E) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis (AS) can cause dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea. However, it commonly causes a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur, not a decrescendo diastolic murmur. Furthermore, AS will more likely cause an S4 from a stiff myocardium due to left ventricular hypertrophy, rather than an S3. Carotid pulses tend to be diminished and delayed, not prominent.
questions.hint: This patient's murmur would become louder with handgrip.

questions.text: You are seeing a 64-year-old man who recently immigrated from Haiti. He presents with a 3-week history of progressively worsening exertional dyspnea and fatigue. In the past few days, he has developed orthopnea. Over the past year, he has experienced intermittent fever, night sweats, and cough, but has not previously sought medical evaluation. His temperature is 37.8°C. A chest x-ray is provided. Further evaluation is most likely to reveal which one of the following findings?

choices.text: Elimination of S2 heart sound splitting with inspiration.
Painless erythematous lesions on palms or soles.
Prominent "a" wave on jugular venous pressure tracing.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Splitting of the second heart sound (S2) is a physiological finding heard during inspiration. It is caused by the early closure of the aortic valve (A2) in relation to the pulmonary valve (P2) when intrathoracic pressure is decreased. In conditions such as aortic stenosis (AS), ventricular septal defect with Eisenmenger syndrome, and left bundle branch block, elimination of S2 splitting can occur because A2 is delayed and superimposed on P2. Although severe, long-standing aortic stenosis can result in fatigue, dyspnea, orthopnea, and cough (due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema), chronic AS is not associated with fever or night sweats but with symptoms such as syncope, palpitations, and angina. Moreover, an x-ray would not show pericardial calcifications but an enlarged cardiac silhouette.

B) INCORRECT:

Painless erythematous lesions on the palms or soles (Janeway lesions) are highly suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE), which can manifest with dyspnea, fatigue, cough, fever, and night sweats. However, the symptoms of IE have an acute or subacute onset (days to weeks), whereas this patient had fever, night sweats, and a cough for a year before developing dyspnea and fatigue. Moreover, an x-ray would not show pericardial calcifications, and IE is almost always associated with the development of a new heart murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

A crescendo-decrescendo (diamond-shaped) systolic ejection murmur best heard in the second right intercostal space is a common finding in aortic stenosis (AS). While severe, long-standing AS can result in chest pain, fatigue, dyspnea, orthopnea, and cough (due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema), fever and night sweats are not commonly seen. Finally, symptoms such as syncope, angina, and palpitations are expected in chronic AS, and x-ray would show an enlarged cardiac silhouette rather than the pericardial calcifications seen here.

D) CORRECT:

Normally, the decrease in intrathoracic pressure during inspiration expands the compliant right ventricle, resulting in a decrease in jugular venous pressure. In constrictive pericarditis, compliance of the right ventricle is decreased and the right ventricle fails to expand during inspiration. This, alongside a possible increase in baseline jugular venous pressure in constrictive pericarditis due to restricted right ventricular filling during late diastole, leads to an increase in jugular venous pressure during inspiration, and therefore, jugular venous distention on inspiration. This phenomenon, which is called Kussmaul sign, can also be seen in patients with restrictive cardiomyopathy and right atrial or ventricular tumors. Management options for constrictive pericarditis include NSAIDs, colchicine, glucocorticoids, pericardiectomy, and treatment of the underlying condition (e.g., antitubercular or immunomodulatory therapy).

In cardiac tamponade without underlying pericarditis (e.g., traumatic hemopericardium), the jugular venous pressure is increased as a result of impaired right ventricular filling. However, the right ventricle is still compliant and a decrease in intrathoracic pressure can be transmitted to the right ventricle across the fluid-filled pericardial sac. Kussmaul sign would not be expected in traumatic cardiac tamponade.

Key learning point: Kussmaul sign—jugular venous distention that worsens with inspiration—is a classic physical finding in constrictive pericarditis due to impaired right ventricular filling.

E) INCORRECT:

On a jugular venous pressure tracing, the “a” wave is caused by atrial contraction in late diastole. A prominent “a” wave is a sign of increased atrial contraction pressure due to restricted filling of the right ventricle (e.g., tricuspid valve stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, cardiac tamponade). In constrictive pericarditis, right ventricular filling is only impaired when the elastic limit of the pericardium is reached. As a result, all right ventricular filling rapidly occurs in early diastole, producing a prominent and deep x descent and y descent on venous pressure tracing rather than a prominent “a” wave.
questions.hint: New-onset dyspnea, orthopnea, and fatigue alongside pericardial thickening and calcifications on x-ray indicate constrictive pericarditis. In this patient with an immigration history from an endemic region and a prolonged history of night sweats, fever, and cough, the most likely etiology of constrictive pericarditis is tuberculosis.

questions.text: You are seeing a 28-year-old woman with a history of scleroderma who presents with a 6-month history of progressively worsening dyspnea. On examination, she has an accentuated P2 heart sound, a right ventricular heave, and a grade 2/4 diastolic decrescendo murmur at the left upper sternal border. Jugular venous distention is measured at 10 cm, and there is 1+ lower-extremity edema. Her lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by elevated jugular venous pressure, Kussmaul sign, and a pericardial knock. An accentuated P2 heart sound or a right ventricular heave is not characteristic of constrictive pericarditis.

B) INCORRECT:

A patent ductus arteriosus would produce a continuous, machinery-like murmur.

C) CORRECT:

Scleroderma is one of the more common connective tissue diseases to result in pulmonary arterial hypertension, in which there is increased pulmonary vascular resistance, with subsequent hypertrophy of the right ventricle. Cardiac examination findings characteristic of pulmonary arterial hypertension include an accentuated P2 heart sound (related to the forceful closure of the pulmonic valve), a right ventricular heave (related to right ventricular hypertrophy), and elevated right heart filling pressures. The diastolic murmur of pulmonic regurgitation (a so-called Graham Steell murmur) may also be audible, as in this patient.

Key learning point: An accentuated P2 heart sound, a right ventricular heave, and evidence of right heart failure are most consistent with a diagnosis of pulmonary arterial hypertension.

D) INCORRECT:

Eisenmenger syndrome (i.e., right-to-left intracardiac shunting, cyanosis, and polycythemia) is caused by pulmonary hypertension related to a congenital defect between the right and left heart circulations. Scleroderma does not cause Eisenmenger syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis is most often a congenital condition that produces a systolic ejection murmur along the left sternal border. The P2 component is usually soft, not accentuated.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man comes to your clinic for follow-up after a preemployment electrocardiogram (figure) was performed. He has not seen a health care provider in many years. He reports no significant medical history, feels well, and does not use tobacco or alcohol. He takes no medications. His blood pressure is 190/105 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 75 beats per minute. Cardiac examination reveals a sustained apical impulse with no audible murmurs. Kidney function and serum electrolyte levels are normal. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is associated with LVH but not hypertension. In addition, patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and significant left ventricular outflow-tract obstruction often have a murmur related to this obstruction or a mitral regurgitation murmur related to systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve.

B) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma that is sufficiently severe and chronic to cause LVH typically produces a range of symptoms, including headaches and palpitations.

C) INCORRECT:

Although aortic stenosis can cause LVH, it does not cause hypertension and is easily identified by the presence of a systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur.

D) CORRECT:

This asymptomatic patient has primary hypertension, with electrocardiographic evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH). A sustained apical impulse indicates that LVH is present. The patient’s echocardiogram would be likely to show thickened LV walls and an elevated LV mass index.

Key learning point: The cardiac examination finding of a sustained apical impulse is most consistent with a diagnosis of left ventricular hypertrophy.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal artery stenosis is a rare cause of hypertension and resultant LVH and is often associated with impaired kidney function.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to your clinic for a well-child examination. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. His height is at the 70th percentile and his weight is at the 55th percentile. Vital signs are normal. On examination, you hear a harsh, holosystolic murmur over the left lower sternal border. The intensity of the murmur increases when he clenches his fist forcefully for a sustained period. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patent ductus arteriosus leads to a murmur heard best at the left infraclavicular region. This murmur occurs during both diastole and systole (i.e., a continuous murmur), unlike the harsh holosystolic murmur seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

An atrial septal defect can cause a systolic murmur because of increased flow across the pulmonary valve, but the murmur is heard best at the left upper sternal border. In addition, this murmur has a midsystolic crescendo-decrescendo character, and it is accompanied by a wide, fixed split second heart sound.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can cause a murmur as a result of mitral regurgitation (MR) or left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. A murmur due to MR is holosystolic and increases in intensity with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload (e.g., handgrip) but is heard best at the cardiac apex (5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line). A murmur due to LVOT obstruction is heard best at the left lower sternal border but has a midsystolic, crescendo-decrescendo character and decreases in intensity with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse leads to a systolic murmur that increases in intensity with maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., handgrip), which is seen here. However, this murmur is heard best at the cardiac apex (5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line). In addition, this murmur has a late systolic crescendo character, and it is preceded by a click due to tensing of the chordae tendinae.

E) CORRECT:

A ventricular septal defect (VSD), which causes a left-to-right shunt, leads to a harsh holosystolic murmur because of turbulent blood flow across the defect. The murmur is heard best at the left lower sternal border (tricuspid area) and becomes louder with maneuvers that increase left ventricular afterload (e.g., handgrip) because of increased left-to-right shunting. The murmur is typically louder with smaller defects because of the large pressure difference between the left and right ventricles.

Key learning point: A harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border that increases with handgrip is characteristic of a ventricular septal defect.
questions.hint: The handgrip maneuver increases afterload by increasing total peripheral resistance.

questions.text: You are seeing a 3-month-old boy in your clinic for a routine follow-up. He was born at 32 weeks' gestation to a 35-year-old woman. Vital signs are normal. On examination, you hear a grade 4/6 continuous murmur best at the left infraclavicular region. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Persistent truncus arteriosus results in a single conduit providing mixed venous and arterial blood to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic circulations. Cardiac examination findings would include a single loud S2, the presence of an ejection click at the cardiac apex or left sternal border, and harsh systolic murmurs at the left sternal border, unlike the continuous murmur heard in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is associated with a harsh crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard along the left mid- to upper-sternal border. The murmur can decrease in intensity as the degree of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction worsens because of increased right-to-left shunting of blood. The examination findings of a continuous murmur would not be seen in patients with TOF.

C) CORRECT:

A patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) manifests with a continuous machinery murmur best heard in the left infraclavicular area. The machinery murmur is generated as blood continuously shunts from the high-pressure aorta through the ductus arteriosus into the low-pressure pulmonary artery. It may envelop the S2 and is not usually affected by positional changes. Patients with moderate-sized PDAs may present with bounding pulses, widened pulse pressure, and symptoms of heart failure.

Key learning point: A continuous "machinery" murmur best heard at the left infraclavicular area is characteristic of a patent ductus arteriosus.
Image Description:

Continuous systolic and diastolic heart murmur (machinery murmur)

D) INCORRECT:

Atrial septal defects (ASD) manifest with pulmonary outflow tract murmurs heard best at the left upper sternal border and are often associated with fixed splitting of S2. ASDs are often low-velocity shunts that produce insufficient flow to be audible. Larger shunts may cause diastolic flow murmurs across the tricuspid valve owing to a large left-to-right shunt. However, a continuous murmur would not be seen in patients with an ASD.

E) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal defects (VSD) manifest with holosystolic, harsh sounding murmurs, best heard in the left lower sternal border. These murmurs often obliterate the S2 and are associated with a palpable thrill. Neonates present with an asymptomatic heart murmur or, in cases of moderate-to-large sized defects, with signs of heart failure. The examination findings in this patient reveal a continuous murmur, which is not suggestive of a VSD.
questions.hint: This patient's condition typically affects premature infants or infants with a congenital rubella infection.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 3-week history of exertional shortness of breath. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His current medications are aspirin, losartan, and simvastatin. His blood pressure is 150/84 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. On cardiac auscultation, you hear an S3 gallop. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which one of the following?

choices.text: Left-to-right shunt through the atrial septum.
Elevated serum brain natriuretic peptide levels.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A left-to-right shunt through the atrial septum is the pathophysiologic mechanism of an atrial septal defect (ASD). Auscultatory findings in ASD include a systolic ejection murmur over the left upper sternal border (due to increased blood flow across the pulmonary valve), a diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border (due to increased blood flow across the tricuspid valve), and a fixed, widely split S2, none of which are seen in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Elevated levels of brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) and the presence of an S3 gallop both indicate increased ventricular filling pressures, which is seen in heart failure (HF). BNP, which is released in response to stretching of the cardiac ventricle, is a sensitive parameter to evaluate patients with symptoms of HF. High levels of BNP (> 400 pg/mL) in patients with classic symptoms of HF have a high positive predictive value and are associated with a worse prognosis, while low values (< 100 pg/mL) in patients with dyspnea have a high negative predictive value for HF.

Key learning point: Elevated brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) levels are a sensitive marker for heart failure, reflecting increased ventricular filling pressures and cardiac wall stretch.

C) INCORRECT:

Calcification of the aortic valve is the most common cause of aortic stenosis (AS). The resulting left ventricular outflow tract obstruction causes left ventricular hypertrophy, which manifests with an S4 gallop, not an S3 gallop. Moreover, the murmur that is characteristic of aortic stenosis is a systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard loudest at the upper right sternal border, which this patient does not have.

D) INCORRECT:

Rupture of a papillary muscle would result in acute mitral regurgitation (MR), a complication associated with myocardial infarction (MI). While this patient has several risk factors for MI, including hypertension and hyperlipidemia, he has no symptoms of chest pain or signs to suggest ongoing acute coronary syndrome. Additionally, this patient lacks the characteristic holosystolic, blowing murmur of MR, which is best heard in the apex.

E) INCORRECT:

Digital clubbing is primarily seen in patients with pulmonary diseases that result in chronic hypoxemia, such as cystic fibrosis, bronchiectasis, interstitial lung disease, and non-small cell lung cancer. It may also be seen in cyanotic heart disease and infectious endocarditis, which are unlikely diagnoses in a 66-year-old afebrile patient. As clubbing is a nonspecific physical finding, it is unlikely to help pinpoint the diagnosis. While shortness of breath can be of pulmonary origin, this patient's S3 gallop on examination is more concerning for a cardiac cause.

questions.text: You are seeing a previously healthy 25-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after collapsing during soccer practice. His father died of sudden cardiac arrest at age 36. His pulse is 73/min and blood pressure is 125/78 mm Hg. Cardiac examination is shows a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard best at the apex and left lower sternal border as well as an S4. An ECG shows large R waves in the lateral leads and deep S waves in V1 and V2. Further evaluation is most likely to show which one of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Calcification of the aortic valve occurs secondary to aortic valve stenosis (AS). Patients can present with exertional syncope due to an inability to increase cardiac output, while examination may reveal a harsh systolic ejection murmur, and an ECG may show evidence of compensatory left ventricular hypertrophy. However, calcific AS is a disease seen in advanced age. Even though individuals with an anatomically abnormal (unicuspid or bicuspid) valve can develop calcific AS one or two decades earlier than those with a normal (tricuspid) valve, this 25-year-old patient is too young to have developed calcific AS.

B) INCORRECT:

Fibrinoid necrosis of the mitral valve occurs in acute rheumatic fever (RF), which is typically preceded by a group A streptococcal pharyngitis. Acute RF could lead to significant mitral regurgitation, manifesting as exercise intolerance. However, mitral regurgitation would cause a pansystolic murmur rather than a systolic ejection murmur, and ECG findings in acute rheumatic fever include different degrees of atrioventricular block rather than the changes seen in this patient. Furthermore, this patient has not had a recent GAS infection and has had no other features of rheumatic fever.

C) INCORRECT:

Significant dilatation of the left ventricle is characteristic of dilated cardiomyopathy. While patients with dilated cardiomyopathy may present with exertional dyspnea from heart failure, they are less likely to experience exertional syncope. ECG findings in dilated cardiomyopathy include first-degree AV block, left bundle branch block, left anterior fascicular block, and other intraventricular conduction abnormalities, or evidence of prior infarction as the underlying cause; none of these findings are seen in this case. Examination may reveal a pansystolic murmur of secondary mitral regurgitation heard best at the apex due to LV dilatation, whereas this patient has a prominent systolic ejection murmur.

D) INCORRECT:

Dilatation of the aortic root occurs in patients with connective tissue syndromes (e.g., Marfan syndrome), a bicuspid aortic valve, hypertension, atherosclerosis, aortic dissection, and aortic stenosis. Significant dilatation of the aortic annulus can lead to aortic regurgitation, which results in a decrescendo diastolic murmur, in contrast to this patient's systolic ejection murmur. Furthermore, this patient's condition is not associated with aortic root dilation.

E) CORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) manifests with an area of increased left ventricular wall thickness that is typically asymmetrical and involves the septum or anterolateral LV wall. Along with mitral valve and papillary muscle abnormalities, septal hypertrophy can lead to left ventricular outflow tract obstruction, resulting in exertional syncope and a systolic ejection murmur. Although the systolic murmur in patients with HCM does not significantly radiate into the carotid arteries, left ventricular outflow tract obstruction in obstructive HCM may mimic an aortic stenosis murmur and may be heard as a subtle ejection murmur on auscultation of the carotids. The ECG shows high voltage QRS complexes, indicating left ventricular hypertrophy. HCM is most commonly a hereditary condition, which explains the history of sudden cardiac death in this patient's father.

The intensity of the murmur associated with HCM decreases with maneuvers that increase venous return (e.g., rapid squatting) because they increase preload, which in turn decreases the pressure gradient across the obstruction. This change in murmur intensity can help differentiate HCM from other causes of systolic murmurs, such as ventricular septal defect and mitral regurgitation.

Key learning point: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is characterized by asymmetric septal hypertrophy on echocardiography, often leading to left ventricular outflow tract obstruction and increased risk of sudden cardiac death in young individuals.
Image Description:

Hypertrophy of the myocardium results in reduced diastolic compliance and filling of the left ventricle (sometimes also of the right ventricle). Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can occur with or without left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) occurs when hypertrophy of the interventricular septum and systolic anterior movement (SAM) of the mitral valve leaflet results in the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction.
questions.hint: This young man has a family history of sudden cardiac death and has just experienced exertional syncope.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with a 3-hour history of chest discomfort and shortness of breath. She reports feeling her heart “racing” intermittently. Her medical history includes hypertension and diabetes. Vital signs are BP, 125/85; P, 135; R, 22; oxygen saturation, 94% on room air. Physical examination shows an irregular pulse with varying intervals between beats. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sublingual nitroglycerin addresses chest pain but does not address the primary concern of the irregular rhythm with significant pulse deficit.

B) INCORRECT:

Adenosine is used for stable supraventricular tachycardia with a regular rhythm. Additionally, rhythm confirmation should precede any antiarrhythmic intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

Carotid massage is a vagal maneuver used for regular supraventricular tachycardias. Carotid massage is not indicated for this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's examination is highly suggestive of atrial fibrillation. An immediate ECG is essential to confirm the arrhythmia and guide further management decisions.

E) INCORRECT:

While chest x-ray might be useful to evaluate for heart failure or other complications, it is not the immediate priority.

questions.text: A physician assistant student is measuring the blood pressure of a 55-year-old man. The student has the patient sit quietly with his back supported and feet flat on the floor. The student selects an appropriately sized cuff and places it on the patient's bare upper arm, supporting the arm at heart level. The student inflates the cuff 30 mm Hg above the point where the radial pulse disappears and then deflates the cuff at a rate of 5 mm Hg per second while auscultating. Which step in this process is most likely to produce an inaccurate result?

choices.text: Supporting the patient's arm at the level of the heart
Inflating the cuff 30 mm Hg above the estimated systolic pressure
Having the patient sit with feet flat on the floor
Deflating the cuff at a rate of 5 mm Hg per second
Placing the cuff on the patient's bare upper arm

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This is a critical step for an accurate measurement. If the arm is positioned below heart level, the reading can be falsely high due to hydrostatic effects. Conversely, if the arm is positioned above heart level, the reading can be falsely low. Supporting the arm at the level of the right atrium (mid-sternum) is the standard procedure.

B) INCORRECT:

This is the correct procedure for cuff inflation. First, the systolic pressure is estimated by palpating the radial pulse while inflating the cuff. Inflating the cuff 20–30 mm Hg above this point ensures that the brachial artery is fully occluded. This technique helps avoid falsely low systolic readings that can occur due to an auscultatory gap.

C) INCORRECT:

This is a correct and essential step for an accurate blood pressure measurement. Having the patient sit with their back supported and feet flat on the floor helps ensure they are relaxed. Crossing the legs can tense muscles and may increase systolic blood pressure by 2–8 mm Hg, leading to a falsely elevated reading.

D) CORRECT:

The recommended deflation rate for a manual blood pressure reading is 2–3 mm Hg per second. Deflating the cuff too rapidly, such as at 5 mm Hg per second, is a common error that can lead to significant inaccuracies. A fast deflation rate may cause the observer to miss the first Korotkoff sound, leading to an underestimated systolic pressure. It can also lead to a falsely low or overestimated diastolic pressure. This error compromises the diagnostic value of the measurement.

E) INCORRECT:

This is the correct technique for cuff placement. Placing the cuff over clothing can interfere with the transmission of pressure and muffle the Korotkoff sounds, potentially leading to an inaccurate, often overestimated, blood pressure reading. The cuff should always be applied to a bare arm for optimal accuracy.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother with a low-grade fever for three days. He has been slightly more tired than usual but is still playing normally. He is previously healthy with past checkups documenting normal cardiac exams. On auscultation, there is a soft, vibratory grade 2/6 midsystolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border, radiating minimally to the apex. The murmur becomes softer when he stands and is most audible while supine. He appears comfortable, and the rest of the physical exam is normal (see lab result).


Test
Result
Normal Values


Hemoglobin
110 g/L
112 - 165 g/L


Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this child’s murmur?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Innocent flow murmurs in school-age children manifest as soft, vibratory, midsystolic sounds best heard at the left lower sternal border. These murmurs exhibit positional variation, becoming less audible when standing and more noticeable while supine, reflecting normal hemodynamic changes related to venous return. The child's history of normal cardiac examinations, absence of symptoms, and lack of concerning physical findings support that the murmur arises from normal blood flow dynamics through anatomically intact heart structures.

Key learning point: In children, innocent murmurs can appear during febrile illnesses or anemia due to increased cardiac output, and are often transient, especially if previous cardiac exams were normal.

B) INCORRECT:

A ventricular septal defect (VSD) typically produces a holosystolic, harsh-sounding murmur that does not vary with position. The described murmur is soft, vibratory, and midsystolic, with intensity changes upon standing, which is more consistent with a benign phenomenon. The absence of other hemodynamic findings further argues against a VSD.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) presents with a dynamic systolic murmur that typically increases in intensity when standing due to decreased preload. The murmur in this child softens on standing and is most audible when supine, consistent with benign murmurs. Additionally, HOCM is often associated with a family history or symptoms like exertional dyspnea, which are absent here.

D) INCORRECT:

Aortic stenosis typically produces a harsh, crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border with radiation toward the neck. The murmur's soft, vibratory nature and positional variation, along with the child's age and normal cardiac history, do not align with aortic stenosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of worsening fatigue and shortness of breath for the past 7 months. She emigrated from China 2 years ago. Cardiac examination shows a loud S1. Which of the following contributes most to this auscultation finding?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid valve opening can be affected in patients with rheumatic heart disease as a result of tricuspid stenosis (TS). However, in the case of TS, tricuspid valve opening would be associated with an opening snap, which is distinct from the S1 heard during early diastole (i.e., immediately after S2). The closure rather than the opening of the tricuspid valve contributes to S1. Tricuspid valve closure in patients with TS can cause a loud S1, as seen here, but TS would cause features of right heart failure (e.g., peripheral edema, ascites) rather than those of left heart failure (e.g., dyspnea).

B) CORRECT:

The first heart sound (S1) is a physiological sound created by the closure of the mitral valve and tricuspid valve that occurs at the onset of isovolumetric ventricular contraction, when ventricular pressure exceeds atrial pressure. S1 is best heard in the 5th left intercostal space in the midclavicular line (cardiac apex). In patients with mitral stenosis (MS) and mobile leaflets (i.e., in mild to moderate MS), a loud S1 is often present because the increased left atrial pressure moves the mitral leaflets further apart during diastole so that the leaflets snap shut with a greater velocity at the start of ventricular systole. If the leaflets are immobile (e.g., in severe MS) or if the leaflets fail to close completely (e.g., in mitral regurgitation), S1 would be soft. In the US, rheumatic heart disease is the most common cause of mitral stenosis in patients that have recently migrated from a developing country.

MS is associated with other auscultatory findings such as an opening snap followed by a low-pitched diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation. However, as MS progresses, left atrial pressure increases and causes the opening snap to occur earlier in the cardiac cycle. If atrial fibrillation develops in a patient with MS, the presystolic accentuation of the murmur will be absent.
Image Description:

Systole
1: Mitral valve closes (1st heart sound)
1–2: Isovolumetric contraction
2: Aortic valve opens
2–3: Ventricular ejection

Diastole
3: Aortic valve closes (2nd heart sound)
3–4: Isovolumetric relaxation
4: Mitral valve opens
4–1: Ventricular filling (3rd and 4th heart sounds)

C) INCORRECT:

Aortic valve closure can be affected in patients with rheumatic heart disease as a result of aortic stenosis, which would also cause fatigue and dyspnea, as seen here. However, aortic valve closure generates the A2 component of S2, and patients with aortic stenosis would typically have a soft S2 (due to immobile atrial valve leaflets) and/or paradoxical splitting of S2. Aortic valve closure does not contribute towards the generation of S1.
Image Description:

If the aortic and pulmonary valves do not close simultaneously, splitting of S2 can be heard on auscultation.

Types of split:
(A) Physiological split
(B) Wide split
(C) Fixed split
(D) Paradoxical (reversed) split

A2: closure of aortic valve; P2: closure of pulmonary valve

D) INCORRECT:

Late diastolic contraction of the atria (“atrial kick”) against a stiff, noncompliant ventricle can cause S4. This auscultatory finding can be seen in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which can present in young adults with worsening fatigue and dyspnea, as seen here. However, atrial contraction is not responsible for the generation of S1.
Image Description:

Systole
1: Mitral valve closes (1st heart sound)
1–2: Isovolumetric contraction
2: Aortic valve opens
2–3: Ventricular ejection

Diastole
3: Aortic valve closes (2nd heart sound)
3–4: Isovolumetric relaxation
4: Mitral valve opens
4–1: Ventricular filling (3rd and 4th heart sounds)

E) INCORRECT:

The opening of a stiff pulmonary valve is responsible for a pulmonary valve ejection click, which can be heard in patients with mild or moderate pulmonary stenosis (PS). However, a pulmonary valve ejection click is heard during early systole (i.e., immediately after S1); pulmonary valve closure does not contribute to the generation of S1. Moreover, PS is typically encountered among pediatric patients with other congenital heart diseases (e.g., tetralogy of Fallot).
Image Description:

Crescendo-decrescendo murmur with ejection click and widely split second heart sound

F) INCORRECT:

Rapid ventricular filling, which occurs during early diastole, can generate S3if the ventricular filling pressure is increased (e.g., mitral regurgitation, heart failure) or if the ventricles are dilated (e.g., dilated cardiomyopathy). However, ventricular filling itself does not significantly increase ventricular pressure, so it does not contribute to the generation of S1. Rather, isovolumetric ventricular contraction, which causes ventricular pressure to surpass atrial pressure, leads to the event that generates S1.
Image Description:

Cardiac pressure-volume loops with examples of changes seen during increased contractility, preload, and afterload.
questions.hint: Worsening fatigue and dyspnea with a loud S1 in a young individual who recently immigrated from a developing country raises concern for a sequela of rheumatic heart disease.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-week history of worsening shortness of breath, lower extremity swelling, and a 3-kg (6.6-lb) weight gain. Crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest. Cardiac examination shows a dull, low-pitched early diastolic sound at the 5th left intercostal space that becomes louder in the left lateral decubitus position at end-expiration. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these auscultation findings?

choices.text: Increased capacity of the pulmonary circulation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased myocardial compliance is the cause of the S4 gallop, which is an important sign of heart failure with diastolic dysfunction or other conditions with reduced myocardial compliance (e.g., active ischemia, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy). However, in contrast to the auscultation findings in this patient, S4 gallop is a late diastolic sound.

B) INCORRECT:

Heart failure due to systolic dysfunction is due to decreased, not increased, ventricular contractility. Increased ventricular contractility can be seen after myocardial hypertrophy and is a sign of a well-functioning heart.

C) CORRECT:

Increased left ventricular end-systolic volume is the most likely cause of this patient's third heart sound (S3). In heart failure with systolic dysfunction, the myocardium cannot effectively contract to empty during systole, resulting in ventricular volume overload. During the rapid ventricular filling phase, a sudden deceleration of blood occurs when the ventricle reaches its elastic limit, producing a third heart sound.
Image Description:

I–IV: anatomical locations of heart valves

1. Aortic area: 2nd right parasternal intercostal space (ICS)
- Ideal site for auscultation of aortic valve murmurs (1a). The murmur of aortic stenosis also radiates to the carotid arteries (1b).

2. Pulmonary area: 2nd left parasternal ICS
- Ideal site for auscultation of pulmonary valve murmurs

3. Tricuspid area: 4th left parasternal ICS
- Ideal site for auscultation of tricuspid valve murmurs

4. Mitral area: 5th left ICS in the midclavicular line (over the cardiac apex)
- Ideal site for auscultation of mitral valve murmurs (4a). The murmur of mitral regurgitation also radiates to the left axilla (4b).

D) INCORRECT:

The left ventricular filling pressure would be decreased in a patient with hypovolemia. In this patient with features of heart failure, LV filling pressure would be increased.

E) INCORRECT:

An increase in the capacity of the pulmonary circulation occurs during inspiration as a result of a decrease in intrathoracic pressure. This results in a split S2 due to early closure of the aortic valve (A2) and delayed closure of the pulmonary valve (P2). However, it does not result in an S3, nor is it related to heart failure.
questions.hint: The patient presents with clinical features of heart failure (shortness of breath, crackles, lower extremity swelling, weight gain); the early diastolic heart sound is S3, a strong predictor for heart failure.
